Borghese per li quadri Vendutigli rogato dal Belgio noto [in another document the name of the notary is given as Betti, see Della Pergola, Dipinti, 1959, II, p. 215] A. Chi. 20 Agosto 1608’.

‘Public instrument of the receipt of 10 M/4 made by the Cardinal Sfondrato in favour of the Cardinal Borghese for the paintings sold to him drawn up by the Belgian notary [in another document the name of the notary is given as Betti, see Della Pergola, Dipinti, 1959, II, p. 215] to whom 20 August 1608’.
Passavant 1860, II, no. 25

‘Tableau d’autel pour le monastère de Saint-Antoine de Padoue, à Pérouse. […] Peintures du gradin. Il y avait cinq sujets, que les religieuses vendirent, antérieurement, à la reine Christine de Suède, en 1663, au prix de 601 écus romains. (Voyez Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug., p. 125.) Ils passèrent de la galerie Bracciano dans celle du duc d’Orléans, et quand cette dernière fut en majeure partie vendue à Londres, en 1798, ces tableaux se trouvèrent divisés entre plusieurs amateurs anglais. […] B) Le Portement de Croix. […] C’est le plus beau des tableaux du gradin, et il est bien conservé. (H.,9’’, l.,23’’.) Ce tableaux fut vendu dans la galerie Bryan, à Londres, en 1798, pour 150 liv. sterl., à M. Hibbert. Le possesseur actuel est M. Ph. John Miles, à Leigh Court, près Bristol. […].’

‘Panel from the altarpiece for the monastery of St. Anthony of Padua at Perugia. […] Paintings of the Predella. There were five subjects which the nuns sold before to Christina of Sweden in 1663 for the price of 601 Roman scudi. (See Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug., p. 125.) They passed from the Bracciano gallery to this of the Duke of Orleans, and when the latter said was for the great part sold in London in 1798, these paintings were separated between several English amateurs. […] B) The Carrying of the Cross. […] It is the most beautiful painting of the predella, and it is well preserved. (H.,9’’, l.,23’’.) This painting was sold at Bryan’s gallery in London in 1798 for £150 to Mr Hibbert. The present owner is Mr Ph. John Miles at Leigh Court near Bristol.’

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: 1913: Fischel, Oskar. Raphael’s Zeichnungen. Berlin: G. Grote, 1913-1941, vol. 8, nos. 346 9, 362, 368, 369.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: ’25. Altarpiece for the Monastery of St. Anthony of Padua at Perugia. […] The Central Picture. […] The Lunette. […]In 1678 the nuns sold these two paintings to Count Gio. Antonio Bigazzini at Rome for about 2,000 scudi, receiving also a copy of each painting for their high-altar. (See Annibale Mariotti : Lettere pittoriche Peruginei, etc. Perugia, 1778, in-8. p. 126. He got this information from the archives in Perugia.) Later, these panels entered the Colonna Gallery, and, at the end of the last century, they became the property of the king of Naples. They are well preserved, or nearly as the main panel is cracked across its width, and one of the two cracks crosses the three heads of the women.’

‘25. Tableau d’autel pour le monastère de Saint-Antoine de Padoue, à Pérouse. […] Tableau principal. […] Le tympan. […] En 1678, les religieuses vendirent ces deux peintures au comte Gio. Antonio Bigazzini, à Rome, moyennant deux mille scudi, et reçurent en outre une copie de l’un et l’autre tableau pour le maître-autel. (Voy. Annibale Mariotti : Lettere pittoriche Peruginei, etc. Perugia, 1778, in-8. p. 126. Il a tiré ces renseignements des archives de Pérouse.) Plus tard, ces tableaux entrèrent dans la galerie Colonna, et, a la fin du siècle dernier, devinrent la propriété du roi de Naples. Ils sont bien conservés, a cela près cependant que le tableau principal est fendu dans toute sa largeur, et qu’une des deux fentes traverse les trois têtes de femmes.’
Passavant 1860, II, no. 25
The haloes and gilded decoration on the Virgin’s headdress are mordant-gilded, and it is evident from the X-ray image that the mordant used is X-ray opaque (probably containing lead pigments).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: ‘7. Christ bearing the Cross, seen. Centre-piece of the Predella of the picture, formerly in the church of the nuns of St. Antonio in Perugia, now in Naples. With the side-pieces, 9 and 10 (sic! 10 and 11), obtained by Christina Queen of Sweden from those nuns, by the intervention of Cardinal Azzolini. Mr. Hibbert, 150l. J. P. Miles, Esq., at his seat, Leigh Court.’ […]. 10. A Pietà, Christ in the lap of his Mother, wept over by his Friends, seen. Engraved in Crozat, No. 27, by Du Flos. Valued at 100l., sold at 60 gs. It was long in the cabinet of Count Carl Rechberg at Munich. Now in the possession of Mr. M. A. White, Barron Hill, Staffordshire. 11. Christ on the Mount of Olives, seen. Very much spoilt even in the time of Crozat, 1729. Engraved in his work, No. 26, by Larmessin. Valued at 100l., sold for 42 gs. A few years ago it was in the possession of Lord Eldin, Edinburgh. Now in that of Mr. Rogers.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Board Minutes, 16/07/1871, p. 8 (see also National Gallery Report 1871, p. 2)

Read a letter from the Treasury, dated 13 June last, approving of the reception of the Colonna Raphael on loan in the National Gallery, as proposed, with the further condition that it shall not be understood, as implying any intention on the part of the Majesty’s Government to purchase the picture.

When the painting was acquired in 1913 from Lord Windsor he mentioned that if the director wished to change the frame he would like to have the present one back as it was made especially for him in Perugia (Letter from the Earl of Plymouth [Lord Windsor] to Hawes Turner, 31/01/1913, NG Archive, NG7/421/3). Two photographs from 1923 and 1928 show the painting in a frame which was apparently cut and adapted to fit the painting. In May 1931 a new frame for this painting was supplied by Arthur Field, their no. 3769, for £18 (Letter from NG to A. Field, 05/05/1931, NG Archive, 105.3 Framing and Hanging 1930-33). Upon arrival Francis Draper made a glazing door for the frame supplied by Messrs Field (their no. 3769, Letter from NG to F. Draper, 08/05/1931; Estimate from F. Draper to NG, 15/05/1931; Letter from NG to F. Draper, 19/05/1931). The estimate describes the frame as ‘4 in. reverse black and gold engraved frame’ which corresponds to the painting’s current frame. The current frame is an Italian sixteenth-century cassetta style frame with sgrafitto frieze made in the nineteenth century (F2919). In 1994 Louisa Davey made a new sight moulding which follows more closely the contours of the panel, reducing the shadows cast on the picture (Conservation Report by L. Davey, 28/02/1995).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Morelli 1683, p. 23

‘V. Unito à Santa Lucia stà il Convento di S. Antonio da Padova delle Monache di S. Chiara, nel quale, tempo già era una bellissima Tavola di Rafaello da Urbino, oggi però ivi non si vede, per haverla le medesime Monache alienata, ora nell’Altar Maggiore della lor Chiesa è una bella Tavola fatta da Vincenzo Pelegrini detto il Pittor Bello con la Madonna, & il Bambino, che pone l’Anello in dito à S. Catarina.’

‘V. Attached to Santa Lucia is the Convent of S. Antonio da Padova of the nuns of S. Chiara, in which, time already was a most beautiful painting by Raphael of Urbino, which one no longer sees today, however, the same nuns having sold it, today, on the high altar of their church is a beautiful painting made by Vincenzo Pelegrini said the Pittor Bello with the Virgin and Child who gives the ring on his finger to S. Catherine.’

In the Virgin and Child group clear signs of pouncing were found, the dots have been joined and most of them brushed away leaving the simple drawing. The infrared reflectogram mosaic detail of the Child shows the simple linear drawing typical of a transfer from a cartoon and some of the spolveri around his hands and legs. As ever with Raphael there are changes to these figures – the Child’s head has been changed and his eyes moved, and in the lower half of his body the arm and hand and the legs have been changed.

Urbino, Italy, Galleria Nazionale delle Marche, “Raffaello e Urbino: La sua formazione e I rapporti con la città natale,” April 4–July 12, 2009, cat. no. 35, illus. (color), detail (color) 66.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: There is no record of the frame when the painting was presented as an indefinite loan in 1976 by Lady Mersey, subsequently acquired by the Gallery in 1983. The current frame, a fifteenth-century Italian style carved moulding frame (F6480) was made by John England (Head of Framing, 1979-2001) in 1983 (Report by A. I. Hopson, 13-24/05/1983, Frame Archive).

GC analysis was carried out in the 1960’s or early 1970’s and the results were published as follows: brown earth, linseed oil, P/S 1.8; green robe, linseed oil, P/S 1.8; blue sky, walnut oil, P/S 3.0 [1]. Unfortunately the original data is no longer available but the variation in methyl palmitate to methyl stearate ratios is clearly evident suggesting the use of both linseed and walnut oils. More recent analysis in 2001 using GC–MS confirmed this result. A sample of dark paint from the left angel’s sash was found to contain fatty acid methyl esters in the following ratios: A/P 1.7, P/S 1.6, A/Sub 4.0. The presence of a large peak for methyl azelate indicates that the binding medium is oil and the methyl palmitate to methyl stearate ratio identifies it as linseed oil. The ratio of the azelate to suberate methyl esters indicates a degree of heat pre-polymerisation. However further samples from the flesh paint of Christ’s upper thigh and from the blue sky were found to contain heat-bodied walnut oil with fatty acid methyl esters detected as follows: flesh paint A/P 1.5, P/S 3.1, A/Sub 3.1; blue sky A/P 1.7, P/S 2.3, A/Sub ca. 2.
Notes [1] N. Brommelle, and P. Smith, eds., ‘Conservation and Restoration of Pictorial Art’, The International Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works, Butterworths, London, 1976, Table 9.1, pp 76-7.

’31. Altartafel fürs Kloster S. Antonio di Padova zu Perugia. […] Die Bilder der Predella. Es sind deren fünf, welche die Nonnen schon früher im Jahr 1663 an die Königin von Schweden um 601 Scudi romani verkauften. (Siehe Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug. p. 125.) Mit der Gallerie des Herzogs von Bracciano kamen sie in die des Herzogs von Orléans in Paris, und aus dieser, als sie im Jahr 1798 zum grössten Theil in London öffentlich verkauft wurde, an verschiedene Kunstfreunde in England. a. Christ auf dem Ölberg. […] Übrigens ist es sehr verputzt und übermalt. In Bryan’s Gallery in London wurde es im Jahr 1800 um L. 42 verkauft. Letztlich erstand es Herr Samuel Rogers in London aus dem Nachlass des Lords Eldin in Edinburgh.’

‘Altarpiece for the Monastery of St. Anthony of Padua at Perugia. […] Paintings of the Predella. There were five subjects which the nuns sold earlier to Christina of Sweden in 1663 for the price of 601 Roman scudi. (See Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug., p. 125.) They passed from the Bracciano gallery to the one of the Duke of Orleans, and when the latter was for the great part sold in London in 1798, these paintings were separated between several English amateurs. a. Christ on the Mount of Olives. […] It is, for the rest, very rubbed and repainted. Sold at Bryan’s gallery for 42 pounds, in 1800. Samuel Rogers bought it from the succession of Lord Eldin at Edinburgh.’

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Document Digitisation relating to NG168, NG168A Cartoon C1-C2, Raphael W139, N-0168-00-000045, NGSL 2004 000193, NGSL 2004 000248, NGSL 2008 000688

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: There is no record of the frame when the painting was acquired in 1847 from Thomas Egerton. Ralph Wornum noted that the painting was put in a new frame and case in 1870, apparently the third one since its acquisition (Wornum Diary, 14/07/1870 and 01/12/1870, NG Archive) and possibly captured in a photograph of 1935 (NG Archive, NG.30.1935.6). The painting was probably reframed again with the simple gilded moulding frame, recorded in a photograph of 1987, previously kept in a shadow box (see the photograph of 1967 showing a copy after Raphael's Madonna di Loreto (Malibu, J. Paul Getty Museum, 71.PB.16) hung with NG213, NG744 and NG2919 in Room 11A in 1967). A similar shadow box associated with the painting (F20693) and today in storage was for the cartoon inventoried at the Gallery as 213A; it was transferred to the British Museum in 1994 (London, British Museum, 1994-5-14-57). The 1935 photograph shows the drawing displayed underneath the painting and protected by a curtain. The shadow box for the painting seems lost. For security purposes as well as for aesthetic reasons it was decided in 1987 to make a new frame for the painting to provide an adequate base for the fittings that attach the frame securely to the wall (Report, 11/11/1987, Frame Archive). The Italian cassetta style frame was made in England in November 1987 by C. A. Powell (F213). A similar frame with slightly different measurements was made for the cartoon at the same time (F20338).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Because of the small size of the picture, and its excellent state of preservation, no samples were taken during the present examination; the painting was studied under the stereomicroscope at magnifications up to 80x. Vertical centre line, incised. Fluid underdrawing (pen?) over traces of pouncing, from a surviving pricked cartoon. Some freehand elaboration adding hatching and small details such as bushes in the background. Ruled straight lines (for example, for swords) are incised.
By descendance to Viscountess Mersay.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Lines forming a square grid (each square corresponding to roughly two-thirds of a Perugian foot or piede) lightly incised; fluid black freehand underdrawing, with some hatching for the shadows of the draperies. Traces of pouncing found in the head and hands of the Virgin and Child. Numerous incisions for straight lines, often not very careful - the lines are frequently longer than necessary in the architecture, or have slipped and have had to be redrawn. Some straight lines in the architecture are ruled using a dry material, but not incised (they show in infrared but not in the X-radiograph). Circles and arcs are incised with compasses. The freehand incision around the figure of Saint Nicholas of Bari apparently indicates a change during painting.

N. 354 / Pitture Ch’è Diomede Ricci m[aest]ro di casa dell’Illu[strissi]mo S[ignore] Card[ina]le Borghese Quattromila di scudi m[oneta] il prezzo di diversi quadri di Pittura comprì dall’Illu[strissi]mo S[ignore] Card[ina]le S[anta] Cecilia per mezzo dell’Illu[strissi]mo S[ignore] Card[ina]le Paravicino per pagarli al S[ignor] Pavolo Benio proc[urato]re dell’emerito S[ignore] Card[ina]le S[an]ta Cecilia, e devenire debito all’Illu[strissi]mo S[ignor] Card[ina]le Borghese. Di Casa li 20 Agosto 1608 – 4000. Gio:[vanni] Batti[sta] Borghese

No. 354 / Paintings ? who is Diomede Ricci master of the house of the Illustrious Signor Cardinal Borghese 4000 scudi coins the price of several paintings bought from the Illustrious Signor Cardinale Santa Cecilia through the mediation of the Most Illustrious Signor Cardinal Paravicino to pay Signor Pavolo Benio procurator of the emeritus Signor Cardinal of Santa Cecilia, and be owed to the Illustrious Signor Cardinal Borghese. At home 20 August 1608- 4000. Giovanni Battista Borghese
Perugia, Archivio di Stato, Archivio Notarile, no. 226, Ser Francesco di Ser Iacopo, fol. 365r–v Published in Manzoni 1899, pp. 643–44, with some errors and misdated to 12th December.

In nomine domini amen. Anno Domini millesimo cccc.lxxxx. indictione optava tempore domini Innocentii pape optavi die xii. octobris. Actum Perusii in domo infrascripti testatoris in camera ubi iacet infirmus sita in porta Solis et parocchia sancti Florentii in suos confines presentibus Antonio Nicolai aliter al Patriarcha, Basilio ser Tholomei ser Nicolai, Antonio Bartolomei Antonii, civibus Perusinis porte Solis, Bonifatio Melchioris Fini de Perusio porte sancte Suxanne, Guidone Cristofori Vignatelli de Perusio porte sancti Angeli, Antonio Nicolai di Asisio habitatore Perusii et Egidio Meneculii dicto el Camerlingho, de castro Sancti Fortunati testibus ad infrascripta habitis vocatis et ab infrascripto testatore rogatis. Cum hominum vita labilis sit et caduca et nil certius morte et nil incertius hora mortis id circho spectabilis vir Filippus Ansidi Simonis de Perusio, porte Solis et parocchie sancti Florentii, sanus, per gratiam domini nostri Jesu Christi, mente, sensu et intellectu, licet corpore languens, in bona et recta scientia et memoria costitutus, timens mortis casum, nolens intestatus decedere, ne de suis bonis et rebus aliqua inter aliquos valeat exoriri discordia, hoc presens testamentum numcupativum, quod dicitur suscriptis in infrascriptum modum, facere procuravit et fecit. In primis quidem comendando animam suam omnipotenti deo, a quo creata extitit, iudicavit corpus suum sepelliri apud eclesiam sancti Florentii [fol. 365v] apud quam sui corporis sepulturam elegit, et super sui corporis sepultura expendi illam quantitatem pecuniarum, quam videtur et placebit infrascriptis suis fideicommissariis. Item iudicavit et reliquit eclesie sancti Florentii et fratribus ipsius eclesie florenos centum ad rationem xl. bolognenorum pro quolibet floreno pro dote capelle ipsius testatoris erepte in dicta eclesia sub nomine sancti Nicolai de penitendis per infrascriptum eius heredem et convertendos in emptione bonorum stabilium; que bona sic emenda non possint ullo umquam tempore vendi set continue fructus recolligendi ex bonis emendis sint pro victu fratrum dicte eclesie; cum hoc onere dictis fratribus iniunto, quod dicti fratres perpetuis futuris temporibus teneantur debeant et ascripti sint qualibet die qua misse secundum ritum sancte matris eclesie celebrantur in dicta capella celebrari facere missam unam, et in die festivitatis sancti Nicolai de mense decenbris celebrari facere missam cantando. Et si dicti fratres dicte eclesie in premissis remissi essent et predicta non observarent, dictam eclesiam et fratres a dicto legato privavit et bona sic emenda devenire voluit ad infrascriptum eius heredem et ad ipsius heredes.

In the name of the Lord amen. By the eighth proclamation of the year of the Lord 1490 in the time of the Lord Pope Innocent VIII on the 12th day of October. Enacted at Perugia in the privacy of the house of the undersigned maker of this will where he lies infirm among his relatives in a room situated at the Gate of the Sun, and of the parish of San Fiorenzo; present are: Antonio Nicolai otherwise known as the Patriarch, Basilio ser Tholomei ser Nicolai, Antonio Bartolomei Antonii, Perugian citizens of the Gate of the Sun, Bonifatio Melchioris Fino of Perugia of the Gate of San Susanna, Guido Cristofori Vignatelli of Perugia of the Gate of San Angelo, Antonio Nicolai of Assisi inhabitant of Perugia and Egidio Meneculi called el Camerlingho, of the Fortress of San Fortunati, witnesses thought worthy to be called to add their signatures, and requested by the undersigned testator. Since the life of men is fleeting and frail and nothing is more certain than death and nothing more uncertain than the hour of death, for that reason the worthy gentleman Filippo Ansidei Simonis of Perugia, of the Gate of the Sun and of the parish of San Fiorenzo, by the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, sound in judgment, apprehension and understanding albeit enfeebled in body, in good and right knowledge and memory, fearful of the event of his death and not wishing to die intestate, lest any discord should arise amongst any concerning his goods and possessions, he has arranged to make and has made this present last will, which is said to the above named in the undersigned way. First in commending his soul to Almighty God, from whom it came forth created, he has decided that his body is to be buried at the church of San Fiorenzo [fol. 365v] at which church he has chosen the burial-place of his body, and over and above the burial of his body that amount of money to be expended as shall seem to please those entrusted with his bequest whose signatures appear below. Moreover he has decided to leave to the Church of San Fiorenzo and to the brothers of the same church, for the endowment of a chapel erected of the same testator in the aforesaid church under the name of San Nicholas for those who must do penitence; a hundred florins; for computation: 40 Bolognese florins to be taken in exchange for any other florin in the charge of his undersigned heir and to be converted by purchase into stable goods; those goods thus bought may not at any time ever be sold; the income continually to be gathered up again from the goods which are to be sold for the provision of the brothers of the aforesaid church; with the obligation enjoined on the brothers, that the aforesaid brothers are, for all time perpetual, to hold themselves bound to proclaim on any day on which in the aforesaid chapel masses are held according to the rite of the holy mother of the church, to cause to be celebrated one mass, and on the day of the festival of San Nicholas in the month of December to cause to be celebrated a sung mass. And if the aforesaid brothers of the aforesaid church should be remiss in their promises and not observe the aforesaid, he has expressed his wish to deprive the aforesaid church and brothers of the aforesaid legacy and that the goods thus purchased are to pass to his undersigned heir and to his own heirs.

Florence, Archivio di Stato, Carte di Urbino, Classe I, Div. G: Filza 148, fol. 919

’1600. 18. III. Roma. Giacomo Sorbolongo al Duca Francesco Maria. Quando credeua hauer la nota delle Pitture del Card.le Sfondrato, mi ha fatto dire dal suo Maestro di casa, che ha ripensato meglio non uolere priuarsi delle ecc(ellent)e si truoua, et che alcune profane ha gia dato uia, che questo è uero, ma erano per Io più copie di non molto conto, et per sua natura ua facendo simili uariationi, però io non ho mai mostrato d’hauerne pure scritto all’A. V., se bene egli medesimo me ne fece ricercare, et quando sentissi tornarli tale capriccio, procurarei di hauerne la lista, con informatione di quel più fosse da auertire; perche quando si risoluesse darle uia, credo si trouarebbe altri ui attenderebbono, et che si potrebbe truouar qualche modo da accomodarsi.’

’18 March 1600. Rome. Giacomo Sorbolongo to Duke Francesco Maria. When I thought I had the note about the paintings of Cardinal Sfondrato, he had his Master of the house tell me, that he had had second thoughts and didn’t want to deprive himself of the very good ones, and it appears, that he had already given away some of the secular ones, it is true, but they were mostly copies of not great quality, and by his own nature he keeps changing his mind, but I have never shown that I had actually written to Your Highness, although he himself suggested me to do so, and when I feel that he is changing his mind again, I could try to have the list with information about which one we needed to be informed of most; so that once it was decided to give them away I believe others would be found who would be interested, and we could find some way to come to a compromise.’

1929: Exhibition of Italian Paintings, Usher Art Gallery, Lincoln, 1 February 1929 - 11 May 1929. 1929-1930: Long term loan, Laing Art Gallery, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, 5 June 1929 - 30 April 1930. 1930: Exhibition of Italian Art, Ferens Art Gallery, Hull, Summer 1930, no. 20. 1930-1931: Exhibition of Italian Paintings, Doncaster Museum and Art Gallery, Doncaster, 1 November 1930 - 28 January 1931. 1931: Exhibition of Italian Paintings, Harrogate Corporation Art Gallery, Harrogate, 29 July - 4 November 1931. 1934: Exhibition of Italian Masters, Bradford City Art Gallery, Bradford, 14 May - 9 October 1934. 1958-1962: Long term loan, Arts Council of Great Britain, Laing Art Gallery, Newcastle, 2 June 1958 - 9 March 1962.

The metal strips and nails at the upper and lower edges have been removed since the painting was X-rayed. The large red wax seals on the reverse (which probably contain vermilion) are clearly visible, as is the broken seal coinciding with the area of the Baptist’s cross. The other smaller white circles and marks visible in the X-radiograph are also connected with seals and other substances on the reverse of the panel (now covered by labels). The meandering shadowy lines visible in the upper right corner are woodworm tunnels. The use of lead white to model all the colours, including the flesh tints, landscape and draperies, means that the X-ray image of the painting relates very closely to the visible image, and is without the strong contrasts to be seen in some of Raphael’s Florentine works (e.g. NG 168). There are no evident pentimenti. The blurred area around the Baptist’s right hand could be mistaken for an alteration. The infrared reflectogram, however, shows that it was painted exactly as in the underdrawing. The increased X-ray opacity and indistinct image in this area may therefore be related to a variation in the thickness of the lead-containing imprimitura, or possibly to something on the reverse of the panel. The small flake losses show as black, particularly those from around the edges of the Virgin’s pink dress.
Venice, Biblioteca Marciana, MS Ital. VII. 245 (9232), fol. 36v (see also Stefani 1879-1902, XVII (1886), col. 60; Shearman 2003, I, pp. 171-2)

‘Di Roma, di Ser Vetor Lipomano, vidì letere di 12 [...]. Scrive come il papa Julio si fè retrar e lo dete in Santa Maria in Populo, qual lo someja molto natural, e fu posto su l’altar, e starà cussi 8 zorni; tutta Roma core a vederlo, par uno jubileo, tanta zente vi va.’

‘I saw a letter of the 12th written from Rome by Sir Vetor Lipomano [...]. He writes how Pope Julius has had a portrait of himself made, which resembles him very much, and given it to the church of Santa Maria del Popolo, where it has been placed on the altar and will remain thus for eight days. All Rome flocks to see it, it seems a Jubilee, so many people go there.’

There is no record of the frame when the painting was acquired in 1839 from William Beckford. Ralph Wornum noted that the frame was (partly) regilt in 1857 and again in 1863 (Wornum Diary, 14/12/1857 and 03/10/1863, NG Archive). A photograph from 1928 shows the painting in a gilt hollow frame which was probably made by Francis Draper in 1926 (Letter from NG to F. Draper, 04/06/1926, Frame Archive; see also Note by S. Perry, 20/11/2000, Frame Archive). It is probably identical with a frame in storage at the National Gallery (F20163; information provided by L. Davey and I. Kocum). The inner separate picture and glazing slip was made later for Ludovico Mazzolino's Trinity with the Holy Family, Nicholas of Tolentino and Angels (NG169). The inner doorframe for the Saint Catherine of Alexandria (NG168) as shown in the 1928 photograph would have measured about 9 cm on each side in order to fit the painting (72.20 x 55.70 cm) into its frame (90.4 x 74 cm). Some decoration on the outer corners, missing on the frame in storage although traces of former embellishment are present, is visible in the 1928 photograph. A photograph of 1941 depicting the painting in wartime storage shows that it was set later into a simpler frame with slim dimensions. The current period frame, a carved and gilded sixteenth-century Italian cassetta frame (F168) may have been purchased from Pollok in the late 1940s (Levi Survey NG168, Frame Archive).

’Loan by Mr John P. Morgan of his Colonna Raphael to the Gallery. A letter was read dated 3 March 1902 from Mr J. P. Morgan just addressed to Sir Charles Tennant offering on behalf of his father to lend to the National Gallery for at least six months the ‘Colonna Raphael’ thus being exhibited at the Royal Academy of Arts. It was resolved unanimously that under the circumstances the offer be gratefully accepted.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Watercolour (by J. Read Fth?) after the original painting with inscription on the back by John Smith, private collection, Cambridgeshire (brought to my attention by Mark Scott, 2009)

J. Read Fth
Done from the original Picture which was bought by me in conjunction with Pi(a)zzetta, of Lord Northwick, and sold (by me) to W(illia)m Beckford Esq. for 3000 guineas
John Smith
49 Gt Marlboro St
March 1824

A shadow area at the ankle of the Christ child’s proper left foot consists of white, some vermilion and some earth pigment, over a very thin layer of red lake (presumably an overlap with the Virgin’s red dress beneath).

As a foil to the curving rhythms running through the figure group, Raphael introduced a dark architectural backdrop with two arched openings, suggestive of a loggia, giving onto a distant landscape reminiscent of the Roman campagna. Visible through the left-hand arch are a church, with a bell tower and a hemispherical apse, and hills shrouded in blue haze beyond. Through the right-hand arch is a larger building, perhaps also a church, buttressed and ringed by perimeter walls. In the underdrawing, the landscape and buildings extend beneath the central pier, suggesting that Raphael originally conceived the composition with the group located in front of a simple parapet. He subsequently drew in the vertical mouldings which so satisfyingly frame the graceful oval of the Virgin’s head and the S-shaped bend of her neck, and then added the segments of the arches with a compass, closing of the composition artificially with two strips painted at either edge.[2] The idea of showing the Virgin in an interior between two arched windows occurs in early works by Leonardo and his followers, and it is possible that Raphael had some such model in mind. Notes [2] For other examples of Raphael modifying the backgrounds of his compositions as they developed see Raphael: From Urbino to Rome 2004, cats 45 and 62.

The Procession to Calvary, the centrepiece of the predella, shows Christ carrying the cross, escorted by five foot-soldiers, one of whom drags him along by a rope. Behind him, Simon of Cyrene helps bear the weight of the cross. The rearing white horse and the twisting pose of the turbaned horseman at the head of the procession suggest knowledge of Leonardo’s unfinished fresco of the Battle of Anghiari. The group of the Virgin supported by the three Maries was inspired by figures in a Deposition for the high altar of SS. Annunziata in Florence, begun by Filippino Lippi around 1503. As was the case with other artists of his acquaintance, Raphael appears to have had access to Filippino’s designs, since his group is closer to the underdrawing of the painting than to the finished work (which was completed by Perugino following Filippino’s death in 1504).[7] The pose and to some extent the type of Christ in the Procession were inspired by the Communion of the Apostles by Justus of Ghent, an artist whose work greatly influenced both Giovanni Santi and Raphael. The procession divides into three distinct groups (the horsemen, the figures around Christ, and the three Maries and John), knitted together by several figures looking back over their shoulders at the groups behind. The figures are animated by a variety of poses, costumes and headgear (Vasari singled out for praise the ‘beautiful movements’ of the soldiers dragging Christ), and the procession in all its diversity may indicate Raphael’s familiarity with Schongauer’s engraving of the same subject.[8] Raphael achieved greater sophistication and compositional depth in the crowd gathered about the preaching Baptist in the nearly contemporary Ansidei predella, also influenced by Northern prints. Notes [7] Nelson 2004, p. 33–4. [8] Hollstein 1999, XLIX, pp. 32–3. We are grateful to Lorne Campbell for this suggestion.

‘31. Altartafel fürs Kloster S. Antonio di Padova zu Perugia. […] Die Bilder der Predella. Es sind deren fünf, welche die Nonnen schon früher im Jahr 1663 an die Königin von Schweden um 601 Scudi romani verkauften. (Siehe Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug. p. 125.) Mit der Gallerie des Herzogs von Bracciano kamen sie in die des Herzogs von Orléans in Paris, und aus dieser, als sie im Jahr 1798 zum grössten Theil in London öffentlich verkauft wurde, an verschiedene Kunstfreunde in England. […] c. Der Leichnam Christi […] In Bryan’s Gallerie um L. 60 verkauft. Aus dem Cabinet Bonnemaison kam es in das des Grafen Karl von Rechberg in München, und aus diesem an Sir Thomas Lawrence. Jetzt besitzt es Hr. M. A. Whyte in Barron Hill bei Ashborne, Derbyshire. Es ist von guter Erhaltung.’

‘Altarpiece for the Monastery of St. Anthony of Padua at Perugia. […] Paintings of the Predella. There were five subjects which the nuns sold earlier to Christina of Sweden in 1663 for the price of 601 Roman scudi. (See Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug., p. 125.) They passed from the Bracciano gallery to the one of the Duke of Orleans, and when the latter was for the great part sold in London in 1798, these paintings were separated between several English amateurs. […] c. The dead Christ […] Sold at Bryan’s Gallery, London, for £60. It passed from the Bonnemaison collection into that of the Count Karl von Rechberg in Munich, and from this into that of Sir Thomas Lawrence. Today it is in the possession of M. M.-A. Whyte, at Barron Hill, close to Ashborne, Derbyshire. This painting is in good condition.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Waagen 1838, II, p. 136

’Mr. Roger’s Collection. […] Next to these pictures is a Christ on the Mount of Olives, by Raphael, at the time when he had not abandoned the manner of Perugino. This little picture was once a part of the predella to the altar-piece which Raphael painted in the year 1505 for the nuns of St. Anthony at Perugia. It came with the Orleans Gallery to England, and was last in the possession of Lord Eldin in Edinburgh. Unhappily it has been much injured by cleaning and repairing, but in many parts, particularly in the arms of the angel, there are defects in the drawing, such as we do not find in Raphael, even at this period. So that, most probably, the composition alone should be ascribed to him, and the execution to one of the assistants, who painted the two saints belonging to the same predella, now in Dulwich College.’

Fiorenzo, at Perugia, but it was sold to Lord Spencer in 1764, and by him presented to his brother, the Duke of Marlborough, in whose palace at Blenheim it still remains. […].’
By inheritance from Ferdinand I, King of Naples and the Two Sicilies, to his son Francis I of the Two Sicilies

Perugino’s influence also makes itself felt in the technique of Raphael’s painting, particularly in the drawing of the drapery folds over the saint’s left arm (even more apparent in the cartoon), the rich saturated colours, and the hatched modelling in the shadows. However, Saint Catherine’s pose is far more dynamic than anything in Perugino’s oeuvre, attesting in form and spirit to the double influences of Leonardo and Michelangelo. Her beautiful curving contrapposto is partly derived from Leonardo’s standing Leda which Raphael had copied not long before, and the spiralling arrangement of her hair and the yellow lining of her mantle are also characteristic of Leonardo’s manner. The burgeoning sense of sculptural form and the foreshortening of the raised head almost certainly derive from Michelangelo’s marble Saint Matthew (1505–6) for the interior of Florence Cathedral. In Raphael’s drawing after the statue, made in connection with the bearers in the Baglioni Entombment, and of almost exactly the same moment, he characteristically clarified all the outlines and forms of Michelangelo’s unfinished sculpture. Indeed, Catherine’s pose is infused with all the clarity and grace of a classical statue (the figure has been likened to a Venus pudica and to a classical Muse).

Bought from Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans (Philippe Égalité) in Paris in 1792.

The high resolution detail infrared reflectograms show more clearly the lack of penetration of the thickly applied paint, and the effect of the tinted priming which, because it contains black pigment, shows in some areas as a pattern of free brush-strokes crossing forms. Looking at the reflectogram of the head it is possible to see fine lines which could mistakenly be interpreted as underdrawing, for example the lower eyelid of the right eye, around the nostril, around the ear and the edge of the hat, but a careful check with the aid of a stereobinocular microscope revealed that all of these lines are in the surface paint, or are later retouchings. Similarly areas which might have been underdrawn hatching to indicate shadow, such as around the nostril, were found to be the result of feathering of the paint by Raphael. In the beard several diagonal scratches are visible in the reflectograms, the most severe of which also show clearly as depressions on the painting. These are probably related to problems during the polishing of the gesso ground before painting commenced and show dark in infrared reflectography because the priming is thicker in the depressions.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The painting is generally well preserved. Apart from the loss of the battens the panel is in an unaltered state (the nineteenth-century batten visible in the upper channel in the photograph taken in 1977 has since been removed). The wide central board has taken up a pronounced convex warp and there is some woodworm damage, particularly along the two joins. The last cleaning took place in 1970 when the overpainting of the green background was removed. There are no large losses but there are many scattered retouchings (which show as dark in the infrared reflectogram) over disruptions caused by faults in the wood, small flake losses and drying cracks, especially in the red paint of the mozzetta and throne. The areas of flesh painting are in exceptionally good condition, the only significant damage being a small vertical scratch on the sitter’s forehead. The final deep green glazes of the curtain in the background, however, have been damaged in past cleanings of the picture. On the right side the glazes retain their original thickness and depth of colour only where they have pooled in the depressions in the paint from the underlying pattern, for example the crossed keys to the right of the sitter’s shoulder. The tones must once have graduated evenly into the darkest green of the corner of the room. Here the vulnerable green glazes have been protected by the application of a final glaze of red lake to darken the colour. A red glaze was also applied to the cast shadow on the left and again the intended effect is compromised by the lighter patches of green now exposed as a result of thinning of the green glaze layers.

Hier blieb es, seiner Bestimmung nach, an dreihundert Jahre, bis dass es von einem Franzosen um 4000 (sic! 2500 scudi, see above) Scudi nebst einer schlechten Copie, die nun die Stelle des Originals einnimmt, erstanden wurde. Dieses ziert jetzt die reiche Gallerie des Cardinals Fesch in Rom. […]’.

‘[…] Raphael painted this altarpiece for the Chapel of the family Gavri or Gavari in the Dominican Church of Citta di Castello and as it seems around the same time as the before said paintings, around the year 1500. It embellishes now the rich Gallery of the Cardinal Fesch in Rome. […]’

The Mond Crucifixion is a relatively early work, painted about 1502–3, and large in scale, standing almost three meters high (actual size 283.3 x 167.3 cm). Underdrawing is visible in many places in normal light and infrared photography produces excellent images of the underdrawing where the paint is penetrated. For example the Magdalen’s pink drapery shows simple linear drawing, clearly in a liquid medium. The lack of major changes and the simple, formulaic nature of the drawing is typical of Raphael’s underdrawings made from cartoons but despite careful examination, no evidence could be found of squaring or of registration lines for a cartoon and no pouncing was seen, so that the method used for transferring the design to the panel is still not known. For this picture, infrared reflectography did not add a great deal to what was already known except to highlight one interesting anomaly. In infrared reflectography some of the underdrawing clearly visible in normal light disappears, while other areas of underdrawing show clearly.
Crowe and Cavalcaselle 1885, II, pp. 129-31

‘IV.E Tableau de Raphaël Sanzio d’Urbin. Peint sur Toile, ayant de hauteur 2 Pieds 6 Pouces, sur 2 Pieds de large. Quelques critiques ont jugé par l’air de la tête de la Sainte Vierge que ce Tableau pouvoit être de la composition de Timothée Viti d’Urbin, élève de Raphaël. […] Ce Tableau a beaucoup souffert, particulièrement dans le Ciel. Il est vraisemblable qu’en le nettoyant on n’aura pas pris les précaution nécessaires pour son entière conservation.’

‘ IVTH Painting by Raphael Sanzio of Urbino. Painted on canvas, 2 feet 6 inches high, 2 feet wide. Some critics have judged from the look of the head of the Virgin, that this painting could be the composition of Timoteo Viti of Urbino, pupil of Raphael. […] this painting has suffered a lot, especially in the sky. It is obvious that by cleaning it the necessary precautions for its entire conservation have not been taken.’

Although the figures are not here arranged within a constructed architectural space as they are in the Sposalizio and the Ansidei Madonna, the design is rooted in the same careful geometrical planning. It has frequently been pointed out that the composition is made up of a series of arcs, echoing the arched top of the composition, detectable for example in the placement of the angels’ feet, and the heads of the figures below the cross, and that the horizon line falls at the level of the capitals in the frame.[7] All of this implies that Raphael mapped out the design of the altarpiece in advance, probably in a composition drawing similar to the Study for a Virgin and Child enthroned with Saint Nicholas of Tolentino (Städelsches Kunstinstitut, Frankfurt, inv. 376). As with other altarpieces such as the Ansidei Madonna, he may have transferred the design to the panel by means of squaring (there is no sign of pouncing). Underdrawing in a liquid material is present under most of the main features, and Raphael painted up to the drawn boundaries, making no revisions or pentiments, a further indication that the whole project was scrupulously designed in advance. Notes [7] Shearman 1986a, pp. 203–10.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Kunstblatt, 5th August 1847, p. 152

These three scenes from Christ’s Passion formed the predella of an altarpiece painted by Raphael for the convent of Sant’Antonio da Padua in Perugia, a religious house (now largely destroyed) for female tertiaries of the Franciscan Order. The altarpiece, known as the Colonna Altarpiece, consisted of a unified central panel depicting the Virgin and Child enthroned with saints (Saints Peter, Paul, Catherine and another female martyr) surmounted by a lunette representing God the Father blessing with two angels (now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York). In the predella, the long central Procession to Calvary was flanked on the left by the Agony in the Garden, and on the right by the Pietà. Two smaller panels of Franciscan saints completed the ensemble. On stylistic grounds, most scholars date the altarpiece to around 1504–5, which accords with the date of 1505 recorded probably on the frame in the nineteenth century.[1] The altarpiece remained intact and in situ until 1663 when the impecunious nuns of Sant’Antonio sold the predella to an agent of Queen Christina of Sweden. A few years later (1677–8), they sold the main panel and lunette to Antonio Bigazzini of Perugia, who in turn sold them to the Colonna family in Rome (after whom the altarpiece is now named). Notes [1] Shearman 2003, p. 97. Oberhuber 1977, pp. 51–91, argues, however, for a dating around 1501–2.

Gustav Waagen, who saw the painting in William Beckford’s house in Bath, described her attitude as ‘the purest expression of holy rapture’.[1] This rapture transmitted itself to the painting’s eccentric owner who exclaimed to another visitor: ‘Oh gracious heaven – is she not beautiful? What a mouth! – look at the corners of that mouth! – no impure twistings – all purity; and the eyes – those eyes that seem to be looking into the very countenance of our divine Saviour with such holy devotion. There, there, now you see what Raphael is! It is one of the very sweetest heads Raphael ever painted.’[2] Notes [1] Waagen 1838, III, p. 122. [2] Melville 1910, p. 293.

Although modern criticism has characterised the Sant’Antonio altarpiece as an awkward blend of styles and influences, early sources responded to it in terms of the highest praise, and it was far more influential for the subsequent development of Umbrian sacre conversazioni than the more highly evolved Ansidei Madonna.[9] Its predella, reunited in the National Gallery exhibition of 2004-5 for the first time in almost two centuries, admirably demonstrates Raphael’s growing talent for narrative and for drawing out a poignantly human dimension in biblical stories. Notes [9] Ferino Pagden 1986, pp. 98–9; Cesare Crispolti’s guide to Perugia of 1597 described the Sant’Antonio altarpiece as ‘di bellezza squisita’, rating it more highly than Piero della Francesca’s altarpiece in the same church (S. Balzani, ‘Il monastero e il polittico: dati d’archivio e memorie’, in V. Garibaldi (ed.), Piero della Francesca: Il poittico di Sant’Antonio, Perugia 1993, pp. 45-56, esp. p. 47).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Underdrawing is clearly visible with the naked eye in places where the paint has become more transparent over time. Infrared reflectography reveals extensive underdrawing for the composition executed in a dry material, identified as an alloy of lead and tin. The drawing lies on top of the priming and can be seen in a couple of places at the bottom edge where lines for the Baptist’s fur wrap extend beyond where the paint stops. The underdrawing describes the composition in full, including smaller details such as locks of hair and drapery folds. It is confident and there are very few revisions.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
The overall arrangement, with a knee-length Virgin seated at an angle to the picture plane, is adapted from Leonardo’s early Benois Madonna. The Virgin here has a more graceful, serpentine pose, generated by the contrapposto set of her head in relation to her shoulders, a trick also learnt from Leonardo, although from his more mature works.[3] Her drapery, especially the blue mantle, has a thick velvety texture very different from the Madonna of the Pinks. Christ’s unusually large body stretches diagonally across his mother’s lap, spanning the width of the composition. It would have been even more elongated were it not for the foreshortening of the legs. The deep blue curtain which serves as a foil in the left background of the Bridgewater Madonna has further darkened with time to the point where it is almost invisible. It would once have played a more active role in the limited but very rich colour harmonies so successfully retrieved by the recent cleaning of the picture.
Notes: [3] For example, his lost Leda, and his cartoon of the Virgin and Child with St. Anne in the National Gallery, London.

‘Vi mando un quadro in cui è la imagine in figura di Caterina Santa. Di Rafaelo da Urbino è tale opra: di colui, dico, che per sempre sarà famoso nel mondo. Io l’havevo destinata a la Reina di Francia; ma conoscendovi ne l’animo, da quanto nel cuore, sia un Re, a voi lo dono e presento. Ma daché nasce dala mano di pittore più che divino; andatavene compiacendo, nel modo ch’io mi vado godendo del ciò che mi mandaste a donar l’altro giorno. D’agosto in Vinetia. M. D. L.’

‘I send you a painting in which is the image of the figure of Saint Catherine. By Raphael of Urbino is such work; by him, I say, who will be for ever famous in the world. I had set it aside for the Queen of France, but knowing that you in soul, as much as in the heart, are a King, I give and present it to you. But since it is born of the hand of a painter [who] is more than divine; take pleasure in it, in the same way in which I delight in what you sent me the other day. August in Venice, 1550.’

A series of watercolours by H. E. Tidmarsh made in the 1880s shows various views of the National Gallery (Guildhall Library W2/TRA). One of them records the Ansidei Madonna in its previous frame, probably supplied when it was acquired in 1885 from the 8th Duke of Marlborough. The painting’s present frame, a sixteenth-century Italian tabernacle style frame, was made in England by R. Dolman & Son (stamp of firm on the back of the entablature) in the late nineteenth century (F1171). The design is based on a doorframe of the church of San Giobbe in Venice (Notes from a lecture given by N. Penny in 1997, p. 2, Frame Archive). Dolman & Son also made the frames for Leonardo da Vinci's Virgin of the Rocks (NG1093) and for Lorenzo Costa's and Gianfrancesco Maineri's altarpiece (NG1119) which have identical or closely related ornament (Notes by N. Penny and S. Perry, 08/01/1997, Frame Archive). In 1908 Mr Somers Clarke suggested a more important framing for the Ansidei Madonna (NG Archive, NG7/350/5). His letter, accompanied by a sketch, describes as follows: 'My suggestion is that, projecting not more than 6'' from the wall should be a background such as I shew in the sketch herewith. This background should be but a few inches wider than the frame and should be surmounted by a very simply moulded pediment, the whole standing on a base which should, in its profile and colour be the same as the plinth which runs round the room. The background and pediment to be coloured the same as the general tone of the walls [...].' Although Mr Somers Clarke offered to cover the financial expenses which would be involved the new setting was not realised.

Catalogue not found Sale according to Exhibition of Italian Art 1930, no. 402; price according to Philip Pouncy (assistant keeper in the National Gallery, London, 1934-1939), see his unsigned typescript in NG Historical Dossier, NG6480.

The painting was also studied under the stereomicroscope at magnifications of up to 80x and on the stage of the Leitz Aristomet research microscope at magnifications up to 400x.

‘In detta chiesa ui sono 2 quadri, dipintj di mano di Raffaello da Urbino, che s’appichono per le solemnita a certj pilastri: Che in uno v’è una meza Madonna con uno putto adiacere et un poco di Giuseppo, che è uno quadro, tanto bene fatto quanto cosa di suo mano, et nell’altro v’è la testa di papa Julio con la barba a sedere in una sedia di velluto, che la testa e drappi e tutto è marauigliosa.’

‘In the aforementioned church [Santa Maria del Popolo] there are two pictures painted by the hand of Raphael of Urbino, which are hung from certain pillars on solemn occasions. In one there is a half-length Madonna, with a child beside, and a little of Joseph, it is a picture done as well as any by his hand; and in the other is the head of Pope Julius, bearded, seated in a chair covered with velvet, the head, the drapery and the whole are marvellous.’

’25. Tableau d’autel pour le monastère de Saint-Antoine de Padoue, à Pérouse. […] Peintures du gradin. Il y avait cinq sujets, que les religieuses vendirent, antérieurement, à la reine Christine de Suède, en 1663, au prix de 601 écus romains. (Voyez Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug., p. 125.) Ils passèrent de la galerie Bracciano dans celle du duc d’Orléans, et quand cette dernière fut en majeure partie vendue à Londres, en 1798, ces tableaux se trouvèrent divisés entre plusieurs amateurs anglais. […] C) Le Christ mort. […] Vendu dans la galerie Bryan, à Londres, pour 60 liv. sterl. Il passa ensuite du cabinet de Bonnemaison dans celui du comte Karl von Rechberg, à Munich, et de chez ce dernier dans la collection de Sir Thomas Lawrence, puis dans celle de M. M.-A. Whyte, à Barrow Hill, près Ashborne, Derbyshire. Il est aujourd’hui dans la possession de M. H. Dawsen. Ce tableau est bien conservé.’

’25. Panel from the altarpiece for the monastery of St. Anthony of Padua at Perugia. […] Paintings of the Predella. There were five subjects which the nuns sold before to Christina of Sweden in 1663 for the price of 601 Roman scudi. (See Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug., p. 125.) They passed from the Bracciano gallery to the one of the Duke of Orleans, and when the latter was for the great part sold in London in 1798, these paintings were separated between several English amateurs. […] C) The dead Christ […] Sold at Bryan’s Gallery, London, for £60. It passed later from the Bonnemaison collection into that of Sir Thomas Lawrence, and then to that of M. M.-A. Whyte, at Barron Hill, close to Ashborne, Derbyshire. Today, it is in the possession of M. H. Dawsen. This painting is in good condition.’

‘9. The Virgin, full front, supporting the Child, which is standing on a pedestal, and leaning fondly on her, seen. Very much injured. Engraved in Crozat, No. 22, by J. C. Flipart. Valued at 200, sold at 150 gs. V. Now in the possession of Mr. Rogers, the poet.’

’Read a letter from the Director, dated this day, enclosing a communication from Madrid from Sir John Crampton, dated January the 8th 1867, and stating the probability of these being now an opportunity [‘possibility’ crossed out] of procuring by purchase a celebrated picture by Raphael, the altarpiece painted in 1505 for the nuns of Sant’Antonio, of Perugia, but now at Madrid, and the property to Don Salvador Bermudez de Castro, formerly Spanish Minister of Naples. The director recommended that an effort should be made to secure this picture for the National Gallery. Resolved that, in the opinion of the Trustees, the purchase of this picture for the National Gallery, if practicable, is eminently desirable; and that the Derector be requested to wait upon the Chancellor of the Exchequer upon the subject.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: T. Barberi, Catalogo ragionato della Galleria Camuccini in Roma, c. 1851, fols 27v-29v, bound manuscript in a clerical hand, Alnwick Castle Archives. Vincenzo Camuccini bought the picture either in 1810, the year of his only recorded visit to Paris (see Falconieri 1875, pp. 107-8), or after September 1825 when the Camuccini were obliged to list their best paintings (see Beaucamp 1939, II, pp. 567-8; The Madonna dei garofani was not included, indicating either that the painting was not considered to be Roman cultural property or that the Camuccini did not yet possess it) and probably not long before the end of 1828, in which year an engraving by Giovanni Farrugia (a Maltese protégé of the Camuccini) was published in Milan as being in the possession of the Camuccini in the legend (see Penny 1992, p. 79).
‘Vincenzo Camuccini ricomperatolo in Parigi, la restituì alla Italia ed a Roma, collocandolo fra i migliori quadri della propria galleria’.
‘Vincenzo Camuccini having bought it in Paris, took it back to Italy and to Rome placing it among the best pictures of his own gallery’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The bench on which the Virgin sits contains lead-tin yellow (EDX). The same pigment has been identified microscopically in the Virgin's yellow sleeve and golden yellow drapery, where it has reacted with the oil medium to form lead soap inclusions. Again from microscopical examination, lead-tin yellow occurs in the paler yellow greens of the distant patch of landscape, combined with mineral malachite and verdigris, as well as in the green curtain to the left (where it is mixed with verdigris).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Three paint samples were analysed by GC–MS in 2001. In each case a large peak for methyl azelate was detected indicating that the paint binding-medium contained a drying oil. However, the ratios of the palmitate and stearate fatty acid methyl esters varied between samples showing that different types of oil were used in different passages of paint. A sample from the yellow paint of the sunlit sky in the top left corner was found to contain non-heat-bodied walnut oil, with fatty acid methyl esters detected in the following ratios: A/P 2.0, P/S 3.1, A/Sub 7.9. The remaining two samples from the green / brown rocks at the lower left edge and from the shadow of Saint Catherine’s red drapery near the bottom edge were found to contain heat-bodied linseed oil, with ratios as follows: green / brown rocks A/P 1.3, P/S 1.5, A/Sub 4.2; red drapery A/P 1.5, P/S 1.2, A/Sub 4.1. These last two samples also contained small quantities of methyl dehydroabietate and methyl 7-oxodehydroabietate, indicating the presence of a degraded resin from the pinaceae family. The absence of any other characteristic compounds suggests that the resin is from a species of pine. The paint samples of the red drapery and green / brown rocks were taken from the edges of the painting but examination of the samples, at the time of this analysis, found no evidence of contamination from residual varnish. It was concluded that the pine resin detected in these samples was part of the paint medium itself. The addition of some pine resin to the heat-bodied linseed oil would raise the refractive index of the medium, with respect to the pigment, thereby heightening the colour saturation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: 2004: Joannides, Paul. “Raphael: a sorority of Madonnas”. The Burlington Magazine 146 (2004): 749-752.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: This panel is the only surviving scene from the predella of Raphael’s altarpiece for the Ansidei chapel in S. Fiorenzo, Perugia. The predella, not mentioned by Vasari, is first described in a manuscript list of 1597 recording outstanding works in Perugia as consisting of ‘very beautiful little stories [by Raphael] and worthy of such a man’.[1] The scenes were most likely painted on a single horizontal plank (like the predella of the Colonna Altarpiece). A ridge of gesso (or barb) at the top and bottom edges of the painted field of this panel suggests that the predella was already framed before the gesso ground and paint layers were applied. Confusion over the subjects of the missing scenes has arisen from two conflicting traditions, both of which mention the Preaching of the Baptist. Passavant, without specifying his source, referred to a predella with three scenes all devoted to the life of the Baptist.[2] However, such emphasis on the Baptist would have been eccentric in a chapel dedicated to Saint Nicholas. It is preferable to assume that an eighteenth-century letter from the monks of S. Fiorenzo recording a gradino (a step or predella) with only two scenes – the Baptist preaching and a shipwreck – is correct.[3] The subjects would thus have related vertically to the two saints in the altarpiece (the shipwreck being a posthumous miracle of Saint Nicholas). Notes [1] Cesare Crispolti in Shearman 2003, p. 1419: ‘Nel predolino ancora della detta tavola si veggiono molto belle historiette, e degne di un tanto huomo.’ [2] Passavant 1839–58, II, pp. 44–5. [3] Cooper and Plazzotta 2004, Appendix V.

All three works [Holy Family with a Palm Tree, Bridgewater Madonna, Madonna del Passeggio] were painted on wood, the usual support for Italian paintings up to the middle of the 16th century when the use of canvas as a support became predominant. The most common timber used was poplar and the panels were made by specialist craftsmen. The wood was generally of a thickness (2-3 cm) which would tend to resist the effects of changes in environment and could survive well if conditions allowed. However, such supports were at the mercy of extreme environmental conditions and also from attack by insects.[4]
Notes: [4] Klein and Bauch, 1983, p. 85.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Crozat 1729, I, p. 10; Passavant 1860, II, pp. 119–20; Crowe and Cavalcaselle 1882–5, I, pp. 345–7; De Tolnay 1947, I, p. 163; Dussler 1971, p. 23; Jones and Penny 1983, pp. 33–6; Brigstocke 1993, pp. 129–33; Weston-Lewis 1994, pp. 21–5, 56–8; Meyer zur Capellen 2001, pp. 250–3, no. 33.
The following documents first published by Gronau 1936, pp. 50-1, 252-4 (see also Shearman 2003, II, pp. 1414-5, 1440-2)

In 1600 he wrote to his master saying that Cardinal Sfondrati was becoming engrossed in charitable works, that he was getting rid of his possessions, and that his pictures, which were valued at about 10,000 scudi, included ‘Raphael’s portrait of Pope Julius which he [Sfondrati] removed from the Chiesa del Popolo in this city’; the Duke replied on 8th March 1600 that he did not wish to buy Cardinal Sfondrati’s pictures en bloc, but only some of his choice. As soon as the Duke’s message about wanting to pick and choose reached Cardinal Sfondrati he started behaving like a prima donna and said he changed his mind, letter of the 18th March 1600 from Sorbolongo to the Duke. Four days later the Duke reiterated that if the Cardinal changed his mind again he would still like to buy some of his choice. No more is heard until six years later. Then the Cardinal himself returned to the charge, still wanting to sell his pictures en bloc. In a final letter to the Duke’s Minister in Venice, the Abate Giulio Brunetti, 4th February 1606, he said he had ‘many Raphael’s, and all the others by excellent masters number 55’. The price was now 6,000 scudi but the Cardinal added that this money would not go into his pocket but to the church (see Gould 1970, p. 1-3).

Very much spoilt even in the time of Crozat, 1729. Engraved in his work, No. 26, by Larmessin. Valued at 100l., sold for 42 gs. A few years ago it was in the possession of Lord Eldin, Edinburgh. Now in that of Mr. Rogers.’
Perugia, Archivio di Stato, Archivio Notarile, 4094, fols 16-18, Rogiti di M. A. Fontaiuti, prot. del 1678

’Ecce.mi et Reu.mi Signori. L’Abbadessa e Suore Zoccolanti del Conuento di S. Antonio di Padoua di Perugia humilissime Oratrici delle EE. VV. riuerentemente le rappresentano che ritrouandosi con pochissime entrate non sufficienti a potersi mantenere, e con qualche debito, per receuere qualche sollieuo hanno desiderio e pensiero di far esito di un Quadro antico dipinto in una tauola, che si trouano nel Choro, o Chiesa interiore del Conuento per rinuestire il prezzo in beni stabili, giachè potria darsi il caso, che se ne trouasse una somma considerabile anche oltre ad un migliaro di scudi. Supplicano pertanto humilmente l’EE. VV. a dare ordine a Monsignor Vescouo di Perugia, che faccia considerare il valore di detto Quadro da due Pittori, e permetta la uendita quando si troui oblatore, hauendo l’Oratrici rincontro che ui sia persona di passaggio che lo ricerchi, e l’Oratrici non uorrebbero perdere la congiuntura atteso che il quadro si ua in qualche parte scrostando per la sua antichità. Che ec.’

‘Most Excellent and most Eminent Sirs. The abbess and the ‘zoccolanti’ sisters of the convent of S. Antonio di Padova of Perugia, most humble supplicants of Your Excellencies reverently explained to you that, finding themselves with very little income, not sufficient to enable them to sustain themselves, and with some debts, in order to receive some relief wish and intend to relinquish an old painting painted on wood, which are found in the choir, or inner church of the convent, to reinvest the price in fixed assets, as the case might be, that a considerable amount might be found even beyond a thousand scudi. Therefore they humbly beg Your Excellencies to order Monsignor Bishop of Perugia to have the value of the aforesaid painting estimated by two painters, and to allow the sale when a buyer is found, having the supplicants before them that there is some passerby who may be looking for such a painting, and the supplicants would not want to miss the opportunity given that the painting is deteriorating in some part, due to its age. Etc.’
No sample has been analysed, but the characteristics of the paint layers suggests an oil binder.

‘[…] lasciò alcune tavole da lui fatte nela nostra città: due in San Francesco del convento, una d’un Christo morto, l’altra d’un Assunta; un’altra ne fece a’ Servi ne la capella degli Ansidei, et una in Santo Antonio da Padova. A San Severo ancora sono di suo alcune pitture. Fu discepolo di Pietro Perugino.’

‘[...] he left some panels done by him in our city: two in Saint Francis of the convent, one with a dead Christ, the other with an Assumption; he made another for the Servites for the Ansidei chapel, and for Saint Anthony of Padua. In Saint Severus are also some paintings by him. He was a disciple of Pietro Perugino.’

The small patch of blue sky to the right is painted in natural ultramarine (lapis lazuli) mixed with white, and the same pigment forms the deepest blue surface paint of the Virgin's blue drapery, painted over an underlayer containing mineral azurite. The rather greenish-blue azurite underlayer is left exposed in the shadows of the drapery. Azurite mixed with red lake pigment, white and a little black, in varying proportions, forms the range of mauvish-grey tones of the Virgin's dress; in the deepest shadows the proportions of red lake and black pigment are at their greatest. A mauve colour, consisting of red lake and azurite, lies beneath the deep green curtain at the left, and can be glimpsed under magnification through small losses and cracks in the upper green paint layer; this is not underpainting but represents a notable change to the colour of the curtain made by Raphael in the course of painting.

Recent FTIR analysis of three samples, from the blue sky, the grey hose of the man on the left and the brown mound on which Saint John stands, suggests that the binding medium is oil. Previous analyses, by GC-MS, confirmed the presence of oil in the green foliage of the trees and identified the oil as walnut. A small amount of pine resin was also found in the sample.[56]
Notes [56] The results of the earlier campaign of medium analysis are published in J. Plesters, 'Technical Aspects of Some Paintings by Raphael in the National Gallery, London', in The Princeton Raphael Symposium: Science in the Service of Art History, Princeton Monographs in Art and Archaeology XLVII, eds J. Shearman and M.B. Hall, Princeton, New Jersey 1990, pp. 15-37 and figs 1-29, esp. p. 36. Here, the GC results from a sample of sky paint are interpreted as being indicative of an egg tempera medium, on the basis of the detected azelate to palmitate ratios. The recent analysis by FTIR of another sample of sky paint, however, showed that the medium was oil.

Raphael must have been familiar with the story of the choice of Hercules from childhood, since the legend inspired the prologue of his father Giovanni Santi’s epic poem about the life and deeds of Federigo da Montefeltro, Duke of Urbino.[3] In Santi’s version, the poet falls asleep in the shade of a leafy beech tree (not a laurel) and hears a voice exhorting him not to waste time. He realises he must abandon the easy path, strewn with grass and flowers, which he has hitherto followed, in order to pursue a new, harsh and rocky road, leading up bare cliffs to the temple of Apollo and the Muses. There he prays for inspiration and the submission of passion to reason (Virtue versus Pleasure), so that he may give free rein to the ‘alto concepto’ of his poem. Remembering this allegory of creative endeavour, Raphael may have had a subjective interest in painting the unusual story from the life of Scipio – who at the time, Silius repeatedly emphasises, was very young, like Raphael himself. Santi referred to his prologue as ‘una visione in somno’, and it may be significant for Raphael’s painting that his father’s is the only textual version of the tale in which the protagonist is asleep. Notes [3] Michelini Tocci (ed.) 1985, I, pp. 5–10.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Catherine of Alexandria, a fourth-century princess, was converted to Christianity by a desert hermit and in a vision underwent a mystic marriage with Christ. When she would not renounce her faith, the Emperor Maxentius devised an instrument of torture consisting of four spiked wheels to which she was bound, but a thunderbolt destroyed it before it could harm her. Catherine was then beheaded. Divorced from the narrative circumstances of her martyrdom, the saint is here depicted in a peaceful rural landscape. Reflected in the stretch of water behind her are the trees and buildings on the far shore. Without her usual attributes of a palm or sword, only the large wheel alludes to her gruesome ordeals (though this is studded rather than spiked). Instead, Raphael focused on the visionary aspect of the saint’s faith, capturing her – with parted lips and hand on heart – in a moment of divine ecstasy. Raphael used gold to depict the heavenly light radiating towards her.

Very fine vertical and horizontal incised ruled axes. The position of the latter has been constructed using compasses. Traces of pouncing due to transfer of the design from a surviving pricked cartoon. The pounced design has been reinforced with black drawing; it is not possible to deduce from the character of the line whether the drawing was carried out with a dry or fluid material. There is also a great deal of freehand adjusting of contours (in the saint's face for example) and drapery folds. Ruled straight lines of rays of light from the sun are incised, as is her elliptical halo.
By inheritance to Don Livio Odescalchi’s nephew Baldassare.

William Herbert, 3rd Earl of Pembroke [1580 1630], Wilton House, Wiltshire, by 1627; possibly his brother, Philip Herbert, 4th Earl of Pembroke [1584 1649/1650], Wilton House; given either by the 3rd Earl or the 4th Earl between 1628 and 1639 to Charles I, King of England [d. 1649];[1] (Charles I [Commonwealth] sale, Somerset House, London, 19 December 1651); purchased by Edward Bass.[2] Charles d'Escoubleau, Marquis de Sourdis [d. 1666], possibly acquired from Bass.[3] Laurent Le Tessier de Montarsy, by 1729; Pierre Crozat [1665 1740], Paris, by 1729;[4] by inheritance to his nephews, Louis François Crozat, marquis du Châtel [1691 1750], Paris, and [on Louis François' death without a male heir] to Louis Antoine Crozat, baron de Thiers [1700 1770];[5] his heirs; sold 1772 through Denis Diderot [1713 1784], as an intermediary, to Catherine II, empress of Russia [1729 1796], for the Imperial Hermitage Gallery, Saint Petersburg;[6] purchased March 1931 through (Matthiesen Gallery, Berlin; P. & D. Colnaghi & Co., London; and M. Knoedler & Co., New York) by Andrew W. Mellon, New York and Washington, D.C.; deeded 30 March 1932 to The A.W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Trust, Pittsburgh;[7] gift 1937 to NGA.
[1] Recorded in Van der Doort, _A Catalogue and Description of King Charles the First's Capital Collection of Pictures, Limnings, Statues, etc_, from an Ashmolean manuscript (c. 1639), prepared for press by G. Vertue (printed by W. Bathoe), 1757: 4. [2] According to O. Miller, 'The Inventories and Valuations of the King's Goods, 1649 1651,' _Journal of the Walpole Society_ 43 (1970 1972): 258. [3] According to N. Le Clerc and J. Colomsat, _Cabinet des Singularitez D'Architecture, Peinture, Sculpture, et Graveure_, Paris, 1699: 66 67. [4] Cited by F. R. Shapley, _Catalogue of the Italian Paintings_, 2 vols., Washington, 1979: 1:394, as documented in the _Recueil des Stampes...dans le Cabinet du Roi..._, Volume I, 1763: 13. [5] Recorded in _Catalogue des Tableaux du Cabinet de M. Crozat, Baron de Thiers_, Paris, 1755: 34. [6] See A. Somof, _Catalogue de la Galerie des Tableaux_, St. Petersburg, 1899: 112 113. [7] Mellon/Mellon trust purchase date and/or date deeded to to Mellon Trust is according to Mellon collection files in NGA curatorial records and David Finley's notebook (donated to the National Gallery of Art in 1977, now in Gallery Archives).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The surface paint of the sky consists of natural ultramarine mixed with white. The distant mountains are also painted in ultramarine. The greener parts of the landscape contain lead-tin yellow, a green pigment, probably verdigris, and some ultramarine; the strongest greens in the middle distance contain verdigris and some black. The central tree is painted directly over the sky; the greenish-blue foliage contains azurite, verdigris and a yellow pigment; the highlights contain lead-tin yellow as the principal pigment. The middle-ground rocks are painted in lead white with some ultramarine, black and yellow; the light greenish-grey foreground is similar and contains a little azurite in addition.

The infrared reflectogram mosaic reveals that the composition was bisected horizontally (a vertical centre line passes through the face of the man in yellow and red) in what appears to be a dry black material. No horizontal line like that in The Procession to Calvary NG2919 is present but the centre point of the vertical line is marked with a short horizontal mark (visible in the man’s hand). These lines may have helped with the alignment of the cartoon that was used to transfer the design to the panel, though such marks are present in many other drawings and underdrawings by Raphael, regardless of whether the design was to be transferred or not.
Crowe and Cavalcaselle 1882, I, pp. 128-35

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The horizontal grain of the panel is clearly visible. The X-radiograph was made before the conservation treatment in 1983 and so the butterfly keys that were glued to the reverse to secure the split at the left end can still be seen. The old putty along the upper and lower borders has also since been removed. Fragments of old nails are apparent and some old fillings show as white as the putty probably contains lead white. Very small white dots are scattered across the image. These are where the imprimitura (which contains lead white and lead-tin yellow) has filled air bubbles in the gesso ground. The X-ray image is closely related to the final painting. Raphael followed the underdrawing quite carefully, although sometimes the broad strokes of paint for the sky and landscape encroach into areas reserved for figures. Even the heads of the tiny mounted figures at back of the group on the left have been carefully reserved, but the wide-brimmed hat was added over the landscape. The trees have been painted over the sky.
Christie’s, 10 May 1830, lot 125

In many of the cross-sections, transparent colourless angular particles are visible in the paint under the microscope. This material is a glass of the same composition as in the imprimitura; its presence has been confirmed by EDX analysis in the greenish paint of the foreground, the orange-yellow tunic of the man on the brown horse and the cream underpaint of the pink robe of Saint John.
Notes
[52] For a fuller discussion of this pigment and illustrations of the infrared images see M. Spring, R. Grout and R. White, 'Black Earths: A study of Unusual Black and Dark Grey Pigments used by Artists in the Sixteenth Century', National Gallery Technical Bulletin, 24, 2003, pp. 96-114.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: It is not known who commissioned the Saint Catherine and its presumed date – extremely close to the Baglioni Entombment – could imply a Perugian or a Florentine patron. It may have been intended as an object for private devotion, perhaps for a patron devoted to the saint or even named after her (an earlier precedent for this type of image in Raphael’s oeuvre is the Saint Sebastian). It is interesting to note that Pietro Aretino thought of presenting a picture in his possession ‘in which is the image of the figure of Saint Catherine, by Raphael of Urbino’ to the eponymous Catherine de’ Medici, Queen of France (in the event he changed his mind and gave it to Agosto d’Adda, a Milanese banker to whom he owed favours).[3] It is impossible to tell whether the painting owned by Aretino, who records it in his possession in Venice in 1550, is identical with this Saint Catherine. The latter is otherwise first documented in the Borghese collection by 1633.[4] A previously unrecorded seal on the reverse indicates that a cardinal of the Crescenzi family may have owned the picture before it passed into Borghese’s collection.[5] Notes [3] Shearman 2003, pp. 1006–7. [4] Corradini 1998, p. 455. [5] The only candidates are Cardinals Marcello Crescenzi (1500–1552) and Pier Paolo Crescenzi (1572–1645). I am grateful to Caroline Campbell for investigating Crescenzi cardinals.

Es sind deren fünf, welche die Nonnen schon früher im Jahr 1663 an die Königin von Schweden um 601 Scudi romani verkauften. (Siehe Mariotti, Lettere pitt. perug. p. 125.) Jetzt besitzt es Hr. M. A. Whyte in Barron Hill bei Ashborne, Derbyshire. Es ist von guter Erhaltung.’

‘Altarpiece for the Monastery of St. Anthony of Padua at Perugia. […] Paintings of the Predella. Whyte, at Barron Hill, close to Ashborne, Derbyshire. This painting is in good condition.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The subject of this exquisite ‘quadruccio’[1] was inspired by a passage in the Punica, an epic poem recounting the story of the Second Punic War by the Latin poet Silius Italicus (AD 25–101). Resting in the shade of a bay tree, the young soldier Scipio is visited by a vision of two ladies, Virtue and her adversary Pleasure (Voluptas). Virtue, described in the poem as a mannish figure, with her hair set low over her brow, promises Scipio honour, fame and glory through victory in war, but warns that the path leading to her chaste mountain abode is steep and rocky. Pleasure, with fragrant, flowing locks and languorous eyes, advocates instead a life of easeful serenity. Raphael subtly contrasts the characters in his painting through their appearance and attire. Virtue, on the left, is soberly dressed and her dark hair is covered, while Pleasure’s dress is hitched up becomingly at the hip and her blonde tresses, adorned with coral beads and a flower, escape from beneath a billowing veil. The arduous path advocated by Virtue is represented by the craggy eminence in the background, linked by a drawbridge to her palace; behind Pleasure gently undulating hills lead down to a sunlit lake. Raphael represented the appeals of the ladies in the poem emblematically, through the objects they offer: a sword standing for valour is balanced in Virtue’s other hand by a book signifying learning (an embellishment of Raphael’s own, not anticipated in the poem), while Pleasure holds out a sprig of flowers (possibly myrtle, sacred to Venus) standing for love. Notes [1] This diminutive of quadro (picture) was used to describe the painting and its pair in the Borghese inventory, Della Pergola 1959 (II), p. 458, nos 315 and 318.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Sir William Boxall, director of the National Gallery in London (1866-1874), recommended securing the painting after he had seen it in Madrid. In the opinion of the Trustees the purchase of this picture was desirable and the Director was requested to write to the Chancellor of the Exchequer. In June 1868 Boxall met with the First Lord of the Treasury, and the following month it was communicated that the First Lord was prepared to arrange the purchase. But as the British prime minister, Benjamin Disraeli, planned to rein in government spending he had to withdraw his support by October 1868. (See also Wolk-Simon, 2006, pp. 49-50).
