rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Città di Castello, Biblioteca Comunale, Archivio Notarile, 266, prot. 6, fol. 775r-v (see also Rossi 1883, pp. 8-16, esp. pp. 11-13) A copy was installed in the Gavari chapel (for which see Mancini 1987, no. 81).

‘Consegna del Crocifisso della cappella Gualterotti al card. Fesch. Al nome di Dio amen. A dì ventuno del mese di Luglio dell’anno mille ottocento otto. Essendochè nella chiesa dei RR. Padri dell’ordine dei Predicatori di S. Domenico di questa Città di Castello, e precisamente sopra l’altare della Cappella di Giuspatronato della Nobile Famiglia Gualterotti esistesse l’imagine di un Crocifisso dipinto in tavola in figura al naturale dall’Eccmo Pittore Raffaele di Urbino fin dall’anno 1503; e che di questa bramasse farne acquisto l’Emo Sig.r Cardinal Fesch, conforme viene asserito etc. Ed essendo ancora che la famiglia predetta dei Sig.ri Gualterotti proprietaria dell’imagine che sopra previo l’opportuno assenso dei RR. Padri suddetti e del Rmo Padre procuratore generale dell’Ordine avanzasse perciò supplica alla Sacra Congregazione de’Vescovi e Regolari onde ottenere il necessario Rescritto Pontificio per l’alienazione surriferita; e che un tal Rescritto effettivamente ottenesse fin sotto dì 8 dell’andante mese di Luglio, come dal Rescritto medesimo esistente negli atti della Cancelleria Vescovile di questa Città ai quali etc. E parimente essendochè l’enunciata vendita e compra respettivamente venisse concordata e stabilita in Roma sotto dì 11 di d.o mese per il prezzo di scudi Duemilacinquecento moneta romana di paoli X per scudo da sborarsi dal Sig.r Marchese Marino Torlonia all’avviso della consegna, come da apoca ed obbligazione privata dallo stesso Sig.r Marchese sottoscritta ed in forma riconosciuta sotto dì 15 del med.o mese dal Sig.r Carlo Maria Sommaini notaro capitolino; e che fosse pur anche convenuto, che il prelodato Emo Sig.r Cardinal Fesch avesse dovuto far rimettere a proprie spese in Città di Castello e collocare dentro il termine di due mesi nell’altare sunnominato una copia della imagine suddetta di buono e accreditato pittore come dall’apoca e obbligazione pred.a in copia esibita e prodotta negli atti sopracitati ai quali nuovamente etc. Ed essendo inoltre, che la stessa Sacra Congregazione de’Vescovi e Regolari con lettera del dì 12 dello stesso mese di Luglio la menzionata vendita e compra respettiva rimettesse in seguito per l’approvazione alla coscienza dell’Illmo e Rmo Monsig.r Vescovo di questa città, e che dal medesimo venisse approvata con suo decreto del dì 20 del più volte nominato andante mese di Luglio, come da d.a lettera e decreto esistenti negli atti pred.i ai quali etc. E sia finalmente che il lodato Emo Sig.r Cardinal Fesch abbia in oggi spedito in questa città il Sig.r Francesco Granet unitamente al Sig.r Feaux suo agente ad effetto prenda la consegna del quadro soprad.o dagli infrascritti Sig.ri Gualterotti e Rev.do Padre Priore del Convento sud.o di S. Domenico e voglino questi ad una tal consegna ora devenire e che di questa a perpetua memoria ne apparisca pub.o rogito; Quindi è che avanti di me notaro ed alla presenza degli infrascritti testimonii personalmente esistenti i nobili Sig.ri Canonico Ugolino della chiara memoria Sig.r Ludovico Gualterotti, Domenico del di buona memoria Sig.r Urbano Gualterotti e Vincenzo Gualterotti di lui figlio donatario del Nobile Sig.r Niccola della b. m. Sig.r Gio. Batta Gualterotti, come da rogito di me sotto dì 9 Gennaro 1807 tutti di Città di Castello, non meno che il Rev.do Padre Fra Domenico Gherardi attuale Priore del Ven. Convento de’RR. Padri Predicatori di S. Domenico di d.a città, a me cogniti i quali asserendo ed affermando tutte e singole cose sudd.e esser vere e quelle ratificando di spontanea loro volontà ed in ogni miglior modo, consegnarono e consegnano al Sig.r Francesco del fu Sig.r Stefano Granet di Aix in Francia a tal uopo incaricato, come viene asserito a me, dall’Emo Sig.r Cardinale Giuseppe Fesch, presente ed accettante un quadro rappresentante il SS.mo Crocifisso dipinto in tavola fin dall’anno 1503 dall’Eccmo pittore Raffaello di Urbino e che restava collocato nella Chiesa de’sudd.i RR. Padri Predicatori sopra l’altare della Ven. Cappella di Giuspatronato della fimiglia dei sudd.i Sig.ri Gualterotti dai medesimi di già venduto per prezzo di scudi duemilacinquecento al riferito Emo Sig.r Cardinale conforme è stato di sopra enunciato, non solo etc. ma in ogni miglior modo etc. Il quadro sud.o il prefato Sig.r Francesco Granet riconobbe e riconosce, asserì ed asserisce essere quello come sopra venduto all’Emo Sig.r Cardinal Fesch e di quello in nome dello stesso Cardinale ne prese e prende la formale consegna assolvendo liberando etc. i sudd.i Sig.ri Gualterotti e R. Padre Priore Gherardi da ogni ulteriore conservazione del medesimo in ogni modo migliore etc. sopra di che etc. diedero a me facoltà di farne pubblico rogito. Fatto in Città di Castello nella libreria del soprad.o Ven. Convento di S. Domenico, ivi presenti Bartolomeo del fu Florido Volpi dalla Villa del Bagno abitante in d.a città e Vincenzo figli di Bernardo Paci della città sud.a testimonii etc. Così etc.; Vincenzo Mariottini Not.o pub.o rogato etc.’

Delivery of the Crucifixion of the Gualterotti chapel to Cardinal Fesch. In the name of God amen. On day 21 of the month of July of the year 1808. Given that in the church of the Reverend Fathers of the Order of Preachers of Saint Dominic of this Città di Castello, and precisely above the altar of the chapel under the patronage of the noble Gualterotti family, has existed the image of a Crucifixion painted on panel in life size by the most excellent painter Raphael of Urbino since the year 1503; and that the eminent Sig.r Cardinal Fesch wished to make a purchase of it, as is stated etc. And given that the aforesaid family of the Messrs Gualterotti still own the abovementioned painting, following the appropriate consent of the aforesaid Reverend Fathers and the most Reverend Father general procurator of the Order, he presented a plea to the Sacred Congregation of the Bishops and Regulars in order to obtain the necessary papal writ for the aforesaid removal; and given that he has effectively obtained such a writ since day 8 of the current month of July, as from the same writ existing in the acts of the Bishop’s Registry of this city to which etc. And similarly given that the aforesaid sale and respective purchase was agreed and confirmed in Rome on day 11 of the aforesaid month for the price of 2,500 scudi in roman currency, 10 paoli to 1 scudo, to be paid by Sig.r Marquis Marino Torlonia on news of the delivery, as from time and private obligation from the same Sig.r Marquis and formally recognized on day 15 of the same month by Sig.r Carlo Maria Sommaini Capitoline notary; and [given] that it was also agreed that the previously praised eminent Sig.r Cardinal Fesch had to have substituted at his own expense in Città di Castello and place within two months on the aforesaid altar a copy of the aforesaid image by a good and recognized painter as from the aforesaid time and private obligation in a copy shown and produced in the abovementioned acts to which again etc. And furthermore, given that the same Sacred Congregation of the Bishops and Regulars, in a letter of the day 12 of the same month of July, had successively sent [request for] the abovementioned sale and respective purchase, for the approval of the most Illustrious and Reverend Mons. Bishop of this city, and that by the same it was approved with his decree of the day 20 of the much mentioned current month of July, as by the aforesaid letter and decree existing in the aforesaid acts to which etc. And finally, be it that the praised Eminent Sig.r Cardinal Fesch has today sent to this city Sig.r Francesco Granet together with Sig.r Feaux his agent for the purpose of taking delivery of the aforesaid painting from the abovementioned Messers Gualterotti and Reverend Father Prior of the aforementioned Convent of Saint Dominic, and these are invited to make such a delivery and may a public deed of this [transaction] appear for everlasting memory; Therefore it is that before me, notary and in the presence of the aforesaid witnesses present in person, the noble Messers Canon Ugolino [son of] Sig.r Ludovico Gualterotti, of illustrious memory, Domenico [son] of Sig.r Urbano Gualterotti, of good memory, and Vincenzo Gualterotti, his son, donor of the noble Sig.r Niccola [son of] Giovanni Battista Gualterotti, of good memory, as by my deed of the day 9 January 1807 all of them from Città di Castello, as well as the Reverend Father Friar Domenico Gherardi current Prior of the Venerable Convent of the Reverend Fathers Preachers of S. Dominic of the aforesaid city, [all] known to me, who asserting and affirming each and every of the aforementioned things to be true, and ratifying these things of their own free will and in every best way, have delivered and deliver to Sig.r Francesco of the late Sig.r Stefano Granet of Aix in France charged to such purpose, as it is stated to me, by the most Eminent Sig.r Cardinal Giuseppe Fesch, present and accepting a painting representing the most Holy Crucifixion painted on panel in 1503 by the most excellent painter Raphael of Urbino and which remained placed in the church of the aforesaid Reverend Fathers Preachers above the altar of the venerable chapel of the patronage of the family of the aforesaid Messers Gualterotti by the same already sold for the price of 2,500 scudi to the abovementioned most Eminent Sig.r Cardinal in conformity with what is stated above, not only etc, but in every best way, etc. The above mentioned Sig.r Francesco Granet recognized and recognizes, stated and states the aforesaid painting to be that as above sold to the most Eminent Sig.r Cardinal Fesch and in the name of the same Cardinal took and takes official delivery of that [painting], relieving, liberating etc. the above said Messrs Gualterotti and Rev. Father Prior Gherardi from any further conservation of the same in every better way etc. upon which etc. they gave me the faculty to draw up a public deed of it. Written in Città di Castello in the library of the above said Venerable Convent of S. Domenico, in the presence of Bartolomeo [son of] the late Florido Volpi dalla Villa del Bagno living in the said city and Vincenzo, sons (sic!) of Bernardo Paci of the said city. Witnesses etc. So etc.; drawn up by Vincenzo Mariottini public notary etc.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: ’31. Altarpiece for the Monastery of St. Anthony of Padua at Perugia. […] The Central Picture. […] The Lunette. […] In 1678 the nuns sold these two paintings to Count Gio. Antonio Bigazzini at Rome for about 2,000 scudi, receiving also a copy of each for their high-altar. (See . Annibale Mariotti Lettere pittoriche peruginei, etc. Perugia 1778, in-8. p. 126. He got this information from the archives in Perugia.) They were transferred to the Colonna Gallery, and at the end of the last century became the property of the King of Naples; although I do not know if they were rescued from the last fire in the castle. I saw them both well preserved, although the central picture is cracked across its width due to too much heat, and one of the two cracks unfortunately crosses the three heads of the women.’

’31. Altartafel furs Kloster S. Antonio di Padova zu Perugia. […] Hauptblatt. […] Lunette. […] Im Jahr 1678 verkauften die Nonnen diese beiden Stücke um 2000 Scudi romani an den Grafen Gio. Antonio Bigazzini in Rom, und erhielten ausserdem eine Copie derselben für ihren Altar. (Siehe Annibale Mariotti Lettere pittoriche perugine etc. Perugia 1788, 8. p. 126, welcher diese Notiz aus dem öffentlichen Archiv der Stadt genommen hat.) Nachmals kamen die Bilder in die Gallerie Colonna, und aus ihr zu Ende des verflossenen Jahrhunderts an den König von Neapel. Noch sah ich sie im Palast zu Neapel, weiss aber nicht, ob sie aus dem letzten Schlossbrand gerettet wurden. Ich fand sie beide wohl erhalten, nur dass die Haupttafel zwei Sprünge in die Quere durch allzu grosse Hitze erhalten, von denen einer leider durch die drei weiblichen Köpfe geht.’
Passavant 1839, II, no. 31 (see also Passavant 1839, I, p. 87)

Crowe and Cavalcaselle 1882, I, pp. 343-4 Cavalcaselle had certainly studied both paintings at Lucca and Alnwick but his notes on the latter seem to have been confused with those on the former (his annotated drawings of the composition and details of the Madonna dei garofani are in the Biblioteca Marciana, Venice, cod. It. IV. 2033 (12274), fasc. 20. Cavalcaselle noted the ‘conservazione perfetta’. From the context this must be the Alnwick painting but the drawing records areas of paint loss which correspond with those revealed in old photographs of the version at that time in Lucca. He was puzzled by the support (‘pare quercia […] olivo’), found much of the painting ‘bello’ but a few details such as the Virgin’s ear and hands defective; see Penny 1992, pp. 80-1).

‘It has been usual to believe that where Raphaelesque Madonnas are preserved of which no single example bears the master’s true sign manual, it may be presumed that the original perished; yet we may suppose that in many such cases Raphael never painted an original at all, but left the designs exclusively to the care of his subordinates. An early specimen of this kind is the ‘Madonna of the Pink,’ […]. The best of these pieces in possession of Count Luigi Spada at Lucca, combines Florentine style and dress with much warmth and sweetness of tone in a rich and harmonious scale of colours, and great minuteness and purity of outline. Yet the treatment is no longer clearly Raphael’s, and it is all the more natural that replicas at Alnwick, Leipzig, Rome and elsewhere should be less attractive since they were comparatively feebler.’
Crozat 1729, I, pp. 10, 11 no. 22 and fig. 22

‘Tableaux de Raphael du Cabinet de Monseigneur le Duc d’Orleans. […] XXII. La Sainte Vierge. Quoyque le temps ait endommagé ce Tableau, […]. Quelques critiques ont jugé par l’air de la teste de la Sainte Vierge, que ce Tableau pouvoit avoir esté peint par Thimothée Viti d’Urbin Eleve de Raphael. Feu S. A. R. l’a eu de M. Dorat qui l’avoit eu du Sieur Beauchamp.’

‘Paintings by Raphael in the Cabinet of Milord the Duke of Orleans. […] XXII. The Holy Virgin. Although time has damaged this painting […]. Some critics have judged, from the look of the head of the Holy Virgin, that this painting could have been painted by Timoteo Viti of Urbino, pupil of Raphael. The late His Royal Highness got it from Mr Dorat who had got it from Sir Beauchamp.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Though the interior is dark, the figures in the painting are brightly lit, not from the window, but artificially, from a light source at the upper left. The subtle description of light and shadow in both the flesh and the draperies reveals Raphael’s familiarity with the works of Netherlandish painters. The knotted bed-curtain, the view through the window with its illusionistic chip in the sill, the square shape of the Virgin’s forehead and her downcast crescent-shaped eyes also reflect Northern European prototypes. But the chief influence here is Leonardo, on whose Benois Madonna Raphael’s composition is closely based. The correspondence is so close as to suggest Raphael was able to study Leonardo’s picture (painted about thirty years earlier) at first-hand. The cool palette, artful lighting, lively interaction of the figures, and arrangement of the draperies all reflect Leonardo’s work. However, Raphael subtly reorganised the dense dynamic grouping of his model, disentangling the figures and reconstructing them as clear volumetric forms in space. The joyful open-mouthed smile of Leonardo’s Virgin, taken up by Raphael, was inspired by contemporary sculpture, particularly the ‘sweet style’ of sculptors of the preceding generation such as Desiderio da Settignano. When in Florence, Raphael took the opportunity to study these earlier sculptural sources for himself (as his father had also done), and this further informed his instinct for formal and spatial clarity, as shown here. Leonardo’s painting focuses on the internal psychological dynamic between the figures, and there is no distraction other than sky through the window. Raphael on the other hand characteristically links the interior and exterior worlds (or heaven and earth) in his painting through colour.

The picture has been comprehensively repainted, perhaps on more than one occasion, although a reasonable proportion of original paints appears to survive beneath. The reason for the extensive repainting must lie with damage caused to the surface as a result of the process of transfer. No sample has been analysed, but the appearance and characteristics of the original paint layers suggest an oil binder. Paint of the landscape to the left contains lead-tin yellow and here, within the paint layer, inclusions of lead soaps have formed. This implies, although does not completely confirm, an oil-based medium.
The analysed panel is made by common yew (Taxus baccata). In the radial section the spiral thickenings are conspicuous in longitudinal tracheids.

Saint John the Evangelist's red cloak is a particularly striking deep saturated colour. The most intense shadows consist of thick layers of red lake glaze over a deep red underpaint of vermilion mixed with red lake. The darkest areas contain black in addition. The fluorescence of samples in ultraviolet (UV) light under the microscope suggested the presence of two distinct types of red lake pigment: these were identified by HPLC as derived from kermes and madder (the latter having a characteristic orange UV fluorescence). UV light examination of samples also reveals that these red glazes contain considerable quantities of powdered glass, and in fact this material has been added to many of the paints, not just the reds.[44] The other areas of saturated red in the draperies also make use of red lake, for example the shadows of the Magdalen's pink and yellow cangiante drapery. The contrast between the shadows and the pink mid-tones has almost certainly become more marked as a result of fading of the red lake.
Notes [44] The presence of glass has been confirmed by EDX analysis on samples from the brownish-gold ray of the sun, the ochre-brown shadow of the left leg of the angel in yellow and Saint John's red drapery.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Document Digitisation relating to NG2069, P4386 103, P4386 104

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The most unusual pigment used in the painting is a warm dark grey, the particles of which have a distinctive metallic lustre under the microscope. This same material occurs in the architecture of the Ansidei Madonna where it has been identified positively (XRD and EDX) as powdered bismuth metal. In the Procession to Calvary it occurs in Simon of Cyrene's hose and in the body of the grey horse. The shadows of the grey horse appear unusually dark in infrared images in spite of the relatively light grey colour of the paint, which is characteristic of this metallic pigment, and distinguishes it from stibnite (antimony sulphide), which has a similar microscopic appearance.[52]
Ramdohr 1787, I, p. 292 and pp. 300-01

‘Viertes Zimmer. Ein bewaffneter Ritter, der in einer Landschaft schläft, und von zwei Heiligen bewacht wird. […] Zu beiden Seiten hat Il Fattore zwei andere Figuren gemahlt [...]. Ein kleines Zimmer mit lauter Kabinettstücken. […]. Die drei Grazien aus der Schule Raphaels. Zu unrichtig gezeichnet, um von ihm selbst zu seyn’.

‘Fourth Room. An armed knight who sleeps in a landscape and who is watched by two saints. [...] To both sides, Il Fattore [Giovan Francesco Penni] has painted two other figures [...]. A small room full of cabinet paintings [...]. The three Graces by the workshop of Raphael. Too wrongly drawn to be by himself’.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: La Madone d’Orléans est unanimement acceptée comme une oeuvre originale de Raphaël et figure donc dans toutes les études sur le peintre. Document Digitisation relating to 46, Raphael W058, Raphael W042
1995: Emison, Patricia. “The paysage moralisé”. Artibus et Historiae 16 (1995): 125-137.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Paradoxically, this is at the same time one of Raphael’s most animated Virgin and Child compositions. This is due principally to the dynamic twisting pose of Christ, which can be traced back ultimately to Michelangelo’s Taddei Tondo. The sense of movement is enhanced by the restless interplay of the diagonal and curved forms which articulate the design, to which the arched alcove in the background and the ellipses of the haloes (that of Christ now scarcely visible) contribute.
Passavant 1833, pp. 103-4; Passavant 1836, I, pp. 229-31 (translation)

‘Zwei Gemälde in der interessanten Kunstsammlung des Grafen Dudley. Raphael. Die drei Grazien, ein kleines Bild von 7 Zoll im Quadrat, ehemals in der Gallerie Borghese. [...] der englische Kupferstecher J. K. Sherwin hat es, als es noch in der Gallerie Borghese war, schlecht in Punctirmanier bekannt gemacht. [...] Unser Bildchen von vortrefflicher Erhaltung wünschte Desnoyers während seines Aufenthalts in London zu zeichnen. Es ist zu bedauern, dass ihm dieses nicht bewilligt wurde, sonst würden wir wohl einen guten Kupferstich darnach besitzen.’

‘Two Pictures in Lord Dudley and Ward’s Collection. Raphael. The Three Graces: a small picture; seven inches square; formerly in the Borghese Palace. […] When in the Borghese Palace, it was only known by an inferior dotted engraving by J. R. Sherwin. […] The picture in question is in excellent preservation, and it is to be regretted that Desnoyers’s request to engrave it was not complied with; as, otherwise, the public might have been favoured with an engraving worthy of the composition.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: To contrast with the saturated red cloak, Saint John's robe is a deep saturated green. This is also thickly painted and multilayered, consisting of translucent deep green verdigris glazes, virtually undiscoloured, over a more solid dark green underlayer, also containing verdigris with some lead-tin yellow and white.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Alnwick Castle Archives, Add. MSS (1973), F 76a

Around 1850, presumably an agent of the Duke compiled in Rome a list of Camuccini's paintings with sterling prices or valuations. The Raphael at £2500, the Claude at £1500 and the Guercino at £1000 were the most highly valued – together with the Bellini, to which no figure seems then to have been attached (see Penny 1992, p. 78). In 1851 the Camuccini Collection was moved to the Palazzo Cesi (T. Barberi, Catalogo ragionato della Galleria Camuccini in Roma, c. 1851, bound manuscript in a clerical hand, Alnwick Castle Archives, fol. 2-4 (another copy in the archive of the Camuccini heirs at Cantalupo); a translation ‘by D. C.’ also at Alnwick Castle).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Seal of a Cardinal of the Crescenzi family on reverse of painting.

The sky is painted with a layer of natural ultramarine mixed with white, over azurite mixed with white. The mid-blue drapery of the figure at the far left also consists of ultramarine painted over azurite. The mauve hose of the figure in the red cloak, on the left, consists of red lake, ultramarine and lead white, in two layers. The red cloak, also in several layers, contains red lake pigment mixed with a little vermilion in the shadows and some white in the highlights. The red glaze on Saint John's red cloak has been blotted with a textile.

The translucent brown background colour of the broad gold-embroidered borders of Saint Nicholas's cope comprises vermilion, black, white, orange earth and a little verdigris with a final mid-brown organic glaze, identified by GC-MS as a softwood pitch in heat-bodied walnut oil. The embroidery is represented by a pattern of mordant gilding on top. The more solid, flat lighter yellow-brown colours of the throne are worked in lead-tin yellow and earth pigments, with almost pure lead-tin yellow in the lightest areas.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The painting is in very good condition. The panel retains its original thickness. There is a small crack running up from the bottom edge in the lower left corner and some woodworm damage, especially at the upper left edge. Only a few minor areas of retouching are visible, for example two scratches across the Virgin’s proper right knee and in the background on the right extending into the window opening. Other than surface cleaning, the painting has not been treated since it came into the collection in 1876; consequently the varnish is discoloured and degraded with many small scratches, splash marks and some damage around the edges caused by the rebate of the frame. The paint of the veil over Christ’s genitals – not present in the original painting – appears to be covering the cracks and is likely to be a later addition.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The infrared reflectogram mosaic reveals that the composition was bisected horizontally and vertically with ruled lines in what appears to be a dry black material. These lines may have helped with the alignment of the cartoon that was used to transfer the design to the panel, though such marks are present in many other drawings and underdrawings by Raphael, regardless of whether the design was to be transferred or not.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The picture has been comprehensively repainted, perhaps on more than one occasion, although a reasonable proportion of original paints appears to survive beneath. The reason for the extensive repainting must lie with damage caused to the surface as a result of the process of transfer. Canvas, but transferred from the original wood panel, no trace of which appears to remain. It seems likely that the original ground structure would have consisted of a lower layer of gesso with an oil-based imprimitura on top. The gesso seems to have been removed entirely as part of the transfer process, but the imprimitura is intact and visible in cross-sectional samples. It is of an off-white, slightly warm tone and consists of lead white with powdered glass (manganese-containing soda-lime type identified by EDX analysis) and a small proportion of fine red earth pigment. The colour and constitution is therefore rather different from Raphael’s pre-Roman panels, which commonly contain a small amount of lead-tin yellow in the imprimitura, although lead-tin yellow, and no red, is present in the priming layer of NG744. The layer of transfer ‘adhesive’ used to affix the paint layers to the new support is of a pale to mid-blue and contains some Prussian blue as the colouring matter, with lead white. It has the characteristics of an oil binder.

Writers on Raphael have consistently disagreed about the date of the Bridgewater Madonna. Opinions have ranged from 1506-7[7] to 1512,[8] a wide span in the context of Raphael’s rapid development. Some have suggested that the painting was begun in Florence and completed later in Rome.[9] Purely stylistic considerations aside, the evidence hinges largely on the related drawings. The problem here involves separating those which are truly preparatory from those which are later reworkings of the theme, and this was a picture from which Raphael continued to draw ideas until the end of his career.[10] Some drawings once associated with the Bridgewater Madonna are now more correctly linked with the later Madonna di Loreto now at Chantilly, which despite the markedly different end result seems in some respects to have evolved directly out of the Bridgewater Madonna. One particularly problematic sheet in the Uffizi includes a reversed variant of the composition which was long regarded as a preparatory study for it, but is now widely accepted as a slightly later development.[11] One of the studies on the verso is related to Raphael’s first Roman project, the Disputà fresco in the Stanza della Segnatura of the Vatican.
Notes: [7] Crowe and Cavalcaselle, 1882-85, II, p. 345; Freedberg, 1971, p. 30; Oberhuber, 1982, p. 48. [8] Passavant, 1860, I, p. 152. [9] Pouncey and Gere, 1962, pp. 19-20; Brigstocke, 1993, p. 131; Clifford (see introduction). [10] The foreground Cupid in the Galatea fresco, for example, repeats the Christ Child’s pose in reverse, while the Virgin’s head reappears in a drawing in the Louvre of 1519-20 for the figure of Charity in the Sala di Costantino (Joannides, 1983, no. 454). [11] Uffizi Inv. no. 496E; Joannides, 1983, no. 202.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The yew panel is in very good condition. It has a slight convex warp. There is a fine crack in the wood at the centre in the lower part of the panel. This appears on the front of the painting, running up through the Child’s right calf. Another fine crack is evident to the right of this and there are further cracks running up from the lower edge of the panel towards the left end. The discoloured varnish present when the painting was rediscovered in 1991 was removed in a restoration undertaken shortly afterwards, revealing the exceptionally well preserved paint surface. There are a few small retouchings along the cracks and to some of the very small paint losses, for example on the Virgin’s neck and the back of her right hand, the Child’s forehead and the area of the Virgin’s draperies between his cheek and outstretched arm. Many of the losses are so small that they have not needed to be retouched. There has also been some retouching of the most disturbing of the minute pitted depressions on the right leg and lower torso of the Child. This pitted surface to the paint seems to originate from the process of painting rather than a later conservation treatment. Initially it would not have been visible but the depressions are now filled with dirt and varnish residues.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: In the bottom left corner is a dandelion, a bitter herb that appears in Netherlandish and German paintings of the Crucifixion, and was symbolic of Christian grief, and in particular Christ’s Passion. The dandelion clock also features in Raphael’s slightly earlier Holy Family with a Palm, and in the almost exactly contemporary Baglioni Entombment, where it is juxtaposed with Raphael’s signature inscribed on a rock (it has sometimes been considered a form of signature).[6] Raphael, who was not as instinctively interested in flora as Perugino or even Giovanni Santi, may have remembered the motif from other Umbrian paintings known to him. One such example is Bartolommeo Caporali’s altarpiece representing the Adoration of the Shepherds for the convent church of S. Maria di Monteluce in Perugia, for which Raphael and Berto di Giovanni were commissioned to paint the Coronation of the Virgin for the high altar in 1505. Caporali’s altarpiece (now in the Galleria Nazionale dell’Umbria), contains among other flowers a beautifully observed dandelion plant, with one whole clock, one three-quarters blown and three flowers in bud.[7] Raphael’s long-stemmed dandelion is characteristically more graceful. Notes [6] Jones and Penny 1983, p. 44. [7] Galleria Nazionale dell’Umbria inv. 178–9; Santi 1989, no. 52 (as Fiorenzo di Lorenzo).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
It comes as some surprise to discover how little of Christ’s body actually rests on, and is supported by, that of his mother. He is portrayed in mid-twist, his left arm and leg moving freely in an instantaneous and unsustainable pose. He clutches the Virgin’s veil for balance, a prop Raphael had already found useful in the Holy Family with a Palm Tree. It is using purely visual devices such as the Virgin’s parallel hands which frame Christ’s torso that Raphael stabilises his pose. This arrangement does not appear in the most advanced of the preparatory drawings, where the child is given much more in the way of physical support, and therefore must have been a late and deliberate change on Raphael’s part. Christ’s poignant gaze into his mother’s eyes intimates some knowledge of his destiny, and it has been suggested that his agitated pose might be explained by his having just woken from a dream about the Passion.[6] Similar though usually more explicit omens appear elsewhere in Raphael’s representations of the Infant Christ.
Notes: [6] Jones and Penny, 1983, p. 36.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The Virgin is seated in majesty on a carved wooden throne with the Christ Child on her lap. With poignant seriousness she draws his attention to a passage in an open book, presumably containing allusions to his inevitable future sacrifice. The delicate string of coral beads suspended from the canopy above the throne, terminating in jewelled crosses, is similar to a rosary, the scarlet colour of the coral a reminder of the blood Christ will shed. Together with the Latin inscription (Hail Mother of Christ) it would have acted as a prompt to the recitation of the rosary. The Baptist gazes up at his slender rock crystal cross, simultaneously pointing to Christ in prescience of his death by crucifixion. In contrast to Saint John’s dynamic rhetorical stance, the older, more contemplative Saint Nicholas withdraws slightly behind the throne, his furrowed brow indicating his absorption in the book he is reading. At his feet are three golden balls representing the purses of gold he provided as dowries for the three daughters of an impoverished nobleman to save them from a life of prostitution.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: This painting of the Virgin and Child with Saint John has traditionally been entitled the 'Aldobrandini Madonna' or the 'Garvagh Madonna' (after families who owned it in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries). NG 744 was probably painted when Raphael was working in the Stanza della Segnatura in the Vatican Palace, Rome. Raphael made numerous studies of the Virgin and Child in his drawings of this period, but none corresponds exactly with the composition in NG 744. There is however a detailed underdrawing (visible in infra-red); this seems to be both in metalpoint and in black chalk. Described in 1787 in the collection of Prince Aldobrandini in the Palazzo Borghese, Rome (and possibly identifiable with a picture described at the Villa Borghese in 1650); acquired by Alexander Day before 1800; bought by Lord Garvagh in 1818; bought from his widow and heirs, 1865.

Apart from slight woodworm damage, the panel is well preserved, retaining its original thickness. The painting was last cleaned and restored in 1992–5; this involved the removal of a discoloured yellow varnish and the residues of an older oil-resin varnish in the sky. Two nails from a later attachment to the panel that were causing disruption and flaking in the paint surface were also removed. The paint film is in good condition in the sense that there a few areas of total loss of paint. However, the surface has suffered slight abrasion in several areas. Worst affected is the group of women around the Virgin. The green glazes are almost intact, and still slightly brown, in the soldier behind and to the right of Christ, but have evidently been damaged in a past cleaning elsewhere on the painting. The deepest shadows of the figures painted with ultramarine blue have become blanched, most notably the tunic of the man helping to bear the cross and the cap of the bearded soldier to the right of Christ. Red draperies painted with red lake and lead white have faded and probably become warmer and more yellow in hue. The increase in transparency in these areas – Saint John the Evangelist’s mantle, the cloak of the man supporting the cross and the short cloak of the man mounted on the grey horse – means that the underdrawing is now more visible than originally intended.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Although the Garvagh Madonna evolved out of Raphael’s Umbrian and Florentine Madonnas, this and other examples from his early Roman years are distinguished by a greater informality of dress and pose, increased complexity of composition and a cooler, less saturated palette. Here, the Virgin sits sideways on a simple bench or plinth, with one leg tucked beneath her. She wears a blue, green and gold striped headdress, gracefully bound up in a turban-like arrangement (similar orientalising headdresses also feature in the Alba, della Tenda and della Sedia Madonnas and probably reflect a contemporary Roman fashion). The Christ Child is depicted with extraordinary naturalness, propping himself up with his left arm on the Virgin’s belly, his drawn-up knee and chubby foot splayed with all the flexibility of a real baby at this age. With a mischievous glance, he takes the sinuous carnation, symbolic of his future Passion, from the infant Baptist. Reminiscent of an allegorical figure of Charity (and indeed echoing in composition that subject in the Baglioni Entombment predella), the pensive Virgin seems prescient of the children’s future destinies, protectively drawing her mantle around Christ’s nakedness with one hand, while with the other gathering the sensuously rendered camel-hair pelt around the Baptist.

Saint Nicholas of Bari is different from the Virgin and Child and Saint John the Baptist. The underdrawing is much freer and the lines look much finer in the infrared reflectogram. The drawing in the face shows aspects of Raphael’s interest in geometry and volume – drawing the curves of the cheekbones, and the structure of the nose for example, which is similar to the kind of drawing seen later in The Garvagh Madonna.[14] Notes [14] Plazzotta C., ‘Raphael, The Madonna and Child with the Infant Baptist (The Garvagh Madonna)’ in Art in the Making: Underdrawings in Renaissance Paintings, ed. rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: A further revelation of the X-radiograph is the major alteration in the folds of the Madonna’s mantle. Originally the mantle enfolded her body with the Child seen against it. Indications of the blue mantle appear in small abraded areas by the side of Christ’s face and a thick underlying edge of this paint shows on the Madonna’s breast. The folds around her lower body were also considerably simplified. The flesh painting in this work appears dark in the radiograph like that in the Holy Family with a Palm Tree.

‘The fine composition of the Madonna with the Pink (16), the original of which is not known, belongs also, doubtless, to this Florentine time. The Virgin is holding the Child upon her lap, who is in lively action, and reaching gaily towards the pink, which she is giving to him. In the background is a window through which we see into the open air. A school picture of this subject was in the possession of the Cav. Camuccini. As on p. 728 (here without footnotes)

Having discounted the references to the 1515 foundation, the remaining passages in the 1720s fondo that actually concern Filippo Ansidei’s chapel can be reassessed (see Appendix 5 and 6). The most important of these described the St Nicholas chapel ‘in the body of the church, opposite St Joseph, by the pilaster’ (see Appendix 5). This information, combined with the memorial to the altarpiece in the church today, allows us to establish the location of the Ansidei chapel within the interior of S. Fiorenzo. The 1777 inscription ‘in eius altaris locum’ is immured to the left of the rebuilt Ansidei chapel, which incorporates a copy after the main panel of Raphael’s altarpiece by Nicola Monti (now the second altar on the right-hand side of the nave). […] a ground plan of the church and its altars drawn by the friars around 1650 is the only source of its kind that predates [Pietro] Carattoli’s radical alterations. The church is drawn in schematic fashion, but the major architectural features – the double portal, Latin cross and rectilinear cappella maggiore – are all recorded accurately. The two side chapels on the right side of the church are included as autonomous structures, but another altar is shown at the head of the nave, to the left of the entrance to the chapel which Moretti identified as that of the Ansidei. The isolated location of this altar would explain the description of the St Nicholas chapel on a pilaster in the main body of the church (see Appendix 5). It can also be reconciled with the location specified by the present commemorative inscription.

1800-1: Exhibited by Alexander Day, for sale by private contract, at 20, Lower Brook Street, London, no.10. (Catalogue printed in Buchanan, Memoirs of Painting, II, pp.3-10). 1816: Exhibited at the Royal Mews Gallery, by permission of the Prince Regent, no. 6. 1819: British Institution, no. 6, lent by Lord Garvagh. 1845: British Institution, no.6, lent by Lord Garvagh. 1915-18: Long-term loan, Cheltenham Art Gallery and Museum, Cheltenham, 3 June 1915 - 5 December 1918. 1992: Raphael's Madonna of the Pinks Rediscovered, National Gallery, London, 12 February - 29 March 1992. 2002-03: Art in the making: underdrawings in Renaissance paintings, National Gallery, London, 30 October 2002 - 16 February 2003, cat. 9. 2004-05: Raphael: From Urbino to Rome, National Gallery, London, 20 October 2004 - 16 January 2005, cat. 91. 2006: Raffaello. Da Firenze a Roma , Galleria Borghese, Rome, 19 May 2006 - 10 September 2006, cat. 40.

Far more compelling as an argument for the use of the cartoon is that virtually every line in the cartoon that was pricked can be seen in the underdrawing, even where Raphael then went on to make changes so that the lines are not followed in the paint. Most obvious is the knot on the Saint’s shoulder in the cartoon, which does appear, although in a truncated form, in the underdrawing but was never painted. In the drapery beside Saint Catherine’s left hand there are a number of changes – for example the folds in the yellow lining of the cloak are drawn roughly horizontal in the cartoon but painted falling diagonally to the left. In infrared reflectography the horizontal lines from the cartoon can be seen crossing the drawing for the folds as painted. In the final painting Raphael added extra folds as the dress is pushed up slightly against the cloak. The changes in the drapery folds were underdrawn freehand. The lines appear broader and darker than those relating to the cartoon perhaps because they are in a different material or possibly, as this is a change, they may be closer to the surface in the layer structure. Notes [12] None of the limited number of paint samples from this picture contain any underdrawing so it has not been possible to determine where in the layer structure it lies, but a difference such as this could be explained if the first drawing were under the priming and the changes applied over it.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The underdrawing describes the figures in great detail, the curtain and landscape are also drawn but less fully. There is no sign of pouncing and the design does not give any indication of having been traced, on the contrary it seems it was drawn freehand, although probably with reference to a pre-existing study. Raphael’s interest in geometric forms can be seen in the great sweeping curves drawn to position the upper body of the Virgin and create the curves of her breast. Over these freer lines is the careful drawing of details such as the careful positioning of the figures’ features, the pattern made by the Virgin’s braided hair and hooks to represent folds in her draperies. Other lines typical of Raphael’s underdrawings are the curves around the knuckles of the Child’s hands. In addition to outlines Raphael has added extensive parallel hatching to indicate shadows for example in the Child’s head and the neck and chest of the Virgin.
Perugia, Archivio di Stato, Scritture disposte per alfabeto, no. 25 (La Madonna degli Ansidei a S. Fiorenzo), no foliation Excerpts published in Manzoni 1899, p. 630.

In S. Fiorenzo alla destra del Pulpito vi è una Cappella chiamata della Madonna Santissima delle Grazie con ornamento di legno dorato, et è uno delli sette altari, a man destra [del quadro] vi è dipinta l’arma Ansidei con il campo rosso, et una benda gialla d’oro, a man sinistra, vi è un arma con il campo bianco, con questo segno = [Emblem], e sotto il quadro, che è coperto, che solo dimostra la faccia della Madonna e del Bambino, vi è dipinto in legno lo sponsalizio [della Madonna] di mano di Pietro, o Raffaello.
Antonius, et Haeredes Bernardini de Catrano Deo Optimo Maximo dedicaverunt 1515.

In S. Fiorenzo on the left of the pulpit there is a chapel called Madonna Santissima delle Grazie with decoration of gilt wood and is one of the seven altars, on the left hand side there is painted the Ansidei arms with a red field and a golden band, and on the left hand side there are arms on a white field with this symbol = [Emblem], and below the painting, which is covered, which shows only the faces of the Madonna and the Child, there is painted on wood a Marriage [of the Virgin] by Perugino or Raphael.

[Addition to Stanza IV, reconstruction; manuscript misbound]: ‘Heilige Katharina. Mit der herabgehaltnen Linken sich auf ihr Rad stützend. Ein Gesicht wogegen die Köpfe aller anderen Heiligen verschwinden. Tiefe Melancholie, und erhabne schöne Seele; ein unbeschreiblicher Ausdruck in dem lebhaften Blick der Augen gen Himmel, und die reizendste Unschuld und Heiterkeit des Geistes zugleich in den Lippen. Die rechte von Gefühl aufs Herz. Eine Landschaft, mit einem stillen Quellenwasser im Hintergrunde. Dies sind so recht seltne Gestalten in dieser Welt unter den fürtrefflichsten Weibern auch; aber es giebt ihrer. Ein süßer Trost bey Leiden.’

[Addition to Stanza IV, reconstruction; manuscript misbound] ‘Saint Catherine, with the left [hand] down, resting on her wheel. A face against which the heads of all other saints disappear. Deep melancholy, and sublime beautiful soul; an indescribable expression in the vivid look of the eyes toward the sky, and the most charming innocence and serenity of the spirit as well in the lips. The right [hand] feeling the heart. A landscape with a quiet spring in the background. These are such rare figures in this world among even the most excellent women; but they do exist. A sweet consolation while suffering.’

‘En février 1870, on exposait au musée du Louvre, dans la salle Denon qu’on appelle aussi la salle des batailles de Le Brun, le tableau d’autel des dames de Saint-Antoine de Padoue peint par Raphaël ; le propriétaire, M. Bermudez de Castro, duc de Ripalda, en voulait un million, c’est pourquoi il a été surnommé le « Raphaël d’un million ». Il avait d’abord été placé dans le cabinet de M. Reiset, qui aime le Sanzio et le connaît bien ; les empressés durent à son obligeance de voir les premiers cette œuvre capitale. On connaît bien son histoire qui est des plus authentiques depuis son origine jusqu'à nos jours. Exécutée à Pérouse vers 1504 pour le couvent des religieuses de Saint-Antoine de Padoue établi dans cette ville, elle fut achetée en 1678 pour le prince Colonna ; puis, en 1802, le roi de Naples l’acquit de la maison Colonna ; ce tableau fut conservé dans les appartements particuliers du roi jusqu'à l’année 1860 où il devint la propriété du duc de Ripalda. Embarqué alors sur un bâtiment de guerre espagnol, il finit par arriver à Madrid où il demeura jusqu'à la fin de 1869, époque à laquelle le duc obtint du gouvernement français l’autorisation de le déposer au Louvre. En l’exposant, l’administration voulait consulter l’opinion publique, et, si elle eût été favorable, le gouvernement aurait demandé le million aux Chambres. La guerre a mis fin à la négociation ; le tableau emballé dans une caisse est resté à Paris pendant le siège et la Commune, et, en juin 1871, il était dirigé sur Londres.’

’In February 1870, the altarpiece of the nuns of Sant’Antonio in Padua, painted by Raphael, was exhibited at the Louvre, in the Denon Room which is also called room of the battle of Le Brun; the owner, Mr Bermudez de Castro, Duke of Ripalda, wanted one million, this is why the painting was nick-named the ‘One Million Raphael’. It had first been placed in the cabinet of Mr Reiset who likes the Sanzio and who knows him well; those in a hurry owed it to his kindness to be allowed to see this major work first. Its history which is one of the most authentic is well known from its beginning to our days. Executed at Perugia about 1504 for the convent of the nuns of Sant’Antonio of Padua established in this city, it was bought in 1678 for the prince Colonna; then, in 1802, the king of Naples bought it from the Colonna family; this painting was kept in the private rooms of the king until 1860 when it became the property of the Duke of Ripalda. Having been loaded on a Spanish war ship, it finally arrived at Madrid where it stayed until the end of 1869, the period when the Duke obtained the authorization from the French government to deposit it at the Louvre. By exhibiting it, the administration wanted to consult public opinion, and, if it would have been favorable, the government would have asked the Chamber for one million. The war ended the negotiation; the painting stayed in Paris, packed away in a crate, during the siege of the Paris Commune, and, in June 1871, it was sent to London.’

NG 929 is a copy of Raphael's Bridgewater Madonna of about 1507 (Sutherland collection, on loan to the National Gallery of Scotland). The picture appears to be an old copy, possibly dating from the sixteenth century. Collection of 'M. le Prince Charles', 1722; Wynn Ellis collection, 1828; Wynn Ellis Bequest, 1876.

‘Madone à l’Œillet. […] Il existe plusieurs anciennes copies de ce charmant tableau, mais jusqu’à ce jour nous n’avons pu en découvrir l’original. D’après une communication qui nous a été faite verbalement, il serait dans la possession du comte Francesco Spada, à Lucques. On dit que, derrière le panneau, se trouve cette inscription : Per la N. Donna SS. Ricevuto 80 scudi. Raphaello. Cette indication nous paraît très-douteuse. […] Nous mentionnerons seulement les meilleures [copies] que nous ayons vues. a). Dans la collection du cavaliere V. Camuccini, à Rome. La Vierge est assise à gauche et tournée vers la droite. L’exécution de cette copie est délicate, mais la couleur froide. C’est certainement un ouvrage de l’école du maître. Des retouches à l’huile, faites dans cette peinture, lui ont donné un aspect très désagréable, en y laissant des taches. […].’

‘The Madonna with the Pink. […] There are several ancient copies of this charming painting but until today we have not been able to discover the original. According to a verbal communication it might be in the possession of Count Francesco Spada at Lucca. It is said that behind the painting is an inscription Per la N. Donna SS. Ricevuto 80 scudi. Raphaello. This reference seems very doubtful to us. […] We mention only the best [copies] which we have seen. a) In the collection of the Cavaliere V. Camuccini at Rome. The Virgin is seated to the left and turned to the right. The execution of this copy is delicate, but the colour cold. It is certainly a work by the workshop of the master. Some retouching in oil, made to this painting, gave it a very unpleasant appearance, leaving there stains. […].’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: When Plesters discussed the Vision of a Knight in 1983 she had been unable to find any evidence of pouncing in the infrared photograph and was forced to conclude that the pricking of the cartoon was for some other purpose,[5] however the new infrared reflectogram mosaic shows clearly that the underdrawing for the Vision of a Knight is based on pouncing.[6] The pounced dots have been joined up using paint or ink and only show where they have been trapped by the line, for example in the outlines of the hills in the background on the right, and in the back of the skirt of the figure on the right. Even where the actual dots no longer remains the style of the underdrawing revealed is typical of a drawing based on a cartoon transfer, with simple rather schematic outlines. Raphael was meticulous in his pricking of cartoons, using large numbers of closely spaced holes along every outline to produce an exceptionally complete replica of the cartoon on the panel, but after the basic design had been transferred he always elaborated the underdrawing further, adding hatching for shadows and making changes freehand.[7] For example he added a tiny group of buildings to the left of the central tree, level with the bridge; and a lovely free squiggle, presumably intending to signify bushes, in the distant landscape above the bridge on the right. Notes [5] “The implication is that although the drawing on paper may well be Raphael’s preparatory drawing for the painted panel, its use as a punched cartoon seems more likely to have been for the purpose of making a copy either of the drawing itself or of the painted panel.” Plesters J., ‘Technical Aspects of Some Paintings by Raphael in the National Gallery, London’ in The Princeton Raphael Symposium: Science in the Service of Art History, Princeton Monographs in Art and Archaeology XLVII, Shearman J. and Hall M.B. eds, Princeton, New Jersey 1990, pp. 15–37 and figs 1–29, esp. p. 18. [6] Confirmation of the presence of dots from pouncing was first published in Dunkerton J., Foister S., Gordon D. and Penny N., Giotto to Dürer: Early Renaissance Painting in The National Gallery, New Haven and London 1991, pp. 169–170. [7] Raphael’s use of cartoons is discussed in Bambach C., Drawing and Painting in the Italian Renaissance Workshop. Theory and Practice, 1300–1600, Cambridge 1999, pp. 14–15. For discussion of his use of a cartoon for The Procession to Calvary (NG 2919) see Plazzotta C., ‘Raphael, The Madonna and Child with the Infant Baptist (The Garvagh Madonna)’ in Art in the Making: Underdrawings in Renaissance Paintings, ed. Bomford D., exh. cat., National Gallery, London, 2002, pp 128–135, esp. pp. 124–127.

‘Raphael. – 1. The Crucifixion: […] This picture was painted originally for the chapel of the Gavari family, in the Dominican church at Città di Castello, whence it passed into the Fesch gallery, and thence into the possession of Lord Ward.’

There is no record of the frame when the 4th Duke of Northumberland acquired the painting together with the Camuccini Collection in Rome in 1855. A carved and partly gilded boxwood cassetta style frame was made around 1860 at Alnwick Castle (F20495). The Italian architect Giovanni Montiroli charged £6 for a full size drawing as design for the frame which was carved at the Duke’s school of woodcarvers, probably by John Brown (see Penny 1992, p. 80). In 1991 the Trustees of the 10th Duke of Northumberland loaned the painting to the National Gallery. It was reframed with a seventeenth-century Bolognese style frame (F20496) (Conservation Report, 14/04/1994, Frame Archive). The painting was acquired in 2004, and its present frame, a Venetian fifteenth- or sixteenth-century cassetta frame was purchased in 2005 from Konraud Riggauer, Munich by Mr and Mrs Ludovic de Walden and donated to the Gallery in the same year (F20492) (Conservation / Re-frame Report 11/2005 and Invoice from K. Riggauer, 25/10/2005, Frame Archive).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The cartoon was first recorded in 1833 when Passavant saw it, together with the painting, in the London collection of Lady Sykes. No other drawings for this composition are known, although it is probable that Raphael made some, since the outlines of the cartoon are unerring, as if he had already worked out the design elsewhere. Characteristically, he made a number of minor changes when he began painting. He adapted the neckline of Virtue to a rectangular design and modified the décolletage of Pleasure from a tight bodice with cleavage visible through a transparent chemise, to a looser, more modest tunic, with strings of coral beads criss-crossing over her breast. A stream traversed by a flat bridge was replaced by a crossroads with three horsemen. Otherwise the drawing is identical to the painting.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: There is gold on Saint John's halo and cross, around the neckline of the man nearest Saint John, and in the pattern on the chest and around the neckline of the man in a yellow tunic. The paint generally contains particles of powdered glass of the composition found in the other pictures discussed here. Its presence has been confirmed by EDX analysis in the imprimitura, the grey hose of the figure fourth from the left and the brown foreground

Rapid sketches for some of the figures in black chalk appear on a sheet in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford.[5] Infrared reflectography reveals that the worked-up design was transferred to the panel by means of pouncing through a pricked cartoon. An intriguing reference in a 1771 inventory of the Palazzo Ansidei, referring to a similar sized drawing of the same subject, suggests that the cartoon may have remained in the family’s possession (though its whereabouts are unknown today).[6] Notes [5] Joannides 1983, no. 96v. [6] We are grateful to Donal Cooper for this reference (for further details see Cooper and Plazzotta 2004).
As on p. 720 (here without footnotes)

In his testament of 12th October 1490 (see Appendix 1 below), the prosperous wool merchant Filippo di Ansideo di Simone, called ‘de Catrano’ (documented 1458–90), bequeathed money for his burial in the parish church of S. Fiorenzo, located some fifty metres from his house on what is now Via Alessi, in the quarter of Porta Sole, Perugia. He also made a bequest of one hundred florins for the endowment of a chapel dedicated to St Nicholas of Bari which he had erected in the church in 1483. […] an inscription commemorating his [Filippo’s] original foundation once carved in stone above the chapel read: ‘To St Nicholas Bishop of Bari, erected in humility by Filippo Ansidei de Catrano, 1483’ (see Appendix 6). Filippo almost certainly died of the illness alluded to in his testament since he ceases to appear in surviving documents after 1490. His chapel must therefore have remained without an altarpiece until Raphael was approached to provide one, probably at some point in 1503 or 1504.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
Cleaning has revealed a fairly subdued colour range with the dark purplish blue (once again a mixture of an organic red pigment and azurite) of the curtains, which had previously only been suggested by engravings, set against the dark brown of the architecture. The blue of the Virgin’s mantle is built up with a thin layer of ultramarine over azurite, a combination which Raphael used on numerous occasions.[14] Another well preserved detail is the crisp painting, probably in lead-tin yellow, of the Child’s curls.
Notes: [14] Rossi Manaresi, 1983, p. 130. This pigment combination is also noted by David Bomford (1980, p. 20).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Christ carries the cross, on his way to Golgotha. Behind him is Simon of Cyrene, who helps to bear the weight of the cross. The fainting Virgin is supported by the three other Maries. Saint John the Evangelist, beside her, wrings his hands. NG 2919 was the central scene of the predella below an altarpiece of the Virgin and Child with Saints, known today as the Colonna Altarpiece. This altarpiece was made for the church of S. Antonio, Perugia, in about 1504-5. The centre panel surmounted by a lunette as well as a part of the predella are now in New York (Metropolitan Museum of Art). Other parts of the predella exist in Boston (Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum) and London (Dulwich Picture Gallery). Sold by the nuns of S. Antonio, Perugia, to Queen Christina of Sweden, 1663; bought by the Duc d'Orléans, 1721; subsequently in the Hibbert and Miles collections; collection of the Earl of Plymouth (Lord Windsor) by about 1893; from whom bought, 1913.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Norton Simon Museum, Pasadena

Wood panel, probably poplar, but not identified microscopically. Gesso ground. Over the gesso there is a thin light-biscuit coloured imprimitura composed of lead white, powdered glass (manganese-containing soda-lime type) and some lead-tine yellow. The proportion of lead-tin yellow in the priming is rather higher than in certain of Raphael’s earlier pictures.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
GC analysis (published in 1972) of a sample from the green background and a sample from the white surplice found the binder to be walnut oil in both cases (P/S 3.0 and P/S 3.1 respectively) [1].
More recent analysis of samples taken in 2001 found a drying oil medium in each sample, identified by a large methyl azelate peak in the GC–MS traces. A degree of heat pre-polymerisation of the oil was also evident. However, variations in the ratios of methyl palmitate to methyl stearate between samples from the green background, the white cuff and the red mozzetta suggest that both linseed and walnut oil are present.
Notes [1] J. S. Mills and R. White, ‘The gas chromatographic examination of paint media part II. Some examples of medium identification in paintings by fatty acid analysis’, Conservation of Paintings and the Graphic Arts, Preprints of Contributions to the Lisbon Congress, 1972, IIC, London 1972, p. 725.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Archivio Segreto Vaticano, Archivio Borghese, busta 346, no. 3 [item no. 3 not found, verified Sept. 2008]

The full infrared reflectogram clearly shows areas of retouching, which mostly appear dark apart from a vertical damage in the forehead which appears light. As an image of the painting the distribution of highlights and shadows in the mozzetta and white surplus are enhanced and the background is easier to read as the corner of a room, as Raphael intended, than is the case in the actual painting in its present state. (note: the regular pattern of narrow horizontal lines across the infrared reflectogram are an anomaly created by the camera they are not in the original painting.)

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: In 1886 the Colonna Madonna was entrusted to the care of Earl of Ashburnham, whom the duke of Castro had designated as his representative in London. The altarpiece was transferred to the South Kensington Museum (today Victoria and Albert Museum) where it was kept under Ashburnham's care until its sale in 1896. Further correspondence relating to the period from 1886 to 1896 can be found at: - Victoria and Albert Museum Archives, M.A./1/C731 - East Sussex Record Office, Archives of the Ashburnham Family and their Sussex Estate, Correspondence, no. 929, p. 24

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The Allegory is first recorded in the Borghese collection in the seventeenth century together with a painting of identical size and style now in the Musée Condé, Chantilly. This shows the Three Graces (Chastity, Beauty and Love) each holding a golden ball.[4] Although – surprisingly – the paintings were not framed together or even at times exhibited in the same room during the 150 years they were in the Borghese collection, their identical size, tripartite subject matter, the similarity in the faces and poses of the female figures, and the strings of coral beads worn both by the Graces and Pleasure in the Allegory, suggest that they were conceived as a pair. Different hypotheses have been put forward as to how the two images were originally combined. The difference in figure scale makes it unlikely that they formed the wings of a diptych. The subjects are appropriate for painted portrait covers, but portraits were never square in format, and it is far more likely that one was the cover for the other, or that they were framed back to back, or even kept as independent treasures in a cloth bag or a drawer. Only by holding the Allegory up close, like a manuscript illumination (to which the picture is comparable also in the way it illustrates a written text), could the original owner have appreciated its minute attention to detail and jewel-like finish. (The landscape, the pointed roofs and spires of the buildings and the tiny figures in the distance, including three on horseback meeting at a crossroads, are reminiscent of Netherlandish manuscripts of extraordinarily high quality that were circulating at this date.) Regardless of how they were originally related, these delightful paintings form an ideal pair: indeed their conjunction of the masculine virtues of courage, learning and love with the feminine virtues of chastity, beauty and love might suggest they were made to mark the occasion of a marriage.[5] Notes [4] Symbols of perfection, these are sometimes interpreted as the golden apples which, as his eleventh Labour, Hercules had to gather from the tree guarded by the Hesperides. [5] A suggestive comparison is afforded by the reverse of Niccolò Fiorentino’s portrait medal of Giovanna Tornabuoni made to mark the occasion of her marriage to Lorenzo Tornabuoni on which the Three Graces are represented (see Béguin 1987, p. 464; Brown 2001–2, cat. 11).

The A/P ratio was slightly lower than expected in the brownish-pink paint sample (A/P 0.5). However, wax together with a degraded pine resin was also present, presumably the remnants of a surface coating. This slightly lowered the A/P ratio and increased the P/S ratio for this sample.
Waagen 1854, III, p. 253

‘Mrs. Blundell Weld’s Bedroom. […] Raphael. – A very delicately executed example on copper of the Madonna with the pink; the same size as the small picture in the Camuccini collection at Rome, which I do not consider to be the original. The tone of the flesh has something insipid and heavy. The treatment makes me suspect a Netherlandish hand.’

In 1957 a minute sample of ground and paint was taken from a damage in the sky at the top right corner. A solubility test performed on this sample suggested that the binding medium was likely to be egg tempera. However more recent examination has noted the presence of lead-soap inclusions in passages containing lead-tin yellow, including much of the landscape. This observation, whilst not entirely conclusive, is strongly suggestive of the use of an oil binding medium and the nature of the brushwork is also indicative of an oil medium.

Because of the small size of the picture, and its beautiful state of preservation, it was only possible to take a very limited number of samples from the extreme edge of the painted surface under the frame. For the same reason the wood of the panel could not be sampled for positive identification. The painting was also studied under the stereomicroscope at magnifications of up to 80x and on the stage of the Leitz Aristomet research microscope at magnifications up to 400x. Full freehand underdrawing, over the imprimitura, in a very fine greyish-black line, identified by EDX as metalpoint composed of an alloy of lead and tin.[59] Many exploratory passages and details, with some shading and changes in design between the underdrawing and the painted image. There is no visible evidence from the infrared reflectogram mosaic for the use of a pricked cartoon (that is, pouncing), although it cannot be excluded that one was used.[60]
Notes [59] Similar metalpoint underdrawing, using a stylus made from an alloy of lead and tin, has been identified, also by EDX analysis of a sample, on the Garvagh Madonna (NG 744), see C. Plazzotta in Art in the Making: Underdrawings in Renaissance Paintings, ed. D. Bomford. exh. cat., National Gallery, London 2002, pp. 122-35, esp. p. 130. [60] C. Bambach, Drawing and Painting in the Italian Renaissance Workshop. Theory and Practice, I300-1600, Cambridge 1999, pp. 14-15. R. Hiller von Gaertringen, Raffaels Lernerfahrungen in der Werkstatt Peruginos: Kartonverwendung und Motivübernahme im Wandel, Munich 1999, pp. 247-51.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: ‘On occasion of my visit to England in 1854 I had the privilege of spending a day at Alnwick castle as his Grace’s guest. [...] The Camuccini collection, which the Duke purchased at Rome in 1856, is to be placed in this castle. On this account it appears to me more appropriate to describe the pictures as if already here. […] Although the pictures had been known to me in Rome, yet the kindness of the Duke in allowing me to study them again on their arrival in Northumberland House was very acceptable. […] Raphael. – The small picture of the Virgin with the Child on her lap, who is holding a pink. It is well known that the charming composition is by Raphael, and of all of the numerous specimens of the picture I have seen, none appears to me so well entitled to be attributed to his hand as this. A notice in the Catalogue by Camuccini states this picture to have been painted by Raphael for Maddalena degl’Oddi, in Perugia, by whose heirs it was sold to a Frenchman before 1636, and taken to Paris, where Camuccini purchased it.’

‘The Vision of a Knight. […] W. Young Ottley bought this painting which was part of the Borghese gallery at Rome, and he sold it again in 1801 for £470. It passed from the succession of Sir Thomas Lawrence into the collection of Lady Sykes, and it was bought from the heir of the before said, the Rev. T. Egerton, for the National Gallery of London, in 1847 for the price of £1,050. One sees next to this painting at the National Gallery the original composition by Raphael, drawn in pen; it is an outline drawing with some hatches; it has been pricked to serve as a tracing. […].’

Sold to Ferdinand I, King of Naples and the Two Sicilies in 1802; little is known of how he came to own the Raphael altarpiece other than that the sale was handled by an agent named Venuti (see Wolk-Simon 2006, pp. 48, 49)

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: It would therefore appear that Raphael used a mixture of techniques when assembling The Ansidei Madonna on its panel. The key figures of the Virgin and Child had a cartoon, as did Saint John. Whether Saint Nicholas was drawn entirely freehand or had a simpler cartoon which needed more elaborate reworking on the panel is not clear, but infrared reflectography and x-radiography show that significant changes were made to this figure quite late in the picture’s development – he was initially bare headed and wearing shorter robes which revealed his ankles.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: In the earliest National Gallery catalogues, the portrait was classified – as it had always been in the past – as an autograph work by Raphael, but it soon came to be regarded as an early copy of a version in the Uffizi, Florence (though some authors were not persuaded that any of the extant versions could be identified as the original).[7] This situation persisted until 1969 when X-ray investigation of the National Gallery picture revealed numerous pentiments, including a radical revision of the background. This, in conjunction with the discovery of the Borghese inventory number in the bottom left corner, convinced almost all critics that the National Gallery portrait was after all the original one by Raphael.[8] Notes [7] Crowe and Cavalscelle 1882–5, II, pp. 102–9. [8] One exception is Beck 1996.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
In the earlier of these works, the Holy Family with a Palm Tree, it is possible to see the remaining influence of tempera with its emphasis on restrained handling and the painting closely following a carefully planned design. However, the fluency of the oil medium is already present, particularly in the treatment of costumes. The technique is largely carried on in the Bridgewater Madonna but minor adjustments in outlines are increasingly to be found. Also the Madonna’s mantle is much thicker than the rest of the painting. The X-radiograph shows that this is due, in part, to the rearrangement and repainting in the folds of the drapery but is also a reflection of the amount of medium required by the pigment to make paint. A similar thick blue layer in the Madonna’s mantle which shows the same cracking is found in the Small Cowper Madonna in the National Gallery of Art, Washington.[3] The ease in making fairly rapid and substantial alterations in composition was one of the advantages offered by the oil medium over tempera but the prominent cracking present in this passage is an indication of the problems associated with the oil medium if it is exploited too far. This development in technical handling is an important factor in determining the dating of Raphael’s work which increasingly exploits the inherent ability of oil paint to create a variety of textures and effects.
Notes: [3] Merril, 1983, pp. 139-47.

Perhaps a painting of shyness, which shows first steps in a new direction; a nearly genre-like mother of the Christ child, in a housedress, with deliberately attenuated colours; a propos so intended and executed that the authenticity can not be doubted. rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The portrait is usually dated to the one-and-a-half-year period during which Pope Julius is known to have worn a beard. This he grew as a token of mortification between October and December 1510 while he was recovering from a serious illness brought on by the loss of Bologna to French troops. The pope vowed to remain unshaven until the French had been chased out of Italy, and removed his beard only when events seemed to take a turn for the better in March 1512. The earliest date Raphael could have taken a bearded likeness was 27 June 1511, when Julius returned to Rome from his Emilian campaign. It is probable that the portrait was painted very shortly after this date, because of its close compositional relationship with the frescoed portrait of Julius as Pope Gregory IX approving the Decretals in the Stanza della Segnatura which was completed by August 1511 when Isabella d’Este’s ambassador described it as ‘His Holiness from the life with the beard’.[9] Many scholars have assumed that the easel portrait was painted after the Decretals fresco because of Julius’s older and more haggard appearance (Vasari suggested Raphael painted it when work had begun on the Stanza di Eliodoro).[10] However, it has recently been established that the heads in the easel portrait and the fresco match each other exactly line for line, and that therefore one depends on the other.[11] It seems more probable that Raphael made the easel portrait first, studying his model from life. The pope’s careworn expression may be explained by his continuing precarious state of health. In August 1511, he was struck by a second near fatal illness during which he received the last rites.[12] Notes [9] Shearman 2003, p. 148. [10] Vasari/BB, IV, p. 174. [11] We are grateful to Arnold Nesselrath for pointing this out. [12] Kempers 2004.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
The Christ Child Diagonal ruled lines that describe the steep perspective of the top step of the throne converge at point at the top of the Christ Child’s left wrist, the exact horizontal center of the main panel. Christ’s role as both the symbolic and compositional focal point of the painting is thereby reinforced. The figure is probably based on a cartoon (a full-scale preparatory drawing), but the majority of the underdrawing was executed freehand in a dry medium, most likely metalpoint. The underdrawing is extensive and refined; Raphael drew the searching contours and folds with great freedom and assurance. The Christ Child’s elaborate robe, with an enigmatic emblem on the shoulder, is delineated in the drawing, indicating that the clothing was not a later revision but was planned from the outset, undoubtedly in accordance with the wishes of the nuns of Sant’Antonio de Padova, as Vasari recounts. Minor adjustments during the working process include the repositioning of the emblem, which was shifted slightly, and the right cuff, which was originally drawn more fitted and closer to the wrist.
Head of Saint Peter The underdrawing of the heads of the two male saints was executed with a brush and accordingly exhibits more painterly quality than other passages of the underdrawing where metalpoint may have been employed. The artist drew the curls of the Saint Peter’s thinning hair and beard with light, arcing strokes; more emphatic lines indicate the wrinkles around the eyes, nose, and mouth. Raphael’s concern for describing volume and shadow is readily apparent, not only in the painted figures of Saints Peter and Paul, but also in the corresponding underdrawing.
Head of an Unidentified Female Saint The underdrawing of the heads of the two female saints is markedly different from that of the heads of the other figures. These hard, schematic outlines were traced or incised from a cartoon and then reinforced with a liquid medium. The mechanical process of transferring a cartoon to the grounded panel was probably delegated to an assistant, as was typical of workshop practice.
Section of Saint Peter’s Robe This detail indicates that the drawing of the robe was transferred from a cartoon by tracing or incising with a stylus. It was then reinforced with slightly faltering and mechanical-looking lines, drawn in a liquid medium that describe the contours and folds of the drapery. Small strokes of hatching are seen in the deepest folds.
Foot of Saint Paul The feet of the male saints are carefully underdrawn. Saint Paul’s left foot shows the drawn contours of the toes (with some small adjustments between drawing and painting), nails and joints. Saint Paul and Saint Peter were originally drawn wearing sandals. Raphael then chose to paint the saints barefoot. It is, however, interesting that they are portrayed wearing sandals in an altarpiece in the Galleria Nationale dell’Umbria, Perugia, by a minor Umbrian painter, Sinibaldo Ibi, that is directly based on Raphael’s composition.
Shadow on step The spidery lines that descend the molding and cross the step show that at the earliest stages of laying in the composition Raphael was planning the powerful spatial effect of the shadow cast by St. Paul on the throne. These delicate, searching lines were probably executed in metalpoint, a medium well suited to freehand drawing.
Saint John The slightly wavering hand-painted lines describing the moldings of the throne were underdrawn before the figure of Saint John was painted and can be seen extending well into the space that he occupies, both in his left shoulder and his right leg. Running vertically through his right side is an incised, ruled line marking the edge of the throne. It is no surprise that Raphael drew and incised in detail this elaborate stepped, spatially complex throne before the adding the figures. Saint John has a minimal underdrawing in comparison to that seen in the Christ Child.
Landscape Raphael used a pen and ink sketch (The Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, PII 508b) as a guide for the bold freehand drawing of the buildings in the background behind Saint Paul. While he made minor modifications when he drew the church and houses on the panel, the buildings retained the spatial relation they have in the sketch. The diagonal half-timbering on the house was clearly important to the artist, as it appears in both the sketch and the underdrawing. In painting the church, the artist decided to omit the tower in the left.
