rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The sky consists of a layer of natural ultramarine over a layer of azurite, in both cases mixed with white. The Madonna's dark blue cloak is painted as a thin glaze of virtually pure ultramarine over a layer of azurite, with a little lead white in the lighter areas of the drapery for the modelling. Both the ultramarine and azurite paint layers are medium rich and have probably darkened markedly as a result. The deepest shadows are finished with hatched strokes of very dark paint containing only ultramarine. The blackish strip of paint on which the gold inscription at the top of the Madonna's throne is painted contains azurite, and was also originally a brighter blue.

This unusual pigment has been detected in other sixteenth-century Italian pictures, although not in any other painting by Raphael in the National Gallery collection.

Gavari’s chapel was modelled on a very similar one in the opposite aisle, erected in the previous decade by Tommaso Brozzi and dedicated to Saint Sebastian. This contained an almost identically proportioned altarpiece depicting the Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian by Signorelli, with a comparable male nude at the centre of the composition. Raphael must have carefully studied this work and indeed made a copy after one of the crossbowmen. He was not, however, deflected from the principles of symmetry, clarity and harmony in part learned from Perugino, and his painting is a virtual manifesto of those aspects of his mentor’s manner, in notable contrast to the busy asymmetry and foreshortenings of Signorelli’s altarpiece. Raphael prominently signed his work by scratching through the brown paint at the foot of the cross to a layer of silver leaf beneath. Vasari famously commented that were it not for this signature, no one would have believed it had been painted by Raphael and not Perugino.[5] Notes [5] Vasari/BB, IV, p. 158.

The foreground also contains this pigment with some azurite and lead-tin yellow.
Inherited after M. A. White of Barron Hill’s death

Un quadro bislongo con l’istoria di Cristo condotto al Monte Calvario con la croce in spalla, con molti soldati a piedi ed a cavallo seguito dalla Vergine, che sviene in mezzo alle Marie, in paese, di Raffaele, in tavola a giacere alta p.mi uno e larga p.mi tre e mezzo senza cornice. 144 & 145. ‘143. A long and narrow painting with the story of Christ led to Mount Calvary with the cross on his shoulder, with many soldiers on foot and on horseback followed by the Virgin, who faints in the middle of the Maries, in a landscape, by Raphael, on a horizontal panel one ‘palm’ high and three and a half wide without frame. 144 & 145. Two other panels adjacent to the same, one with the prayer in the garden and sleeping disciples, and the other of the dead Christ on the Virgin’s chest with St. John who supports him, kneeling the Magdalene who kisses one of his feet, and Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus standing in a compassionate attitude, one ‘palm’ high and just below one and a quarter wide. 146 & 147. Two other panels, one with St. Francis, and the other with St. Anthony of Padua standing, walking on either side, one ‘palm’ high and two thirds wide without frame.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The cartoon, in black chalk with touches of white chalk on four sheets of beige paper pasted together, is pricked for transfer along the outlines.[9] When Plesters studied the painting for the Princeton Symposium she only had IR photographs to help her and reported that the underdrawing consisted of “smooth, thin lines, with no sign of spolveri”.[10] The fact that the Paris cartoon was used for the National Gallery painting has been difficult to prove. The correlation of sizes between the two was tested first, by taking a tracing of the figure in the painting over to France and laying it over the drawing. Apart from the angle of the head the two were found to match so closely that a second tracing was made, this time a “map” of all the pricked holes in the cartoon.[11] This was brought back to London and when the picture was re-examined with infrared reflectography, with the help of the “map” it was possible to find a few traces of spolveri (although it has to be said that, had we not had such good reasons to believe in them, they would probably have been rejected as not sufficiently distinct from the spots caused by bubbles in the gesso). Notes [9] Département des Arts Graphiques, Musée du Louvre, Paris, inv. 3871. See Chapman H., Henry T. and Plazzotta C., et. al., Raphael: From Urbino to Rome, exh. cat., National Gallery, London 2004, p. 231. [10] Plesters J., ‘Technical Aspects of Some Paintings by Raphael in the National Gallery, London’ in The Princeton Raphael Symposium: Science in the Service of Art History, Princeton Monographs in Art and Archaeology XLVII, Shearman J. and Hall M.B. eds, Princeton, New Jersey 1990, pp. 15–37 and figs 1–29 (p. 25). [11] This work was carried out by C. Plazzotta, J. Dunkerton and T. Henry, with the kind assistance of Catherine Goguel of the Département des Arts Graphiques at the Louvre.

Kress Foundation, New York; gift 1943 to NGA.
[1] The complete provenance of this painting is described in David Alan Brown and Jane Van Nimmen, _Raphael & the Beautiful Banker_, New Haven and London, 2005. Regarding deaccessions from the Pinakothek, see also Jonathan Petropoulos, _The Faustian Bargain_, Oxford, 2000: 31+. The painting is listed in the General Stock Book of Duveen Brothers that covers the period 1 June 1937 to April 1941 (copy in NGA curatorial files; Duveen Brothers Records, Accession No. 960015, Getty Research Institute, Reel 66, Box 186).

‘Die Bekanntschaft mit dieser netten Sammlung konnte uns keinen Ersatz dafür geben, dass wir die von Herrn P. J. Miles in Leight Court nicht zu sehen bekamen, da der Besitzer abwesend war und er seiner Dienerschaft beim Verlust ihrer Stelle untersagt hatte, seine Sammlung ohne seine besondere Erlaubniss und seine Gegenwart irgend einem Fremden zu zeigen. Nur nach einer Beschreibung mit radirten Abbildungen, welche John Young vor etwa 10 Jahren herausgegeben hat, sind mir diese Bilder bekannt. Nach dem, was ich von einem Kenner vernommen, sind folgende die vorzüglicheren: Raphael. Die Kreuztragung, ein kleines, langes Bild, welches einen Theil der Predella des Altarblattes für die Nonnen des heil. Antonius von Padua zu Perugia ausmachte. Es war mit den übrigen in der Gallerie Orleans und ist von N. De Larmessin gestochen.’

‘Ill, however, could the inspection of this pretty collection repay us for our disappointment at not seeing the famous gallery at Leigh Court, the access to which, unfortunately for us, owing to the absence of the proprietor, was strictly denied to every stranger. My knowledge, therefore, of these pictures, is only derived partly from the report of a brother connoisseur, and partly through the medium of the etchings, with annexed descriptions, published about ten years ago by John Young. Raphael. Christ bearing a Cross, a small long picture, which formed part of the Predella for the altar piece of St. Anthony of Padua, at Perugia. Formerly with the other portion of the altar piece in the Orleans Gallery, and engraved by N. de Larmessin.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The X-radiograph shows that the vertical losses followed the grain of the former deteriorated wood support but fortunately skirted the finely preserved features and profile of the Virgin. Further damage had occurred in areas of paint which apparently had not been sufficiently supported during the transfer process and had been fragmented. These areas too had avoided any sensitive part of the work and on the whole, though the damages were severe they were also quite localised. The remainder of the surface is in surprisingly fine condition.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Lead-tin yellow ('type I') has been identified by XRD in the drapery of the Magdalen and of the angel on the right, which also contains yellow earth pigment in the warmer tones. Lead-tin yellow occurs extensively in the mixed browns and greens of the landscape and has been identified by XRD in the Virgin's green sash. The brownish-gold rays of the sun at the upper left contain orpiment (mineral arsenic trisulphide; EDX), now rather deteriorated. The deep brown paint of the cross is based on vermilion, black and earth pigments.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The picture has been comprehensively repainted, perhaps on more than one occasion, although a reasonable proportion of original paints appears to survive beneath. The reason for the extensive repainting must lie with damage caused to the surface as a result of the process of transfer. Interpretations of the layer structure may be affected by the presence of considerable amounts of overpaint, although Raphael’s original over the off-white imprimitura is fairly easy to discern in most cases where samples are available.

Because of the small size of the picture, and its excellent state of preservation, no samples were taken during the present examination; the painting was studied under the stereomicroscope at magnifications up to 80x.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
Artist: Raphael Title: The Agony in the Garden Date: 1504-5 Dimensions: 9 ½ x 11 ½ in. (24.1 x 28.9 cm) Curatorial Department / Accession number: European Paintings / 32.130.1 Conservator: C. Hale Date(s) of Examination: November 2009
The relationship of the Metropolitan’s panel to the Morgan’s The Agony in the Garden , a drawing pricked for transfer and the only surviving study for the predella of the Colonna Altarpiece, had not been established conclusively up to this point. Previous infrared examination of the painting revealed neither underdrawing nor spolveri. The painting was reexamined with new equipment: the Merlin InGaAs near infrared digital camera (sensitive to wavelengths from 0.9 to 1.7 microns), fitted with a customized macro lens sensitive to the same range, in April, 2009. This examination revealed some underdrawing around the contours of the figures and in folds of drapery, though no spolveri. It is likely that the underdrawing is more extensive than what we are able to image, but that it is masked by the dense overlying paint layers. Fortunately, there are two areas where the paint does not coincide with the underdrawing so it can be seen clearly: in the extended foot of the young disciple in green and yellow (where the initial contour line describing the top of the foot was placed within its painted contour) and in Christ’s robe (where two diagonal lines indicate folds around the feet).
On 11/17/09, Peggy Ellis, Director of the Thaw Conservation Center at the Morgan, brought to the Met enhanced infrared images of the drawing which map the tiny holes pricked through the drawing to transfer the design. The coincidence of the drawing and the infrared reflectogram was initially examined using a one-to-one infrared reflectogram of the painting and acetates of the enhanced digital infrared photograph of the drawing, but more effective was overlaying digital images using layers in Photoshop (see digital file. A high resolution image of the painting was overlaid with the infrared reflectogram and the enhanced infrared photograph of the drawing, and the X-radiograph of the painting. A perfect alignment of the overall images was not possible due the deformations in the paper support and minor distortions from the assembly of the infrared reflectogram, but aligning the infrared photograph of the drawing in several different positions, with small shifts in between, created perfect local alignment, down to the smallest details. Significantly, when the bottom left quadrants of the images were aligned, in the extended foot of the young disciple in green and yellow, the prick marks lined up over the initial contour line describing the top of the foot, and when the bottom right quadrants were aligned the prick marks lined up over the two diagonal lines of underdrawing indicating folds around the feet of Christ’s robe. This provides conclusive evidence that the pricked drawing was used to transfer the composition to the panel. Additionally, the prick marks can be aligned with X-radiograph to show that the chalice was originally painted as it appears in the drawing, before it was painted out and replaced the angel holding a smaller chalice.

’1600. 8. III. Pesaro. Il Duca Francesco Maria a Giacomo Sorbolongo. [Cancellato]. Quando si fosse per far essito delle pitture del Card.e Sfondrato, noi non saressimo gia per attender’ alla compra di tutte insieme, secondo l’intentione che dite esserci nel uenderle, ma potendone hauere qualcheduna di gusto nostro, saressimo per pigliarle uolentieri, e però non solo hauete fatto bene a darcene auiso, ma saremo anco per ueder uolentieri la notola d’esse, la quale, oltra il resto che si richiede per informatione di dette pitture, uorressimo che contenesse anco come siano ben conditionate, essendo qualita questa che merita d’esser hauuta in molta consideratione. [In the margin] A quello che ci auuisate per conto delle Pitture del Card. Sfond(ra)to crediamo bene che non si conuuenga di pensare a si gran fascio, con tutto cio potrete mandarcene la notola che dite, con aggiunta di come siano ben conditionate, che forse co’l uederla noi, et con far uoi di là qualche manifattura, si potrebbe trouar strada di far bene.’

‘8 March 1600. Rome. Duke Francesco Maria to Giacomo Sorbolongo. [Erased]. At the moment of the sale of the paintings of Cardinal Sfondrato we would not be in [favour] of buying the whole lot, according to the intention you say there is in selling them, but being able to have some of them of our liking, we would gladly take them, and in fact not only have you done well to inform us but we will also be willing to see the little note regarding them, which, beside the other information requested about the aforesaid paintings, we would like it to contain also information about their good condition, being this a quality which merits to be held in great consideration. [In the margin] [Regarding] that which you inform us about the pictures of Cardinal Sfondrato we think that it is not convenient to consider such a great bundle, however you could send us the note regarding them, as you say, with the addition of how good their condition is, as perhaps when we see it, and when you have made some [restoration] works over there, we could find a way to do well.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: However, it is also possible that the pictures were painted for a Sienese patron. The figure group of the Three Graces is based on a Roman sculpture owned by the Piccolomini family who moved it from their Roman palace to Siena in 1502. At around this time Raphael was himself in the city, assisting Pintoricchio with designs for the Piccolomini Library where the sculpture was displayed. Although datable a couple of years later, it has been suggested that the Allegory could have been painted for a youthful member of the Sienese Borghese family named Scipione, since it was subsequently recorded in the Borghese collection in Rome.[9] Whatever its original destination, no more evocative exemplum could be imagined for a virtuous young nobleman, particularly if – as the Allegory’s counterpart in Chantilly implies – he stood on the threshold of marriage with one in whom all the feminine graces were reunited. Notes [9] Panofsky’s suggestion that they were painted for the first communion of a Scipione Borghese (b. 1493), which took place in 1501, should, however, be discounted: this date is too early for the painting and the subjects are inappropriate for such an occasion.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Raphael’s bold iconic presentation of the saint in ecstasy developed out of conventions previously adopted principally for altarpieces. Perugino was a notable pioneer of religious sentiment in devotional works, and his figures – frequently with upturned heads and raised eyes – were praised by contemporaries for their ‘angelic air’. Raphael may well have been reapplying lessons learned from a work such as Perugino’s Certosa Altarpiece, in which the saints are depicted independently, in separate compartments, on account of the original polyptych format. Perugino’s juxtaposition of the figures against distant landscapes, the still-life details of flowers, and in particular Tobias’s upturned head, open-mouthed expression and contrapposto pose, are all highly comparable to equivalent features in the Saint Catherine.

GC–MS analysis of the imprimitura indicated that heat-bodied walnut oil had also been used in this layer (A/P 3.4; P/S 2.9; A/Sub 1:3.4), however, the paint was found to be lean in medium relative to the other areas analysed.
Analysis by FTIR microscopy of a sample from this imprimitura layer illustrates some of the difficulties involved in the interpretation of binding media results from complex samples. Large colourless glass particles were visible and spectra from regions containing these inclusions had bands that could be interpreted as amide bands from protein (ca. 1650 and 1550 cm-1). This could have led to the conclusion that an egg tempera binding medium had been used, however, when other areas of the imprimatura that did not contain any glass particles were examined, the composition was shown to be lead white in an oil medium, corroborating the results obtained from the GC–MS analysis. The apparent ‘amide’ bands could therefore be assigned to lead soaps and hydrated/deteriorated glass [1].
Notes [1] M. Spring, C. Higgit, and D. Saunders, ‘Investigation of Pigment-Medium Interaction Processes in Oil Paint containing Degraded Smalt’, National Gallery Technical Bulletin, 26, 2005, pp. 56-70.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The sky is composed of natural ultramarine (lapis lazuli) mixed with white, painted directly onto the imprimutura. The Virgin’s sleeves and cloak are also finished with ultramarine, mixed with some red lake pigment in the shadows and combined with white and a little red lake in the lights. Some fading of the lake seems probable. The ultramarine-containing layers of the drapery pass over an underpaint of greenish-coloured mineral azurite mixed with white; the later paint is a pigment combination used also for the greenish landscape of the middle ground.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: In normal light underdrawing can be seen all around the left foot of the angel dressed in green, but in infrared reflectography there is clear drawing for the toes but it does not continue up the leg. The fact that some of the underdrawing disappears in infrared reflectography and some does not (although looking the same in normal light where visible) suggests that two different materials have been used; the one that disappears is probably iron gall ink while the other is a carbon-containing black. The almost random choice of one or other material (both being used in the same figure sometimes, for example Christ, whose drawing disappears in his arms and hands but does not in his loin cloth or knees) suggests that the artist was not particular as to which black ink he used for the drawing of a particular area, but just used whatever was to hand.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: As on pp. 727-8 (here without footnotes)

Much of the confusion stems from two closely related texts copied for Cardinal Ansidei (see Appendix 3 and 4). In both versions the Ansidei chapel is described on the left side of the church from the entrance ‘con ornamento di legno dorato’, accompanied by family stemmi, a merchant’s emblem, and an inscription recording the dedication of the altar in 1515 by ‘Antonius, et Haeredes Bernardini de Catrano’. Manzoni identified this ‘Bernardino de Catrano’ with one of Filippo’s younger sons of that name, who was frequently documented in Perugia at the beginning of the sixteenth century. […] In his Scorta Sagra, Ottavio Lancellotti cited the 1515 dedication, not in his description of the St Nicholas chapel in S. Fiorenzo, but in a separate entry for the chapel of Beato Filippo Benizzi in the same church: ‘The [chapel’s] panel is not deemed an average work. It formerly belonged to the Catrani family, having been founded in 1515 by Antonio and the heirs of Bernardino Catrani, today it belongs to the Timotei.’ This information must derive from the same inscription recorded by Manzoni’s source, but the chapel was evidently not Filippo Ansidei’s foundation, which Lancellotti recorded elsewhere in his compendium. Lancellotti’s text establishes beyond doubt that there were two Ansidei chapels in S. Fiorenzo in the sixteenth century: Filippo Ansidei’s 1483 chapel dedicated to St Nicholas, and another founded by the Benincasa branch of the family in 1515. Furthermore, Lancellotti glossed his judgment of the Benizzi altarpiece with a marginal note: ‘It being a work by the Perugian Sinibaldo Ibi, disciple of Raphael Santi of Urbino.’ This painting is identifiable as Sinibaldo Ibi’s Virgin and Child enthroned with Sts John the Baptist, Joseph, Fiorenzo and the Blessed Filippo Benizzi in the Galleria Nazionale dell’Umbria in Perugia.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: This detailed drawing is the cartoon which Raphael used to transfer his design for the Vision of the Knight to panel. In addition to laying out the overall composition, he paid close attention to nuances of light and shade in the figures, confidently building up the shadows with rapid diagonal strokes of hatching and cross-hatching. The figure of Scipio and the upper body of Virtue are elaborated in more detail than other parts. For the areas of deepest shade on and beneath the shield he intensified this linear hatching into a diamond pattern reminiscent of engraving, a technique with which he was familiar through study of Northern prints. The cartoon – with its indications of light and shadow – would have been kept for reference during the execution of the painting, since only the outlines could be transferred by pouncing. The main outlines were pricked through with a pin and black chalk dust was pounced through onto the gessoed panel in preparation for painting. These dots have mostly been brushed off the gesso and are therefore difficult to detect in the underdrawing. However, some of the underdrawn lines have a blotchy quality where the ink has stuck to remnants of chalk, confirming that pouncing was indeed used, and their hesitant character is indicative of the mechanical procedure of joining up the dots, and is quite unlike freehand drawing.[1] Notes [1] This disproves the opinion expressed by Plesters, in Shearman and Hall 1990, pp. 17–18.

A sample of transparent dark green paint from the left arm-band of the figure on the horse was analysed by GC–MS in 1993. The presence of a drying oil was confirmed by the detection of a large methyl azelate peak in the GC-MS trace (A/P 1.4). The ratio of the palmitate and stearate fatty acid methyl esters, P/S 3.0, indicated the presence of walnut oil while the ratio of the dicarboxylic acids, azelate and suberate (A/Sub 4.4) suggested no or little pre-polymerisation. A small amount of pine resin was also present, indicated by the presence of methyl dehydroabietate and methyl 7-oxodehydroabietate [1].
Recent analysis by FTIR microscopy of samples from six different areas of the painting suggests that the binding medium is oil throughout, but further GC–MS analysis would be required to establish the type of oil in each case.
Notes [1] R. White and J. Pilc, 'Analyses of Paint Media', National Gallery Technical Bulletin, 16, 1995, pp. 85-95.

’Eisdem millesimo (1678) Indictione (prima) et Pontificatu (Innocentij undecimi) Die uero octaua mensis januarij. Actum Perusiae in V. Monasterio S. Antonij de Padua in Choro eiusdem Monasterij presentibus etc. Coram Ill.mo et Reu.mo D. Luca Alberto de Patritijs meritissimo Episcopo Perusino, sedente etc. Conuocato, congregato, et cohadunato generali Capitulo RR. Monialium V. Monasterij S. Antonij de Padua in loco supradicto ad sonum campanulae de ordine et mandato infrascriptae R. M. Abbatissae ubi interfuerunt infrascriptae videlicet. Ad.m R. M. S. Victoria a Cornea Abbatissa R. M. S. Iuditta Vicaria (sequuntur nomina aliarum Monialium n.o 28) quae ut supra capituraliter congregatae asserentes esse ultra duas ex tribus partibus vocem in capitulo habere illudque totum et integrum representare, uigore et in uim facultatis et licentiae ipsis concessae – Agentes infrascripta omnia et singula cum presentia licentia auctoriate et decreto praefati Ill.mi et Reu.mi D. Episcopi ibi presentis etc. nec non cum presentia et assistentia ad.um R. P. f. Clementis de Cannario Guardiani V. Conuentus S. Francisci de Monte Perusiae, Superioris, ac R. P. f. Francisci de Perusia Confessoris eiusdem Monasterij sponte etc. dederunt uendiderunt, cesserunt, ac libere tradiderunt Ill.mo C. Com. Io: Antonio de Bigazzinis nobili Perusino presenti stipulanti et recipienti pro se, eiusque heredibus etc. Depictam Tabulam opus celeberrimi Pictoris Raphaelis de Vrbino, quae in superiori semiarcuata ac seiuncta Tabula praefert imaginem Dei Patris cum duobus Angelis, et Serafinis hinc inde adstantibus, et tabulam inferiorem latitudinis palmorum octo, et longitudinis pariter octo palmorum, et in qua habentur imagines Deiparae Virginis sedentis in solio, suumque Vnigenitum filium gestantis in sinu, ac aspicientem Praecursorem suum Io: Baptistam eidem solio, Virginique innixum nec non a dexteris S. Petri Apostoli, et S. Catherinae Virginis et martyris, a sinistris uero S. Pauli Apostoli pariter et S. Margheritae itidem Virginis et Martyris et quae asseruabatur in ecclesia interiori, et Choro supradicti V. Monasterij Et eodem venditionis, cessionis, et concessionis titulo, et causa dictae RR. Moniales dederunt et eidem D. Comiti Io: Antionio presenti omnia et singula ac quaecumque earum jura nullo penitus jure sibi reseruato etc. Hanc autem venditionem fecerunt supradictae Moniales quia sic etc. et ex causis in supra enunciata et infrallegata licentia expressis et pro precio et precij nomine scutorum bis mille monetae, de paulis decem pro scuto; in quorum computum dictus D. Comes Io: Antonius pro summa et quantitate scutorum quatuorcentum trigintaquatuor b. 41 q. 3 monetae dedit – suprascriptis Monialibus – creditum quod in simili summa habet contra Sanctem Pauolozzium de territorio Castilionis Lacus etc. (sequuntur aliae quinque cessiones creditorum, post quas) Alia scuta ducentum monetae praefatae Moniales fassae fuerunt habuisse, et recepisse a dicto D. Comite Io: Antonio in tot frumento et uino pro eorum usu ante presens instrumentum, de quibus quietauerunt in forma eumdem D. Comitam presentem Alia uero scuta quatuorcentum septuagintatria b. 58. q. 2 pro residuo et integra solutione supradictae Moniales habuerunt et receperunt in contanti, et pecunia numerata a dicto D. Comite Io: Antonio, quem presentem de dicta integra summa scutorum bismille quietauerunt in forma etc. Promisit quoque dictus D. Comes Io: Antonius infra tres menses proximos ab hodie fieri facere et tradere copiam supradictarum pictarum Tabularum ad formam dictae et infralligatae licentiae, alias de proprio etc. etc.’

‘In the same year (1678), (first) indiction, and in the pontificate (of Innocent XI) where on the 8th day of the month of January. The act done in Perugia in the venerable monastery of St Anthony of Padua in choir of the same monastery, being present etc. In the presence of the most illustrious and most revered Lord Luca Alberto de Patritiis of the greatest merit, Bishop of Perugia. The general chapter of the most revered nuns of the venerable monastery of St Anthony of Padua being convened, assembled and joined together in the place mentioned above to the sound of the small bell of the order of the below-written Reverend Mother Abbess – where evidently the below-written [nuns] were present: [addendum, in addition] Reverend Mother Superior Victoria a Cornea, Abbess Reverend Mother Superior Judith, Deputy (followed by the names of 28 other nuns) that they being summarily assembled, more than two out of three parts of the chapter agreed, this representing the whole and entire [chapter], in vigour and strength of ability – each and every [of the nuns] below mentioned granting with the present authorised license and the decree (made previously) from the most illustrious and most revered lord bishop being here present etc . with the presence and assistance of Reverend Father friar Clement de Cannario guardian of the convent of St Francis of Mount Perugia, Superior, and the reverend father friar Francis of Perugia confessor of the same monastery, with free will etc .. they [the nuns] give, sell, concede, and hand over freely. To the most illustrious Count Iohannes Antonio de Bigazzini, a noble of Perugia, present, in promise and guarantee for himself and for his heirs etc. The painted panel, a most renowned work of the painter Raphael of Urbino, in which in the upper arch and separate panel there appears an image of God the Father with Angels and Seraphim standing, and the lower panel has the width of eight ‘palms’, and the equally a height of eight ‘palms’, and in which there are images of the Virgin, Mother of God ,sitting on a throne, and her only born son held on her breast , and gazing upon Him is John the Baptist by the throne, and supporting the Virgin to the right is St Peter the Apostle, and St Catherine Virgin and Martyr, and to the left is St Paul the Apostle together with St Margaret likewise Virgin and Martyr, and they [the panels] are kept in the inner church, and choir of the above mentioned venerable monastery. And by the same deed, [the panels] being sold, ceded, and granted, and the most reverend nuns sold [the panels] by the mentioned stipulation and to the same Don Count Iohannes Antonio, present, in all and every (thing) and within no rights whatsoever reserved. Thus the above mentioned nuns made the sale etc and from the stipulations expressed in the above mentioned legal license for the named price of price being two thousand scudi, of Paul X for the scudi. In which calculations, the said Lord Count Iohannes Antonio, for the amount and quantity of 430 scudi four b. 41 q. 3 of money, gave the above mentioned nuns credit for a similar sum he had against Sancto Pauolozzio in the territory of Castilionis Laucis (followed by five other concessesions of credit, after which:) Regarding another two hundred mentioned scudi mentioned, the nuns will receive from the named Lord Count Iohannes Antonio all [200 scudi] in grain and wine for their own use, in the present [legal] instrument, in which they had agreed in this way with the present Lord Count. Another [amount] of four hundred and seventy scudi and b. 58. q. 2 for the remaining and entire payment mentioned above the nuns will be received in cash, and the money counted by Lord Count Iohannes Antonio, with whom they agreed in this way the entire amount of two thousand scudi. The named Lord Count Iohannes also agreed, within the next three months from today to have made and to bring a copy of the above mentioned painted panel according to the way of mentioned license, apart from his own, etc, etc.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
Also in 1985, two further samples were analysed by GC; one from the blue paint of the sky and one from the black border at the edge of the panel, with original green paint underneath. The results of these analyses were interpreted as showing the binding medium of the paint to be egg tempera [1] . This was based on the very low levels of methyl azelate detected. However more recent research has demonstrated that in certain cases low methyl azelate levels can be detected in oil paint samples [2] . FTIR spectra from samples of similar areas, recorded during the more recent examination in 2003, do not show any indication of the amide bands at ~1650 and 1550 cm-1 expected if protein, from an egg tempera binding medium, was present. Rather these spectra all contain a band at 1730-1740 cm-1, due to the glyceride esters, present in the oil medium.
Notes [1] J. Plesters, 'Technical Aspects of Some Paintings by Raphael in the National Gallery, London', in The Princeton Raphael Symposium: Science in the Service of Art History, Princeton Monographs in Art and Archaeology XLVII, eds J. Shearman and M.B. Hall, Princeton, New Jersey 1990, pp. 15-37 and figs 1-29. [2] C. Higgit, M. Spring, and D. Saunders, ‘Pigment-medium Interactions in Oil Paint Films containing Red Lead and Lead-tin Yellow’, National Gallery Technical Bulletin, 24, 2003, pp. 75-95.

Because of the small size of the picture, and its beautiful state of preservation, it was only possible to take a very limited number of samples from the extreme edge of the painted surface under the frame. For the same reason the wood of the panel could not be sampled for positive identification. The painting was also studied under the stereomicroscope at magnifications of up to 80x and on the stage of the Leitz Aristomet research microscope at magnifications up to 400x. GC-MS analysis of samples from the yellowish-brown bench on which the Virgin sits, the blue sky and the off-white imprimitura identified the binding medium as heat-bodied walnut oil. The paint of the imprimitura was found to be lean in medium relative to the other areas analysed.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: NG 213 may illustrate an episode from Silius Italicus' Punica, in which case the knight who sleeps beneath a bay tree would be the Roman hero Scipio Africanus (236-184 BC). In a dream he was offered a choice between Virtue, who lived at the end of a steep and rocky path (seen behind her), and Pleasure (at right), who is less soberly dressed. However, the two women are not presented as contestants, and the attributes they hold (a book, a sword and a flower) suggest the ideals of scholar, soldier and lover which a knight should combine. The panel has been dated stylistically to about 1504. A related panel of identical size and depicting The Three Graces exists (Chantilly, Musée Condé) - it is likely that one was the cover for the other, or that they were framed back to back, or even kept as independent treasures in a cloth bag or a drawer. A cartoon for NG 213 formerly in the Collection was transferred to the British Museum in 1994. Borghese collection, Rome, before 1633; collection of William Young Ottley, 1798; said to have been in the collections of Sir Thomas Lawrence and then of Lady Sykes (1833); bought from the Revd Thomas Egerton, 1847.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Saint Catherine of Alexandria leans against her traditional attribute of the wheel on which she was tortured. NG 168 was probably painted just before Raphael left Florence and went to Rome. The pose of the saint reflects his study of the dynamic compositions of Leonardo and Michelangelo. A full-size and pricked drawing for NG 168 is in Paris (Louvre). Collection of a cardinal of the Crescenzi family (seal on reverse); recorded in the Villa Borghese, Rome, before 1633; acquired by Alexander Day, before 1800; bought from William Beckford, 1839.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Ce tableau date de la période florentine du peintre, vers 1505-1507. On ignore le nom de son premier propriétaire, mais sans doute se trouvait-il au Piémont où de nombreuses copies ont été réalisées au début du XVIe siècle ; peut-être appartenait-il au duc Charles II de Savoie qui en fit faire une copie. Au début du XVIIIe siècle il est en France dans les collections du duc d’Orléans, Régent. Il est vendu au début de la Révolution avec la galerie du Palais-Royal par Philippe-Egalité, duc d’Orléans et grand-père du duc d’Aumale, qui n’eut de cesse de le racheter, car le tableau porte le nom de sa famille. L’iconographie s’inspire du Saint Jérôme de Van Eyck (Detroit Institute of Art) qui appartenait à Laurent le Magnifique ; le pot surmonté d’une pomme présent sur l’étagère derrière la Madone reprend le pot de tyriana visible dans le Saint Jérôme. Le tyriana est un remède médiéval contre les morsures de serpent, or le serpent dans l’iconographie chrétienne est l’image du mal. Raphaël reprend donc l’idée de Van Eyck, qu’on retrouve dans de nombreux tableaux comme l’Annonciation de Filippino Lippi à San Gimignano, mais sans l’inscription, celle-ci devenant inutile puisque bien connue des contemporains. Du point de vue stylistique, il présente une nette influence michelangesque dans l’aspect sculptural de l’enfant. La Madone d’Orléans est un témoin des Vierges de dévotion privée de la jeunesse de Raphaël. Elle est une preuve de plus du raffinement de la culture de ce dernier. Musée Condé
Transcription of a letter from Colnaghi to Ashburnham, dated 12 July 1896, in the files of the Department of European Paintings, The Metropolitan Museum of Art

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
It is assumed that all three works [Holy Family with a Palm Tree, Bridgewater Madonna, Madonna del Passeggio] are painted using an oil binder although no analytical examination has been carried out to confirm this. By the time these works were painted, the gradual transition from tempera, which uses an egg binder, to the more expressive potential of the oil medium was almost complete. Already in the Mond Crucifixion in the National Gallery, London, datable to 1503, oil has been identified as the medium.[2] Significantly Perugino, Raphael’s master, was a pivotal figure in this crucial transition as was Leonardo da Vinci who was also to be a powerful influence on him.
Notes: [2] Plesters, 1983, p. 23.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Waagen 1859, pp. 271-2 (for the date see also Shearman 2003, p. 97)

‘Auf dem ersten mit 1505 bezeichneten Bild [...]. Von den Nonnen im Jahr 1678 um 2000 Scudi an den Grafen Giovanni Antonio Bigarrini in Rom verkauft, gelangte das Bild später in die Galerie Colonna, und gegen das Jahr 1800 an den König von Neaple, wo es sich noch in den Zimmern des Königlichen Palastes befindet. Von den fünf Stücken der Altartafel, welche von den Nonnen schon 1603 an die Königin Christina von Schweden verkauft, später in die Galerie Orleans, und mit dieser nach England kamen, zeigen die Kreuztragung und die Beweinung Christi in Composition wie Ausführung entschieden den florentinischen Einfluß; bei dem Christus am Ölberg möchte die Ausführung, bei dem heiligen Francescus und Antonius von Padua aber auch die Erfindung von Mitschülern des Rafael herrühren.’

‘On the first picture dated 1505 […]. The picture, sold by the nuns in the year 1678 for 2000 scudi to Count Giovanni Antonio Bigarrini in Rome, came later to the Colonna Gallery, and about the year 1800 to the king of Naples, where it still is in the rooms of the royal palace. The five pieces of the altarpiece, which were sold by the nuns already in 1603 to Queen Christina of Sweden, came later in the Orleans Gallery, and with it to England; Christ Carrying the Cross and the Lamentation of Christ show in composition as well as in execution a distinctively Florentine influence; the Christ on the Mount of Olives might be in its execution, and the Sts Francis and Anthony of Padua also their invention from the school of Raphael.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: This is a cartoon for a painting in the National Gallery of the Virgin and Child, a work generally known as the Mackintosh Madonna after its donor Miss Eva Mackintosh. Sadly the picture is in such a ruinous and repainted condition, in part due to it having been transferred from panel to canvas in the eighteenth century, that it has not been included in the present exhibition. Although the cartoon is in a better state than the painting, it too has suffered: the chalk or charcoal (or perhaps a combination of the two) and the paper are much abraded. As a result, in the more shadowed areas the tonal gradations and the underlying modelling of form have been blurred to a virtually impenetrable blackness. This is especially apparent in the passages around Christ’s left leg and in the Virgin’s drapery at the lower right corner. These damaged areas can be interpreted by comparison with the ruined original, and conversely some idea of the original quality of the painting can be gained through study of the cartoon.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Among Raphael’s small-scale Madonnas, the Garvagh Madonna represents the height of formal purity, and the metalpoint underdrawing shows that the idealising tendency extends to individual features, which are prepared with a schematic shorthand of arcs and circles. The perfect proportions of the Virgin’s head epitomise a formal ideal that fascinated later classicising painters, including Sassoferrato, and above all Ingres.

Le panneau des Trois Grâces fait l’objet d’une abondante bibliographie, qui est détaillée dans les publications émanant du musée Condé : . Elisabeth de Boissard, Hommage à Raphaël, Raphaël au Musée Condé, cat. d’exp., Chantilly, musée Condé, 1983 (n°25 du « Bulletin de Musée Condé), cat. n°29. . Elisabeth de Boissard, Valérie Lavergne-Durey, Chantilly, musée Condé, peintures de l’école italienne, Inventaire des collections publiques françaises, 34, Paris, RMN, 1988, n°66, p.125-127. . Les peintures italiennes du musée Condé à Chantilly, ed. Generali, 2003, p. 198-219, cat. 48.
Le tableau a été étudié à plusieurs reprises sous l’angle du laboratoire :
- En septembre 1983, une mission à Chantilly a donné lieu à la constitution d’un dossier d’imagerie scientifique comprenant des photographies en lumière directe, rasante, infrarouge et sous fluorescence d’ultraviolets (clichés 42136 à 42139), une photographie du revers (cliché 42140) ainsi qu’une radiographie (rx 5020).
Un rapport (n°1821, septembre 1983) a été exploité dans la communication suivante :
. Lola Faillant-Dumas, « Etude de la technique picturale et du dessin sous-jacent de quelques tableaux de Raphael », ICOM-CC, 7th triennal meeting, Copenhagen, 1984, p. 84.1.10-84.1.13. (publication d’une photographie infrarouge d’ensemble).
- En 1986, une mission de Charles de Couessin à permis d’examiner le tableau au moyen d’une caméra réflectographique infrarouge et de réaliser plusieurs clichés de détails du dessin sous-jacent.
Les observations recueillies ont été publiées dans :
. Charles de Couessin, «Le dessin sous-jacent de quelques tableaux de Raphaël des collections publiques françaises» Raffaello, ricenti indagini scientifiche, Actes du congrès de l’ICOM-Italie, Milan, juin 1986, s.d ., p. 65-96 (détail de la photographie infrarouge du corps des trois femmes ; réflectographie infrarouge de la femme de senestre et du bras droit de la femme au centre).
- Ces textes ont été complétés dans des publications plus récentes : . Sylvie Béguin, « Nouvelles recherches sur le ‘Saint Michel’ et le ‘Saint Georges’ du musée du Louvre », Studi su Raffaello, actes du congrès d’Urbino, 1984, Urbino-Florence, 1987, p. 455-464 (publication des photographies infrarouge et UV). . Elisabeth Martin, Jacqueline Bret, « Enquête technique sur quelques chefs-d’oeuvre italiens », Les peintures italiennes du musée Condé à Chantilly, s.l., Editoriale Generali, 2003, p.198-219. (publication de la photographie infrarouge de l’ensemble et d’un détail des deux femmes de senestre, à mi-corps).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
There is both gold and silver on the picture, applied in several different ways. The sun on the top left is water gilded - gold leaf applied to red bole - and the silver moon on the top right is made in the same way. There are more delicate touches of gold on Christ's loincloth, the angels' wings, Saint Jerome's belt and the borders of the robes of the Virgin and Saint John. It is not certain how the gold was applied in these areas, but the lack of a pigmented mordant and the character of the line suggest that it is probably shell gold, even though it appears more solid than is usual for shell gold.[45] A reserve was left for the relatively large letters of the inscription above the cross. This has been confirmed by a recent cross-section in which a comparatively thick orange-brown oil mordant layer for the gold leaf is present directly on the imprimitura. The mordant contains the strongly drying pigments red lead (lead tetroxide) and verdigris. The silver inscription at the bottom of the cross is also mordant gilded, but is unusual in that the brown paint of the cross was brought over the silver and then scratched away to form the letters in a type of sgraffito technique.
Notes
[45] In the back-scattered image in the scanning electron microscope of a sample of the gilded pattern on the green cloak of Saint John it could be seen that the gold was not a continuous layer of gold leaf bur was in the form of flakes. It is therefore likely to be shell gold. It seems more substantial than is usual for shell gold, but is similar to the gilding on the border of Saint John's robe in the Ansidei Madonna, where it is more certain that it is shell gold.
Archival material has been excluded with due regard to the Data Protection Act and Public Records Act.
Passavant 1839, II, no. 55, esp. p. 79

‘Es gibt mehrere alte Copien dieses hübschen Madonnenbildes, ohne dass ich bis jetzt noch das Original entdeckt hätte. [...] Ich will hier die vorzüglichern mir bekannten Exemplare angeben: a) In der Sammlung des Cavaliere Vinc. Camuccini in Rom. Sie sitzt links und ist rechts gewendet. Die Behandlung hat etwas zartes; die Färbung ist kalt. Es komm sicher aus der Schule Rafael’s. Leider hat es durch Retouchen mit Ölfarben ein etwas fleckiges Ansehn erhalten. […]’

‘There are several old copies of this lovely picture of the Madonna, without having discovered the original yet. […] I will give here the better versions known to me: a) In the collection of the Cavaliere Vinc. Camuccini in Rome. She sits on the left and is turned to the right. The handling is somewhat delicate; the colouring is cold. It certainly comes from the school of Raphael. Unfortunately it has a somewhat spotty appearance due to retouchings with oil paints. […].’

‘[…] in 1856, I have had the opportunity of inspecting it in the possession of Mr. Munro, to whom Lord Ward entrusted it for a time.’

In the Pietà at the right end of the predella, Raphael borrowed certain motifs, such as the seated Virgin, the kneeling pose of Saint John and the clasped hands of Nicodemus, from Perugino’s Pietà in S. Giusto, but there is far less rhetorical gravitas and more tender intimacy in Raphael’s small scene, designed specifically for the private devotions of the nuns. Perugino depicted Christ’s elongated body laid out rigidly, but Raphael’s Christ is small, his limbs are soft and round, and his vulnerability is conveyed by the bruised flesh around his wounds (especially that in his side) and the dark shadows under his eyes. His graceful pose is more evocative of serene sleep than death (compare the sleeping knight in the Allegory, a painting to which both the Agony and the Pietà are stylistically very close). Neither Christ’s features nor the scale of the figures are particularly consistent in the three predella scenes, perhaps implying that they were designed at intervals or simply that Raphael was not attentive to the overall design of the predella.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: This altarpiece was painted for the Ansidei family chapel in the Servite Church of S. Fiorenzo in Perugia. The chapel had been erected in 1483 by Filippo di Ansideo di Simone ‘de Catrano’, a prosperous wool merchant, whose will of December 1490 left provision for its maintenance as well as for his burial in the church. [1] Filippo’s eldest surviving son Niccolò (b. 1469 – after 1527) inherited his father’s business interests and therefore probably also assumed the patronage rights of the chapel. It is he who most likely commissioned Raphael to paint the altarpiece in around 1504–5.[2] This is supported by the fact that the two saints in the altarpiece reflect his name and that of his eldest son Giovanni Battista (b. 1496). The Ansidei altar was originally located on a pier on the south side of the nave at the point where it meets the transept. It was demolished when the church underwent extensive refurbishment in the baroque style in 1768–70. In 1768, perhaps to pay for the renovations, the monks of S. Fiorenzo sold Raphael’s altarpiece, with at least part of its predella, to the dealer Colin Morison, who in turn sold it to Lord Robert Spencer.[3] A copy of the altarpiece (minus the predella) was commissioned from Nicola Monti to replace the original, and remains in situ on the reconstructed altar. Notes [1] Cooper and Plazzotta 2004. [2] Mancini 1987, pp. 57–60; Cooper and Plazzotta 2004. [3] Cassidy 2008 (Passavant 1833, pp. 173-4, erroneously assumed that the altarpiece had been bought by Gavin Hamilton, on behalf of Lord Robert Spencer, in 1764). Lord Spencer, then on his Grand Tour aged 21, seems to have acquired the altarpiece on behalf of his brother the fourth Duke of Marlborough, from whose descendant the eighth Duke it was purchased by the National Gallery in 1885. Spencer kept the related predella panel for himself (see NG 6480).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Even at the cartoon stage, Raphael seems to have had doubts about whether to include the knot of drapery on the saint’s right shoulder, though this faintly drawn feature was pricked for transfer and appears in the underdrawing on the panel. The drapery folds above the twist of the saint’s mantle are more complex in the painting than in the cartoon, and were elaborated by Raphael in strong dark strokes of underdrawing directly onto the prepared panel. Minor pentiments in the index and middle fingers of the saint’s left hand occur in both the cartoon and the underdrawing, indicating Raphael’s ongoing concern to get this key passage right. The painted composition extends about another 10 cm at the bottom. Infrared reflectography reveals no trace of pouncing in this area of the painting, but it is hard to tell whether the drawing has been cut along this lower edge or whether Raphael was presented with a slightly taller panel than he expected and simply extended the design at the painting stage.
Frankfurt/M., Stadt- und Universitätsbibliothek, [MS] Heft 22, pp. 5, 6, fols 3, 3v, quire 2 and p. 11, fol. 6, quire 3 (see also Wiecker 1977, pp. 32, 34 and p. 41) Wilhelm Heinse in full

‘Stanza IIII. [...] Drey Gemähldchen auf einem breiten Brete, worunter das in der Mitte gewiß von Raphael. Viel kindliche Schönheit [‘in’, crossed out] aus der Idee. Zwey schöne weibliche Gesichtchen, viel Grazie im ganzen Kontur. Ein [‘kranker’, crossed out] schlummernder Soldat unten in der Mitte auf einem Schilde [‘und hinten’, crossed out]. Die eine hält ein Blümchen, die andre ein Buch. Ein Landschäftchen.’ [Stanza IX which corresponds to stanza XII in Heinse’s description] ‘Drey Grazien auf dem länglichen Bretchen von Raphael ist ein reizend Studium von Konturen; die vom Rücken ist lauter Mark darin und Nachschub in Schenkeln; sonderbarer Haarputz mit Corallen überzogen wie Perücken. Alle drey haben Aepfel. Die linker Hand hat ein wollüstig gedrängtes Leibchen; und zieht die Beine wollüstig schaamhaft an den Knieen zusammen; die andre rechter Hand hat eine Binde um die Schaam; jede betrachtet ihren Apfel. Der Grund ist an einem Wasser wie zum Baden. In den Gesichtern Naivität.’

‘Fourth Room. [...] Three small paintings on a broad panel, amongst which, the one in the middle is certainly by Raphael. A lot of childlike beauty [‘in’, crossed out] of the idea. Two beautiful feminine small faces, very graceful in the whole contour. A [‘ill’, crossed out] Knight below in the middle dosing on a shield [‘and behind’, crossed out]. One holds a little flower, the other a book. A little landscape.’ [Stanza IX which corresponds to stanza XII in Heinse’s description] ‘Three Graces on an oblong panel by Raphael, a charming study of contours; the one (seen) from the back is all of marrow and full in the thighs; strange hairstryle covered with corals like wigs. All three have apples. The one on the left has a lusty small body; and pulls together her knees in a lusty bashful way; the other on the right has a cloth around the pubis; each looks at her apple. The background shows water for bathing. In the faces naivety.’

‘Viertes Zimmer. […] Die heilige Catharina, von demselben [Raphael]. Derselbe Stil, ja sogar dieselben Blumen auf der Erde. Der Kopf voller Ausdruck hat viel von seiner Galathee im kleinen Pallast Farnese, der sogenannten Farnesina.’

‘Fourth room. [...] Saint Catherine, by the same [Raphael]. The same style, and even the same flowers on the ground. The head full of expression has a lot of his Galathea in the small Palace Farnese, the so-called Farnesina.’

Giuliano della Rovere (1443-1513) was elected pope in 1503. He took the name of Julius II and was active both in defence of the church and as a patron of the arts until his death. NG 27 can be dated to the period from June 1511 until March 1512, when Pope Julius grew a beard as a token of mortification at having lost the city of Bologna, in imitation of ancient practices of mourning. The picture was probably set up in 1513 (after his death) in his favoured church of S. Maria del Popolo, Rome. This portrait was considered by contemporaries to be one of the greatest of Raphael's portraits, but NG 27 was not recognised as Raphael's original until 1970. Before then it had usually been considered an old copy, and the copy attributed to Titian (Florence, Palazzo Pitti) was sometimes claimed as the original. Papal cross-keys are faintly visible on the green background; these appear to have been Raphael's original idea for the background. He changed his mind in favour of the green curtain. Probably in the church of S. Maria del Popolo, Rome, until 1591, and then in the collection of Cardinal Sfrondati; probably bought by Cardinal Scipione Borghese, 1608; J.J. Angerstein collection by 1823; bought, 1824.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The painting was celebrated in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, judging from the many early copies and prints made after it. It was first published as by Raphael in Francesco Longhena’s monograph of 1829, but was subsequently dismissed as a copy after the greatest early authority on Raphael, Johann David Passavant (who saw the picture in Rome in 1835), published it as one of the best of many copies after a lost original.[4] The Camuccini themselves were demonstrably uncertain about the status of the work,[5] but it was promoted by Barberi and valued above all other paintings when the Camuccini sold their collection to the fourth Duke of Northumberland in 1855. Although installed at Alnwick as a Raphael, the painting’s reputation was eroded by the negative opinions of scholars and gradually ceased to be prized as an original work. Nicholas Penny rediscovered the Madonna of the Pinks in 1991, and his attribution (endorsed by the vast majority of Raphael scholars) was verified by scientific investigation of the underdrawing and the pigments, both typical of Raphael’s pre-Roman productions. It was acquired by the National Gallery in 2004 following a public appeal. Notes [4] We are grateful to Martin Sonnabend, who found the reference to the painting among Passavant’s notes on the Camuccini collection, in vol. 4 (1835, p. 195) of his unpublished notebooks held in the print-room of the Städel, Frankfurt. See also Passavant 1839–58, I, p. 131; II (1839), p. 79. [5] It is called ‘Maniera di Raffaello’ in an inventory of the family’s possessions of 1833; see Finocchi Ghersi 2002, p. 372, no. 11.

Jean Baptiste Colbert, Marquis de Seignelay, Paris, by 1685;[1] Laurent le Tessier de Montarcy; André Rondé; Louis, Duc d’Orléans, by 1727; by descent at the Palais-Royal, Paris, to Louis-Philippe-Joseph, Duc d’Orléans (Philippe Égalité), by whom sold in 1792 to Édouard Walckiers of Brussels (but resident in Paris); by whom sold in the same year to his cousin François-Louis-Joseph de Laborde-Méréville, Paris; by whom transported to London in 1793 and mortgaged to the banker Jeremiah Harman; by whom sold in 1798 to the dealer Michael Bryan, acting on behalf of a syndicate consisting of Francis, 3rd Duke of Bridgewater, his nephew George Granville Leveson-Gower, Earl Gower (later 2nd Marquess of Stafford and 1st Duke of Sutherland) and Frederick, 5th Earl of Carlisle (husband of Lord Gower’s sister); reserved by the Duke of Bridgewater; by whom bequeathed in 1803 to Lord Gower; by whom bequeathed in 1833 to his second son Lord Francis Egerton, from 1846 1st Earl of Ellesmere; by descent to John, 5th Earl of Ellesmere, from 1963 6th Duke of Sutherland, by whom placed on loan to the National Gallery of Scotland in 1945; by whom bequeathed to Francis, 7th Duke of Sutherland in 2000.
Notes: [1] The existence of several apparently 16th century versions of the painting in French collections suggests an earlier French provenance for either the Bridgewater Madonna itself or an early copy of it. See Cordellier and Py, 1992, p. 84.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: In contrast to Raphael’s precise, linear cartoons in pen and ink for small-scale works between 1500 and 1504, the Louvre cartoon and others of this slightly later period (see the Cartoon for the Mackintosh Madonna) demonstrate a rougher, more experimental type of drawing, with far greater emphasis on tonal modelling. This new approach was clearly the result of Raphael’s study of techniques developed by Leonardo, who embellished his cartoons with extraordinary chiaroscuro and sfumato effects (see The Virgin and Child with Saint Anne and Saint John the Baptist). Raphael used a broad-ended chalk to reinforce the contours in certain areas (the wheel, some of the drapery, Catherine’s neck), going over some of the outlines several times. He laid in the shadows with fairly rough hatching and cross-hatching, not always in the same direction, softening the transitions by rubbing the chalk with his fingers, and used white chalk, similarly rubbed, for some of the more prominent highlights. The cartoon would have been kept as a guide to the lighting of the figure once the contours had been transferred, and indeed hatching in the shadows of the saint’s sleeves and down the left side of her body in the underdrawing was clearly copied freehand and not traced.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
Because of the small size of the picture, and its excellent state of preservation, no samples were taken during the present examination; the painting was studied under the stereomicroscope at magnifications up to 80x. An earlier report based on solubility tests on a single sample suggested the use of egg tempera;[46] however, the presence of lead-soap inclusions in passages containing lead-tin yellow (including much of the landscape) strongly suggests the use of an oil binding medium. The nature of the brushwork is also indicative of an oil medium.
Notes [46] J. Plesters. 'Technical Aspects of Some Paintings by Raphael in the National Gallery, London', in The Princeton Raphael Symposium: Science in the Service of Art History, Princeton Monographs in Art and Archaeology XLVII, eds J. Shearman and M.B. Hall, Princeton, New Jersey 1990, pp. 15-37 and figs 1-29, esp. p. 17.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note:
The radiograph also revealed that the construction lines of the architectural background, including the niche, had been fully and carefully incised with a stylus – the ‘geometric scaffolding’ which Penny noted Raphael was to use from his earliest altarpiece onwards. There is clear indication that the niche had been a window looking on to a landscape. This was later painted out presumably by Raphael himself although there is no certain evidence to support this other than the directness of handling and the subtlety of the representation of the fall of light over the forms of the architecture. The rather discordant brown shape at upper right only seems to make tonal sense if read as a shutter catching light from the previously existing window. There is a parallel here with the Madonna del Granduca in the Pitti Palace in Florence which also had a window framing a landscape which was then painted out. This was thought formerly to be a later alteration by another hand but subsequent examination suggests that it was made by Raphael. The supporting evidence for this includes convincing original details such as the curls of the Child’s hair encroaching on to the overpainted area.[11]
Notes: [11] Chiarini, 1983, p. 79; Chiarini, 1986, pp. 21-28.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The satisfying geometry of the composition, in which the picture space is divided vertically and horizontally into harmonious thirds (reminiscent of compositions by Piero della Francesca), was carefully calculated. Close scrutiny reveals that the picture surface was prepared with a grid nine squares high by six squares wide incised into the gesso with a stylus.[4] The whole composition is therefore based on a simple geometrical construction in the proportions of 3:2, a scheme Raphael would have worked out in squared composition drawings on paper. One important aspect of the picture’s composition was, however, improvised at a late stage, namely the pale grey architecture and vaulting behind the Virgin’s throne, which endows the sacred figures with their own hallowed space. Recent technical investigation has revealed that this lofty vaulted structure was not planned by Raphael from the beginning, but was painted over the sky and landscape after painting had begun. Raphael used the pre-existing grid to position the parapet (one-third of the way up) and the mouldings (approximately two-thirds of the way up). This explains why the architecture seems so integral to the composition and why the revision has never been noted before. He may have made this significant alteration to compensate for a lack of structure in the actual architecture of the chapel or altar frame. Two separate seventeenth-century sources record that the Ansidei chapel was plain and deficient in ornament in contrast to the noble majesty of the altarpiece.[5] The idea of setting the figures in a barrel-vaulted interior had already been adopted by Raphael for his first known altarpiece (see his studies for the Coronation of Saint Nicholas of Tolentino), and reflects his early exposure in Urbino to works by Piero della Francesca and his circle. Notes [4] The squares are 24.5 cm wide; approximately two-thirds of a Perugian piede (equivalent to 36.4 cm). [5] Cooper and Plazzotta 2004.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The significance in the variation of the results has not been fully explained. However, the painting is known to have undergone extensive reworking, especially in the background, which may offer some explanation for the use of different oils.

Artist: Raphael Title: Madonna and Child with a Book (“Madonna at Nones”) Date: c1503 Dimensions: oil on wood, 20 ¾ x 15 ¾ in. (52.7 x 40 cm) Collection: Norton Simon Museum, Pasedena. Norton Simon Art Foundation (M.1972.2.P) Conservator: C. Hale Date of Examination: 9/5/06
Following the exhibition, “Raphael at the Metropolitan”, focusing on The Colonna Altarpiece, the Norton Simon Museum’s Madonna and Child (“Madonna at Nones”) was examined using infrared reflectogaphy with the Indigo Systems Merlin Near Infrared camera, and was X-radiographed, at the request of the Norton Simon. A complete infrared reflectogram mosaic and a complete X-radiograph mosaic accompany this report, in digital form and as photographs. The following are notes made during the infrared examination: The figures appear to have been transferred from a cartoon via pouncing. Traces of what appear to be spolveri are seen along the upper contour of the proper right foot of the Christ Child, in the folds of flesh at his proper right elbow, and in the fold of the Madonna’s robe beneath his proper left wrist. Whether or not pouncing was used to transfer the design (a technique that has been observed in infrared reflectograms of other paintings by Raphael), the contours were then reinforced in a liquid carbonaceous medium (that shows up clearly using IRR) using a fairly broad brush; this can be seen very clearly at the contour of the Child’s proper right knee and at the fold of his proper right wrist and elbow, as well as in the folds of the Madonna’s red robe, and elsewhere. (At the wrist, a thick line tapers to a point, where paint has pooled as the brush was lifted.) Finer lines are seen in for the features of the Child’s face and in the underdrawing of the hands. The arrangement of the hands and the book is the focus of the composition, and this is the only area where significant changes have taken place between the underdrawing and painting: the Child’s proper right hand was originally drawn in a more horizontal position, and then when it was raised, the fingers were drawn in what appear to be three different positions before settling on what we now see in paint. A joint of the ring finger in its original position was indicated with a little circle, a feature seen in other underdrawings, including the Garvagh Madonna. Other minor adjustments of contour, such as the lower contour of the Child’s proper right arm, which was painted slightly higher than the underdrawn line, are typical of the artist. The shadowed side of the book is cross-hatched. No underdrawing could be imaged in the landscape.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Infrared Photography of NG744, N-0744-00-000072, N-0744-00-000034
Gronau, George. Raffael. Berlin: Deutsche Verlags-Anstalt, 1923.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Because this picture represents a more extreme resolution of the subject of the Madonna and Child than any other of Raphael’s pre-Roman compositions, it has sometimes been dated to his early years in Rome, about 1508–12. The preparatory drawings are the most cogent arguments in favour of a dating around 1507, especially since the other compositions that are developed on these two sheets are usually dated to this period. The closest stylistic comparisons can be made with the Saint Catherine in the National Gallery. Like this saint, the Virgin has a characteristically Leonardesque twisted pose and a particularly poignant gaze. This has sometimes been related to a prefiguration of Christ’s destiny, and it has also been proposed that the child’s pose can be interpreted as waking from a dream in which he foresaw his future Passion. Whether or not this can be inferred, it is striking that Raphael breaks from convention to represent the child in such an active pose (just as he was also breaking free from the conventions of altarpieces in the exactly contemporary Entombment).

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Rome, Archivio di Stato, Odescalchi, VII E 10, Inventario de quadri della Regina di Svezia; unpublished

‘Raffaelle [...] 15 Christo che porta la Croce al Calvario istoriato con molte figure a piedi et a Cavallo con atti diversi, che lo strascinano di mirabile finitura, e la Beata Vergine Madre con altre sante Donne, e s. Giovanni dolenti che lo seguitano, tutto dipinto in tavola, alto palmi uno et un onciale, e longo palmi tre oncie dieci in circa con cornice dorata a mordente larga circa sei oncie. Questo quadro con li due seguenti sono fatti da Raffaelle che non era ancor di 30 anni e percio vi si conosce un poco del Perugino ma pero è sempre Raffaelle schietto e naturale. Questo quadro di gran lavoro, e finitura si pone sua stima luigi d’oro 5000 16 S. Francesco in piedi un libro in mani largo circa nove oncie et alto sopra un palmo con cornice dorata a mordente dell’istesso gusto, e lavoro pero una sola figura si pone per sua stima e presto luigi d’oro 800 17 S. Antonio di Padoua medesinam in piedi, e di consimili perfetto lavoro della sud.a grandezze cornice quadro in tutto compagno all altro sua stimato simile luigi d’oro 8000 (sic) Questi tre pezzi furono dalla Regina levati da una chiesa antica ultimamente, e sono riguardevoli per la loro schiettezza e finitura con disegno ben condotto, anzi non sono nell’inventario dell’Azzolini. Crede perche li diede a parte mentre non furono mai esposti vivente la Regina.’

‘Raphael [...] 15 Christ carrying the Cross to Calvary decorated with many figures walking and on horseback in different postures, who drag him wonderfully finished, and the Blessed Virgin Mother with other holy women, and St John sorrowful who follow him, the whole thing painted on a panel, one ‘palm’ and one ‘inch’ high, and about three ‘palms’ ten ‘inches’ wide, with a mordant gilt frame about six ‘inches’ wide. This painting with the two following are made by Raphael, who was not yet 30 years old and therefore one can see there a bit of Perugino but however it is still Raphael genuine and natural. This painting of great workmanship and finish is estimated at 5000 gold louis d’or. 16 St Francis standing with a book in hand large about nine ounces and high above one ‘palm’ with mordent gilt frame of the same taste, and workmanship but a single figure is estimated at the price of 800 gold louis d’or. 17. St Anthony of Padua similarly standing, and of the same perfect workmanship of the abovesaid size and frame, the painting in all a pendent to the other one its estimate is similar 8000 (sic) gold louis d’or. These three pieces were taken by the Queen lately from an ancient church, and are notable for their authorship and finish with a well made design, in fact they are not in Azzolini’s inventory. It is believed because she gave them separately while they were never exhibited during the lifetime of the Queen.’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The use of several overlapping lines around some contours, e.g. the Baptist’s raised forearm, shows Raphael refining and tightening his design on the panel but there are no major changes to the main figure group. The background, however, has been changed. The IRR shows that the landscape was continuous behind the Virgin with small buildings drawn above her left shoulder where the pillar is now painted.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: A small fragment, the only remaining part of the original edge of the painting, is preserved at upper left. This hints at a blue green underpaint which suggests that the figure group might originally have been set out of doors like the Belle Jardinière in Paris and the Canigiani Madonna in Munich. Since the scattered damages provided convenient sites for sampling the paint to make cross-sections, a series of samples were taken at intervals from the background around the figures and in the brown shape at upper right. All of these show a green to green/blue underlayer which strengthens the possibility of an outdoor setting.

The figure of Pleasure's red underdress has a mauve undermodelling which tends towards pure blue (ultramarine and lead white) in the shadows; the upper glaze is red lake with some vermilion in the shadows. On the sleeve, the red lake glaze shows evidence of blotting with a finger. Her pink and blue cangiante drapery consists of a pinkish-mauve combination of white, red lake (faded) and some ultramarine, with an ultramarine glaze to represent the bluest areas. There is a thin fragmentary line of gilding following the hem. The string of coral beads is pure vermilion.

Barberi, Catalogo ragionato della Galleria Camuccini in Roma, c. 1851, fol. 27v, bound manuscript in a clerical hand, Alnwick Castle Archives; another copy in the archive of the Camuccini heirs at Cantalupo; a translation ‘by D. C.’ also at Alnwick Castle (see also Penny 1992, p. 79 note 31). A manuscript inventory of the Camuccini collection, datable to the early 1850s, states that the painting was made for Maddalena degli Oddi, a nun in Perugia, from whose heirs a Frenchman acquired it in 1636, taking it to France. According to recent research conducted by Alberto Maria Sartore (Archivio di Stato, Perugia), Maddalena is said to have died before her son Giulio Cesare was poisoned in Rome on 4 March 1504, and one octogenarian witness declared in 1546 that he had been over 40 years old at Maddalena’s death (see Sartore forthcoming). This discounts her as a potential patron for the Madonna of the Pinks which has to be dated on stylistic grounds to about 1506-7.

‘Questa piccola tavola perfettamente conservata fu da Raffaelle condotta nella sua seconda maniera per Maddalena Degli Oddi, Monaca in Perugia […] innanzi l’anno 1636 un francese acquistò esso dipinto dagli eredi della Degli Oddi, e lo portò seco in Francia [...]’.

‘This small panel, perfectly preserved, was executed by Raphael in his second manner for Maddalena Degli Oddi, nun in Perugia […] before the year 1636 a Frenchman bought this painting from the heirs of [Maddalena] Degli Oddi, and brought it with him to France […]’

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Ce tableau a été identifié comme un original de Raphaël seulement en 1976 ; le duc d’Aumale l’avait acheté avec la collection de son oncle et beau-père le prince de Salerne comme une copie d’un un original perdu de Raphaël. La Madone de Lorette avait été peinte par l’artiste pour l’église de Sainte-Marie-du-Peuple à Rome, sans doute à la demande du pape Jules II, dont le portrait figurait également dans l’église. Les deux oeuvres y sont mentionnées par Vasari en 1550 et 1568 ; la Madone est gravée trois fois en 1553, 1572 et 1575, la gravure de 1572 mentionnant le tableau dans l’église. En 1591 le tableau fait partie des collections du Cardinal Sfondrato qui l’aurait détourné et donné des aumônes pour calmer le mécontentement. En 1608 sa collection est acquise par le Cardinal Scipion Borghese, mort en 1633. L’inventaire Borghese de 1693 cite La Madone de Lorette sous le n° 133 et le Portrait de Jules II (Londres, National Gallery) sous le n° 118, numéros qui correspondent à ceux peints sur la face des tableaux. En 1802 les Borghese vendent leur collection, le roi de Naples acquiert le tableau qui entre ainsi dans la collection du prince de Salerne. Le tableau fut identifié en 1976 grâce aux numéros d’inventaire de la collection Borghese par Cecil Gould, conservateur de la National Gallery de Londres, qui, travaillant sur le pendant, a pu établir l’historique des deux oeuvres. Le tableau a alors subi des analyses scientifiques qui ont montré qu’il s’agissait bien d’un original de Raphaël et une restauration qui a mis en valeur ses qualités picturales, jusque-là dissimulées sous d’épais vernis jaunis (un petit témoin de l’état avant restauration a été conservé en bas à gauche). Le nom de Lorette vient d’une copie du tableau de Raphaël qui se trouvait au XVIIIe siècle dans l’église de Lorette en Italie. L’iconographie montre un jeu profane entre une mère qui tend son voile à son enfant, mais le voile symbolise aussi le linceul et donc la Passion du Christ. Musée Condé

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: Powdered glass was also found in the imprimitura, the red lake glazes, the grey of the architecture, the dark brown of the canopy and the yellow-brown of the throne. It is likely that its function here too is primarily as a drier and not for its optical properties. It is unlikely to be an extender or bulking agent since it has been found in paint layers based on cheap earth pigments.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: As on p. 726 (here without footnotes)

The earliest witness for Raphael’s altarpiece is Vasari, who in 1568 observed the painting ‘in the church of the Servite friars in the chapel of the Ansidei’. Cesare Crispolti the elder, writing at the end of the sixteenth century, praised ‘the panel placed in the chapel of the Ansidei painted by Raphael of Urbino’, while Ottavio Lancellotti (d. 1670) recorded the altarpiece in the St Nicholas chapel in S. Fiorenzo founded by ‘Filippo di Ansidei di Catrano’. These early sources do not specify the location of the St Nicholas chapel within the church, nor does Filippo Ansidei’s final testament (see Appendix 1). A commemorative plaque of 1777 in S. Fiorenzo claims to record the location of Filippo Ansidei’s altar, but this post-dates the comprehensive rebuilding of 1768–70.

rdf:Description.crm:P3_has_note: The presence of a drying oil in each of the samples was confirmed by the detection of a large methyl azelate peak in the GC–MS trace. In the paint sample from the sky, the ratio of the palmitate and stearate fatty acid methyl esters indicated the use of walnut oil, while the ratio of the azelate and suberate dicarboxylic acid methyl esters pointed towards a heat-bodied oil (A/P 4.0; P/S 2.7; A/Sub 3.8). A similar result was obtained from the GC–MS analysis of the yellow paint from the bench, with the relevant ratios also indicating the use of heat-bodied walnut oil (A/P 5.1; P/S 2.4; A/Sub 1:4.1).

‘Gemälde bei Madame Sykes Wittwe. [...] Das Kleinod der Sammlung aber ist ein kleines Bild von Raphael, eine Jugendarbeit, ehemals in der Gallerie Borghese. [...] Von besonderem Interesse ist es, neben diesem Bildchen auch die Originalskizze dazu, sehr zierlich mit der Feder gezeichnet, sehen und vergleichen zu können. Die Umrisse der Zeichnung sind mit einer feinen Nadel durchstochen, woraus ersichtlich ist, dass sie zur Bause für das Bild diente. [...] Gestochen wurde es, soviel ich weiss, noch niemals.’

‘Lady Syke’s Pictures. […] The star of the collection, however, is a small picture by Raphael; a youthful work; formerly in the Borghese Palace. […] Lady Sykes also possesses the original sketch to this picture, delicately drawn with the pen; and the opportunity of examining these two works thus side by side, was no small gratification. The outlines of the sketch have been pricked though with a needle, which evidently shows that it served as a model for the picture. […] As far as my knowledge extends, it has never been engraved.’
